story:
UPDATE: see the impact that our first donated lights have in this special report from Papua new Guinea (Lights start at 1'50'' in this video).

Elevator pitch (small building version)

We designed the world's most affordable and durable solar-powered LED light. With our lights we want to eradicate the developing world of toxic and expensive kerosene lamps, solving many problems and creating a huge positive impact.

Our lights are perfect for home and outdoor usage as well, now you have to opportunity to pre-order some for yourself against a discounted price or donate lights to projects in need.

Note that the expected delivery of these lights is April-May, they are being produced right now!

Flexiway Solar: our Story

Flexiway Solar Solutions is a bootstrapped company started by 3 people who wanted to help people in Africa & Asia as well as our environment. We found that for over 1.5 billion people in developing countries depend on kerosene for lighting purposes and up to 30% of family income is used to pay for it, while these lights are the major cause of health fires & health problems and cause environmental damage.

From the beginning our goal has been to develop a simple, durable light that should cost $8 or less in developing countries and therefore can be earned back within one month of kerosene savings. The lights last at least 3 years and have replaceable rechargeable AAA batteries (included). After changing these the lights can work for many years more.

Our light exists, has been in the field for years and has had a huge positive impact; now we are ready for the next steps.

The Impact & change

Thousands of our lights have been produced and were used in the field for over 2 years and the impact and results are astounding. Children no longer have headaches and have improved their test scores, while their parents save 25-30% on their household costs and tons of CO2 were saved.

Women and children in a refugee camp felt safe at night and had time and light to relax and play. See the website and the video above for the 10 major positive impacts our light is making.

Version 2 of our light and our company: a new light, bigger plans to help out

We have incorporated all feedback and designed an even improved lightwhich we are producing right now. This light will change many people's lives and the first 3000 have already been received by an Australian NGO to be distributed in Papua New Guinea.

UPDATE: see the impact that our first donated lights have in this special report from Papua new Guinea (Lights start at 1'50'' in this video).

We prefer to work with NGO's as they have local knowledge, low overhead costs and we provide them the lights against the lowest costs possible; this is the cornerstone of our company.

We think big and our next project is focused on helping an entire country getting rid of kerosene lamps. Rwanda has been the victim of a brutal civil war and we want to help the people get back on their feet by supplying them all with affordable solar-powered lights. Some will be donated to the poorest, other will be sold directly or through Micro Credits.
Meanwhile our lights are also distributed in other developing countries and as the lights are so extremely useful, will now be sold to the western market as well.

We present: The Solar Muscle: unlimited smart light for everybody

In order to use solar-power, you need a Solar Muscle. Compacter, brighter, lighter, more waterproof, more functional, more powerful (both solarpanel + LED's), better batteries and more durable than our first successful light, yet more affordable!

We have redesigned the light based on feedback from users and the United Nations, who had already approved our lights for the Carbonmarket. We surpass all specifications required by SolarAfrica with a huge margin.

  • Our light has no separate parts as the solarpanel is integrated (backside)
  • It has only one button with 3 settings: off, 50% or 100% of the LED's will be on.
  • On a day's charge in the sun at least 7-8 hours of light (on full power) or double that (on 50%) will be available.
  • It can handle the rain and dust and a drop onto concrete.
  • Thin and small: it is only 9x9x2,5 cm / 3.5x3.5x1 inch and weighs only 120grams, roughly 1/4 lb! So it fits into a pocket!
  • You can connect any number of Solar Muscles together for a wall of light: connect 4 for a Solar Square, or get your 6-pack for full 200 lumens power!

The first lab tests confirmed that real life Luminosity is 33 Lumens (other lights often use theoretical luminosity, which is normally 50% higher). This is 4 times as much as a typical rural kerosene lamp (source: pdf), so even at the 50% setting we will double the light output compared to the toxic kerosene lamps!

One smart new feature is the connector on the side of the light: you can now connect a few to dozens of lights together: get 4 lights and you have the Solar Squared, and when you want superpower, you get the Solar Muscle Sixpack! Every light alone delivers enough light to light a room (or a tent, toilet, hallway etc), but together they really rock!

Not only the Africans have used our lights to save money, their health and houses and safety in refugee camps; we have used it ourselves as well. In Australia we saved up to $100/month in electrical bills using a couple of lights, in Argentina we used them during trekkings, during power cuts and even to feed our baby and to read in the night!

What We Need & What You Get

This IndieGoGo project is different than many others: our light exists and has proven itself and will definitely be produced. We have set our funding goal low as we offer the new lights to you here at such low margins that we cannot risk having to pay the additional 5% in IGG costs should we not reach our goal. Our real goal is $100.000 for this IndieGoGo project and millions more to eradicate entire countries of kerosene lamps.
 
What we need is to sell lights to the general public in developed countries in order to generate funds for a few essential next steps:

- Official 'Solar Africa' (SA) lighting laboratory tests: these cost $USD 3750 in total (tests +lights), but once finished our light will be one of the few that are approved and promoted by the UN/SA. The sooner, the better.
- Marketing, travel and setting up distribution: we need to send out many lights in order to get into new markets, both in developing as well as developed countries, update our websites and other marketing materials. Though we try to minimize travel, we still need to see our clients, factory, partners, trade fairs and others in person.
- Setting up new projects in other developing countries: we always need to donate the first batch of lights in order to introduce them, to show the benefits and to get UN approval.

Our lights are and will be sold to partners in developing countries for less than cost (cost = production costs + development costs + time worked by us). This is only possible because we have not paid ourselves a single cent so far and invested our own money. We will need to get paid at some point, but we won't charge more to NGO's and local projects. Instead we will sell these incredible lights to the general public, to subsidize our other projects while offering great lights against a great price to everybody.
The final price in the countries depend on transport options, order size, urgency, local taxes and fees and distribution costs, but should be lower than $10/light in most cases, making it the most affordable light, ever!

What you get is 3 choices and you can choose all!

- Help out one of our supported projects (Papua New Guinea, Rwanda, more to come) by donating lights. Every light donated will save a family up to $100/year (which is 25% of average household income) + save them from burns, lung disease and will improve their standards of living!
- Get our light for less than it will be sold for online later this year. You will help both yourself as us! For larger store or company orders, we can even create personalized lights (your own colour or logo).
- Support our efforts, either by one or both of the above or by donating directly to us as well

Our light will be produced for sure, we have already pre-paid our next order which will start soon (after Chinese New year!); delivery to us is expected early April, so then we can start sending them out. So if you order you will get one at the end of the project for sure, even if we do not reach our goal. However, if more are ordered/donated through IndieGoGo, we can make a much larger production run, lowering costs for transport etc.

 

Perks and benefits

The best you get is the knowledge that you are helping out the less fortunate as well as our planet. In addition, you can receive your own Solar Muscle lights against a discounted price. The lights are extremely useful and cost-saving. See all details in the sidebar for the perks. Most already include shipping!

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate your order and donations beyond what words can express. But if you want to help out even more or cannot afford a light at this moment, please help us in other ways:

 

(1): Share! Spread the word about our IndieGoGo project, our light and our website to your FB friends, Twitter followers, G+ circles, blog readers family, colleagues and even the guy/girl sitting next to you right now (it's a great conversation opener)!

(2): Publicity: do you work for a newspaper, blog or TV station or know someone? Let them and us know!

(3): Lead by example: use less fossil fuel, cycle where possible, and show the benefits of solar-power and renewable energy to others.

(4): Offset your business: contact us to discuss the possibilities by offsetting your company's CO2, by donating lights to one of our projects.

(5) Set up projects yourselves: we supply larger amounts of lights against even lower costs, especially to NGO's and other positive projects aimed at helping rather than profiting. Please see our info for NGO's on our website about how we can help each other.

 

If you want to make a large tax-deductible donation, contact us and we will set this up with our NGO partners.

 

Congratulations if you made it all the way to the bottom of this page! We really appreciate your time and effort and help in creating a better and cleaner world for everybody.

story:
LA VERSION FRANÇAISE SUIT

What can we do to help create a sustainable future, one in which the economy, environment, and human society exist in balance?

WE CAN_ be the voice of change at Earth Summit 2012

We Canada is seeking donations to support the baseline operating costs of our projects over the next seven months.  These are critical times for the Canadian sustainable development community, as Canada’s international reputation on sustainable development continues to worsen.  We want to ensure that there is a positive, meaningful, and responsible Canadian presence at Earth Summit 2012.  We want the diverse interests of Canadians to be represented, and to do that we need your support.  

We Canada was founded, and is run entirely on youth volunteer passion and power, and as such we rely on the support of our communities, partners, and generous sponsors.  Please support the work of We Canada as they work to ensure a healthy and sustainable future for Canada and for the world.

How you Can Help:
We are looking to raise $7,500 to cover the operating costs of the initiative from January 1 - June 30, 2012.  During this period, We Canada will be launching a number of incredible projects across the country.  We will be:
  1. Listening to Canadians and sharing concrete ideas and actions for a sustainable future by:
    1. Promoting 3 key policy ideas for a sustainable future (measuring what matters; getting the prices right and making trade fair) and what it means to put these in practice both here in Canada and globally;
    2. Conducting a cross-country speaking tour in elementary, and secondary schools, as well as universities with follow-up action through our network of partners;
    3. Running an intensive series of Earth Summit Dialogues across the country; and
    4. Running a national social media campaign, including contests and prizes, as We Canada and with the support of our high-profile Champions who collectively have hundreds of thousands of Twitter followers;

  1. Bringing Canadians’ voices to the United Nations by:
    1. Traveling to the United Nations in New York at the third Intersessional of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development;
    2. Being active contributors to the official negotiations as a coalition of concerned nonprofits and citizens;
    3. Attending the Canada-US Citizens Summit in New Haven, Connecticut; and
    4. Attending the Rio Earth Summit 2012 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, helping represent the concerns of Canadian civil society.


Background
We Canada was founded by the One Earth Initiative to encourage Canadian leadership at the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, or Earth Summit 2012, in Rio de Janeiro, June 2012. We Canada is a volunteer-run initiative, supported by the Canadian Earth Summit Coalition, a collection of non-governmental organizations (NGOs), campus groups, think tanks, and academics all working to promote ecological and economic sustainability, and social justice.

United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development (UNCSD)
The United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development  will be held in June of 2012 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The Conference is milestone commemoration of the 20th anniversary of the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, also known as the Rio Earth Summit.

The Rio Earth Summit was one of the largest gatherings of heads of state, civil society leaders, individuals and organisations in human history. These stakeholders met with the purpose of charting a course for a more sustainable future. From the Summit emerged agreements, most notably Agenda 21, which began the creation of a framework for developing global, national, and regional plans for sustainability. The Rio Earth Summit has since stood as an example of what is possible when governments and civil society work together.

Why Canadian leadership? Why now?
In difficult economic times, our collective attention has seemingly shifted away from environmental and social concerns. The government of Canada has seized this opportunity to firmly place environment, climate, and sustainability concerns on a back-burner, despite the continued demonstration by many Canadians that we do care about these issues. Sustainable development is about more than just environmental protection; it is also about creating meaningful and lasting green employment opportunities.

In comparison with past Earth Summits, our government has not held consultations with Canadians to provide input on what our country’s position at Earth Summit 2012 should be, a step away from the consistent praise that Canada has received as a world leader in democracy. Canadian voices need to be brought back into focus. What do we want our future to be?

What is We Canada?
We Canada is about stepping up where government has stepped back. We are about spreading knowledge and empowering people to make the change in their own lives. We foster dialogue and consultation among the public, responsible business networks and NGOs. We have forged a nation-wide civil society coalition and are developing relationships with similar initiatives in other countries. We are working to make the upcoming Earth Summit 2012 the tipping point for the sustainability movement.

How will we do this?
Specifically, the We Canada initiative has two main objectives:

  1. To empower Canadian citizens in supporting progressive policies on sustainable development for Earth Summit 2012 through community dialogues centred on the policies, and through We Canada’s online and offline outreach programmes

  2. To influence Canadian political actors to take on a leadership role in sustainable development at Earth Summit 2012 by acting as a vehicle for the hopes, wants, and concerns of Canadians to our government and the international community


***


VERSION FRANÇAISE

Que pouvons-nous faire pour créer un avenir durable où l’économie, l’environnement et la société humaine existent en équilibre?


OUI_ soyons la voix du changement au Sommet de la Terre 2012!


Oui Canada est à la recherche de dons pour soutenir ses coûts de fonctionnement pour les sept prochains mois. C’est un temps critique pour la communauté canadienne du développement durable alors que la réputation du Canada à l’échelle internationale empire jour après jour. Nous voulons nous assurer qu’une présence canadienne positive, sérieuse et responsable soit au Sommet de la Terre 2012 pour que les intérêts des Canadiens et des Canadiennes soient représentés. Pour ce faire, nous avons besoin de votre soutien.


Oui Canada a été fondée et est menée par la passion et la force de jeunes bénévoles. Ainsi, nous dépendons du soutien de nos communautés, de nos partenaires et de nos généreux commanditaires. Soutenez le travail de Oui Canada alors que l’équipe travaille dans le but d’assurer un avenir sain et durable pour le Canada et pour le monde.


Comment vous nous aiderez:

Notre objectif est de recueillir 7500$ pour couvrir les coûts de fonctionnement de l’initiative du 1er janvier au 30 juin 2012. Durant cette période, Oui Canada lancera une série de projets incroyables à travers le pays. Nous:


  1. Écouterons les Canadiens et les Canadiennes et partagerons des idées et des actions concrètes pour un avenir durable en:
    1. Promouvant trois idées de politique clés (Mesurer ce qui compte - aller au delà du PIB; Parvenir au juste prix - éliminer les subventions aux énergies fossiles et mettre un prix sur le carbone; Rendre le commerce équitable - Politique d’achat équitable pour le gouvernement du Canada) et ce que ça veut dire de les mettre en oeuvre au Canada et à l’échelle mondiale;
    2. Menant une tournée pan-canadienne dans des écoles élémentaires, secondaires et des universités;
    3. Menant une série intensive de Dialogues pour le Sommet de la Terre à travers le pays;
    4. Menant une campagne des médias sociaux nationale incluant des concours et des prix avec le soutien de nos Champions et de nos Championnes qui ont des centaines de milliers de personnes les suivant sur Twitter.


  1. Apportant les voix des Canadiens et des Canadiennes aux Nations Unies en:
    1. Voyageant aux Nations Unies à New York pour la troisième réunion intersession de la Conférences des Nations Unies sur le développement durable;
    2. Étant des contributeurs actifs lors des négociations officielles en tant qu’une coalition d’organismes à buts non-lucratifs et de citoyens;
    3. Participant au Sommet citoyen Canada - É.-U. qui aura lieu à New Haven, au Connecticut, et en
    4. Participant au Sommet de la Terre 2012 à Rio de Janeiro, au Brésil, pour aider à représenter les inquiétudes de la société civile canadienne.


Contexte

Oui Canada a été fondée par le One Earth Initiative Society pour encourager le leadership canadien lors de la Conférences des Nations Unies pour le développement durable, ou le Sommet de la Terre 2012, qui aura lieu à Rio de Janeiro en juin 2012. Oui Canada est une initiative menée par plus de 50 bénévoles et soutenue par la Coalition canadienne pour le Sommet de la Terre, un regroupement d’organisations non-gouvernementales (ONG), de groupes universitaires, de groupes de recherche et de groupes académiques qui travaillent tous pour promouvoir l’écologie, une économie durable et la justice sociale.


La Conférence des Nations Unies pour le développement durable (CNUDD)

La Conférence des Nations Unies pour le développement durable aura lieu en juin 2012 à Rio de Janeiro, au Brésil. La conférence est aussi la commémoration du 20e anniversaire de la Conférence des Nations Unies sur l’environnement et le développement qui a eu lieu à Rio en 1992 et connue comme le Sommet de la Terre de Rio.


Le Sommet de la Terre de Rio fut l’un des plus grands rassemblements de chefs d’États, de dirigeants de la société civile, d’individus et d’organismes de l’histoire humaine. Ces parties-prenantes se sont réunis avec l’objectif de créer un plan d’action pour un avenir durable. Du Sommet ont émergé des ententes, notamment Action 21, contribuant à la création d’un cadre pour le développement de plans mondiaux, nationaux et régionaux pour le développement durable. Depuis, le Sommet de la Terre de Rio est demeuré un exemple de ce qui est possible lorsque les gouvernements et la société civile travaillent de concert.


Pourquoi un leadership canadien? Pourquoi maintenant?

Durant cette époque économique difficile, notre attention collective semble s’être déplacée à l’écart des soucis environnementaux et sociaux. Le gouvernement du Canada a saisi cette occasion pour mettre les questions environnementales, climatiques et de justice sociale en veilleuse malgré le fait que plusieurs Canadiens et Canadiennes aient démontré se soucier de ces questions. Le développement durable est plus que la protection environnementale; c’est aussi à propos de créer des emplois verts significatifs et durables.


Notre gouvernement n’a pas encore mené de consultations avec les Canadiens et les Canadiennes pour qu’ils suggèrent ce que la position de notre pays devrait être au Sommet de la Terre 2012. Ceci est retourner un pas en arrière par rapport aux louanges que le Canada a autrefois reçu en tant que dirigeant mondial de la démocratie. Les voix des Canadiens et des Canadiennes doivent retourner au premier plan. Comment imaginons-nous notre avenir?


Oui Canada, c’est quoi?

Oui Canada, c’est aller de l'avant alors que le gouvernement va à reculons. Nous voulons disséminer des connaissances et donner le pouvoir aux gens pour qu’ils fassent un changement dans leur propre vie. Nous encouragerons le dialogue et les consultations parmi le public, des réseaux d’entreprises responsables et les ONGs. Nous avons créé une coalition nationale de la société civile et nous développons des relations avec de similaires initiatives dans d’autres pays. Nous voulons faire du Sommet de la Terre 2012 un moment charnière pour le mouvement du développement durable.

Bringing Canadians’ voices to the United Nations by:

Traveling to the United Nations in New York at the third Intersessional of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development;
Being active contributors to the official negotiations as a coalition of concerned nonprofits and citizens;
Attending the Canada-US Citizens Summit in New Haven, Connecticut; and

Attending the Rio Earth Summit 2012 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, helping represent the concerns of Canadian civil society.



Background We Canada was founded by the One Earth Initiative to encourage Canadian leadership at the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, or Earth Summit 2012, in Rio de Janeiro, June 2012. We Canada is a volunteer-run initiative, supported by the Canadian Earth Summit Coalition, a collection of non-governmental organizations (NGOs), campus groups, think tanks, and academics all working to promote ecological and economic sustainability, and social justice.United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development (UNCSD)The United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development  will be held in June of 2012 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The Conference is milestone commemoration of the 20th anniversary of the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, also known as the Rio Earth Summit.The Rio Earth Summit was one of the largest gatherings of heads of state, civil society leaders, individuals and organisations in human history. These stakeholders met with the purpose of charting a course for a more sustainable future. From the Summit emerged agreements, most notably Agenda 21, which began the creation of a framework for developing global, national, and regional plans for sustainability. The Rio Earth Summit has since stood as an example of what is possible when governments and civil society work together.Why Canadian leadership? Why now? In difficult economic times, our collective attention has seemingly shifted away from environmental and social concerns. The government of Canada has seized this opportunity to firmly place environment, climate, and sustainability concerns on a back-burner, despite the continued demonstration by many Canadians that we do care about these issues. Sustainable development is about more than just environmental protection; it is also about creating meaningful and lasting green employment opportunities.In comparison with past Earth Summits, our government has not held consultations with Canadians to provide input on what our country’s position at Earth Summit 2012 should be, a step away from the consistent praise that Canada has received as a world leader in democracy. Canadian voices need to be brought back into focus. What do we want our future to be?What is We Canada? We Canada is about stepping up where government has stepped back. We are about spreading knowledge and empowering people to make the change in their own lives. We foster dialogue and consultation among the public, responsible business networks and NGOs. We have forged a nation-wide civil society coalition and are developing relationships with similar initiatives in other countries. We are working to make the upcoming Earth Summit 2012 the tipping point for the sustainability movement.How will we do this? Specifically, the We Canada initiative has two main objectives:
To empower Canadian citizens in supporting progressive policies on sustainable development for Earth Summit 2012 through community dialogues centred on the policies, and through We Canada’s online and offline outreach programmes

To influence Canadian political actors to take on a leadership role in sustainable development at Earth Summit 2012 by acting as a vehicle for the hopes, wants, and concerns of Canadians to our government and the international community



***

VERSION FRANÇAISE


Que pouvons-nous faire pour créer un avenir durable où l’économie, l’environnement et la société humaine existent en équilibre?

OUI_ soyons la voix du changement au Sommet de la Terre 2012!

Oui Canada est à la recherche de dons pour soutenir ses coûts de fonctionnement pour les sept prochains mois. C’est un temps critique pour la communauté canadienne du développement durable alors que la réputation du Canada à l’échelle internationale empire jour après jour. Nous voulons nous assurer qu’une présence canadienne positive, sérieuse et responsable soit au Sommet de la Terre 2012 pour que les intérêts des Canadiens et des Canadiennes soient représentés. Pour ce faire, nous avons besoin de votre soutien.

Oui Canada a été fondée et est menée par la passion et la force de jeunes bénévoles. Ainsi, nous dépendons du soutien de nos communautés, de nos partenaires et de nos généreux commanditaires. Soutenez le travail de Oui Canada alors que l’équipe travaille dans le but d’assurer un avenir sain et durable pour le Canada et pour le monde.

Comment vous nous aiderez:
Notre objectif est de recueillir 7500$ pour couvrir les coûts de fonctionnement de l’initiative du 1er janvier au 30 juin 2012. Durant cette période, Oui Canada lancera une série de projets incroyables à travers le pays. Nous:



Écouterons les Canadiens et les Canadiennes et partagerons des idées et des actions concrètes pour un avenir durable en:



Promouvant trois idées de politique clés (Mesurer ce qui compte - aller au delà du PIB; Parvenir au juste prix - éliminer les subventions aux énergies fossiles et mettre un prix sur le carbone; Rendre le commerce équitable - Politique d’achat équitable pour le gouvernement du Canada) et ce que ça veut dire de les mettre en oeuvre au Canada et à l’échelle mondiale;


Menant une tournée pan-canadienne dans des écoles élémentaires, secondaires et des universités;


Menant une série intensive de Dialogues pour le Sommet de la Terre à travers le pays;


Menant une campagne des médias sociaux nationale incluant des concours et des prix avec le soutien de nos Champions et de nos Championnes qui ont des centaines de milliers de personnes les suivant sur Twitter.






Apportant les voix des Canadiens et des Canadiennes aux Nations Unies en:



Voyageant aux Nations Unies à New York pour la troisième réunion intersession de la Conférences des Nations Unies sur le développement durable;


Étant des contributeurs actifs lors des négociations officielles en tant qu’une coalition d’organismes à buts non-lucratifs et de citoyens;


Participant au Sommet citoyen Canada - É.-U. qui aura lieu à New Haven, au Connecticut, et en


Participant au Sommet de la Terre 2012 à Rio de Janeiro, au Brésil, pour aider à représenter les inquiétudes de la société civile canadienne.




Contexte
Oui Canada a été fondée par le One Earth Initiative Society pour encourager le leadership canadien lors de la Conférences des Nations Unies pour le développement durable, ou le Sommet de la Terre 2012, qui aura lieu à Rio de Janeiro en juin 2012. Oui Canada est une initiative menée par plus de 50 bénévoles et soutenue par la Coalition canadienne pour le Sommet de la Terre, un regroupement d’organisations non-gouvernementales (ONG), de groupes universitaires, de groupes de recherche et de groupes académiques qui travaillent tous pour promouvoir l’écologie, une économie durable et la justice sociale.

La Conférence des Nations Unies pour le développement durable (CNUDD)
La Conférence des Nations Unies pour le développement durable aura lieu en juin 2012 à Rio de Janeiro, au Brésil. La conférence est aussi la commémoration du 20e anniversaire de la Conférence des Nations Unies sur l’environnement et le développement qui a eu lieu à Rio en 1992 et connue comme le Sommet de la Terre de Rio.

Le Sommet de la Terre de Rio fut l’un des plus grands rassemblements de chefs d’États, de dirigeants de la société civile, d’individus et d’organismes de l’histoire humaine. Ces parties-prenantes se sont réunis avec l’objectif de créer un plan d’action pour un avenir durable. Du Sommet ont émergé des ententes, notamment Action 21, contribuant à la création d’un cadre pour le développement de plans mondiaux, nationaux et régionaux pour le développement durable. Depuis, le Sommet de la Terre de Rio est demeuré un exemple de ce qui est possible lorsque les gouvernements et la société civile travaillent de concert.

Pourquoi un leadership canadien? Pourquoi maintenant?
Durant cette époque économique difficile, notre attention collective semble s’être déplacée à l’écart des soucis environnementaux et sociaux. Le gouvernement du Canada a saisi cette occasion pour mettre les questions environnementales, climatiques et de justice sociale en veilleuse malgré le fait que plusieurs Canadiens et Canadiennes aient démontré se soucier de ces questions. Le développement durable est plus que la protection environnementale; c’est aussi à propos de créer des emplois verts significatifs et durables.

Notre gouvernement n’a pas encore mené de consultations avec les Canadiens et les Canadiennes pour qu’ils suggèrent ce que la position de notre pays devrait être au Sommet de la Terre 2012. Ceci est retourner un pas en arrière par rapport aux louanges que le Canada a autrefois reçu en tant que dirigeant mondial de la démocratie. Les voix des Canadiens et des Canadiennes doivent retourner au premier plan. Comment imaginons-nous notre avenir?

Oui Canada, c’est quoi?
Oui Canada, c’est aller de l'avant alors que le gouvernement va à reculons. Nous voulons disséminer des connaissances et donner le pouvoir aux gens pour qu’ils fassent un changement dans leur propre vie. Nous encouragerons le dialogue et les consultations parmi le public, des réseaux d’entreprises responsables et les ONGs. Nous avons créé une coalition nationale de la société civile et nous développons des relations avec de similaires initiatives dans d’autres pays. Nous voulons faire du Sommet de la Terre 2012 un moment charnière pour le mouvement du développement durable.

story:
Decades of Pollution & Zero testing

We need a lot of small donors to help protect kids and schools in these dense pollution zones.  Are you passionate about data and kids? 

Let me introduce myself and why I started this project:

  • I am a teacher and resident of a neighborhood with toxic air
  • I have a daughter with occasional and random coughing
  • My District is bisected by 2 different freeways (5 &205)
  • Testing is a key step to removing pollution.
  • This would be the second such project in Oregon History.
  • The equipment and contractor has a proven record in other states.
  • My lawmaker is ineffective, so I'm starting this project and running for office

Why are we asking you to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

  • we have found several scientists from Oakland who help communities setup toxic air monitoring systems in a way that produces valid data for enforcement.  Their startup costs are $8,000
  • http://www.gcmonitor.org
  • Donating here prevents pollution,  and saves everyone money.
  • Donating here will help train students and teachers
  • Several local schools and teachers will have the opportunity to have field trips and guest speakers.  
  • Using this data lawmakers we will force lawmakers into action.  We are tired of promises that never lead to reductions or penalties for polluting our air.   We need more of this test equipment.  It will save us money statewide.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Tell friends and make some noise about this donor campaign.
  • Call your lawmaker at this URL below
  • http://gov.oregonlive.com/legislators/

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Investigating matrifocal ways of social organisation (in humans and Elephants) as a means to discover principles that could contribute to a philosophy of Eco-Civilisation.

Summary

Since December 2013, as an honorary research fellow at OASES graduate school, I have been undertaking research in the field of Eco-civilisation. This work led me to investigate my own community in Kerala, South India and my ancestry to understand their relationship with Earth.  
To my astonishment, I discovered a rich heritage of matriarchal clan living with sacred snake groves, Goddess worship, gender equality and a close relationship to elephants. A form of this way of living was practised by my ancestors up until the 1920s in Kerala.  Elephants in particular, with their matriarchal clan living, are important and have a formidable presence in the lives of people living along the Western Ghats of South India.
With my research in Eco-Civilisation, I am trying to find principles for 'a social formation, consistent with the repair and ongoing renewal of the biosphere'. I believe that Matrifocal forms of social organisation are significant with their unique gender relations and deep engagement with the greater living system; the Earth herself.  

This Crowd-funding appeal is for a field trip to South India to:

1) Document living memories of my own ancestors, and also of other matrifocal communities in Kerala and along the Western Ghats.

2) Investigate and record folk-tales, rituals, and other clues that might exist today that might be able to throw light on past ways of matrifocal kinship.

3) Liaise with ecologists working with Asian elephants in these areas to learn about records of particular clan behaviour and matrifocal kinship among elephants in the area.

4) Liaise with researchers in Kerala working in this field.

5) Source relevant books and materials in Malayalam.

6) Employ auto-ethnographic and embodied methods of qualitative research while on the field-trip to record my own journey to claim my ancestry and my inheritance of power.

Owing to my ancestral heritage of matrifocal kinship and the geographical location of my ancestral land in the vicinity of the Western Ghats, which is also home to other matrifocal human as well as elephant communities, the focus of my research will be geographically limited to the Western Ghats of India. This gives me the advantage of familiarity and connections to locals in the area.  Further, proficiency in my mother tongue, Malayalam, gives me the privilege of undertaking bilingual research, sourcing materials written in Malayalam and conducting interviews.  Also, access to sacred places, including temples, allows me to record the matrifocal elements with ecological relevance still practised today in the form of rituals, ceremonies and sacred rites.


Why is this important?

The journey so far has been challenging as I learn more about my own heritage and try to understand it’s implications for the world and myself. I have come to realise that this knowledge is not only important for me, but is also very relevant for the world. The reason I started this work was to look for old ways of being that could be recovered and made meaningful in our modern context. As capitalism blurs our vision and blunts our moral and ethical sensibilities, it becomes harder and harder to know how to be in this world. It is important in this conjuncture to explore ways of being together, as a society, to consider steps for moving forward. This is something we forget as we run around trying to come up with political, social and technological solutions to our global problems.

Matrifocal ways of living have been practised by humans and animals for a very long time; Whales and Elephants are mammalian examples while Humans and Bonobos are examples of apes[15]. In this era of globalisation, where cultural identities and boundaries are dissolving, humans are in a position to choose how to be in this world and how to relate to Earth. This research will provide a glimpse in to one way of living and relating that has been abandoned by most humans, but still practised by non-human apes and other mammals. I believe that there are important lessons to be learned that could be made meaningful in our modern context; this will provide one strand of a rope that we, as humans, can use to climb out of the mess we have created for ourselves. I believe what I have stumbled on with my work can be an invaluable resource and an important addition to the growing theory of Eco- civilisation.


Why I need your support

As an honorary research fellow at OASES Graduate School, Melbourne, I have been researching this topic in my own time. I have had incredible support from OASES, without which this work might not have come this far. However, OASES Graduate School is not in a position to fund my field-trip; They are a not-for-profit organisation already stretching their resources to do all the good that they are currently doing in this world. 

Because of my VISA situation, I will be considered an International student if I were to apply for a PHD at any university in Australia. This means that I will have to pay $22,000 per year as an International student. I am not in a financial situation to afford this. I have been told that scholarships for International students who already live and work in Australia, especially in the field of Environmental Philosophy, is hard to come by. This left me in a challenging situation at the end of 2013, having to decide between waiting two years for my VISA situation to change or undertake the research independently with institutional support from OASES Graduate School. I chose the latter as it is very clear to me that this research gives meaning to my life and purpose to my time. 

As mentioned earlier, I have come to a point where I need to go to Kerala to continue my research . This crowd-funding campaign is to raise funds for this field-trip. I have tried getting support through grants from institutions such as the Australia-India Council, but did not meet the eligibility criteria as I am not an Australian Permanent Resident and also because they expect research institutions to fund projects like this. As an immigrant, I also fall through the cracks of most grant-programs that are set up for this sort of research. Being an international student is not an option I can follow even if I decide to borrow money from the bank as Australian Banks do not give loans to immigrants who are not permanent residents. 

Having exhausted all my options I have turned to crowd funding. I do this with the courage that this work has given me and through the conviction that what I am doing is important not only for me, but also for the world. I hope that you are able to see this, that you are moved by my story so far, and that you are inspired to support me through the next leg of my journey.  I thank you from the bottom of my heart for reading my story and for your consideration to support this project.


Research Background

Since December 2013, as an honorary research fellow at OASES Graduate School, I have been undertaking research in the field of Eco-civilisation. What drew me to undertake this research was Freya Matthews’ work on philosophy of bio-mimicry[1] and theory of Eco-civilisation.

Freya Matthews (2013)[2] defines ‘Eco-Civilization’, as a ‘social formation, consistent with the repair and ongoing renewal of the biosphere.’  She also states that an inter-civilisational dialogue will be ‘key in the discovery of cultural and philosophical foundations for Eco-Civilisation in the west.’

Old civilisations of the world, whose philosophies of their engagement with the living Universe were developed far before industrialisation may still hold clues to principles of biomimetic engagement with the universe. These principles, when recovered, could be used to lay the foundational philosophy for an Eco-Civilisation. This requires an inter-civilisational dialogue - to remember and renovate old ideas in new forms that will contribute to a re-awakening of human civilisations through a re-engagement with the living Universe, each through their own unique narratives, yet, together in their goal of Eco-Civilisation.

I wanted to respond to Freya's call for an inter-civilisational dialogue by contributing to this idea of Eco-Civilisation using my background of Indian civilisation.

At the onset of my research, I wanted to look at Indian philosophy to tease out principles that might contribute to an Eco-Civilisation. But it soon became too large and too complex a task to undertake. ‘Indian Philosophy’ encompasses many different philosophies, and Hinduism is a constantly renewing process and can only be called a way of living that changes according to geographic locations, historical migrations and political interventions.

In order to find a grounding point in this revolving chaos that I found myself in, and with invaluable guidance form my supervisors, Freya Matthews and Jacque Boulet, I began to look in to my own ancestry. This was my way into a particular component of Indian philosophy, investigating what particular philosophy influenced my ancestors, what was their relationship with nature, and to see what principles, if any, could be applicable to an Eco-Civilisation in the modern context.

This has turned out to be the most challenging, meaningful and rewarding work that I have ever done. As I began to investigate my own community from Kerala I found out facts that not only astonished me, but also challenged what I knew about this world and who I knew myself to be in this world.


Cultural Background

I belong to a caste/community called ‘Nair’ from Kerala.  Kerala is bounded by the sea on one side and a mountain range called Western Ghats on the other. Growing up, I knew that my community used to be matrilineal and I understood this to mean that women of the family inherited land and had rights to property. I was never given any indication that it meant anything else. Nor did my immediate family structure or circumstances give any clues to a different past. 

I grew up in a conservative and patriarchal household, though modern in its outlook. My parents had accepted modernity with gusto to bring up two daughters, with conservatism liberally sprinkled in for ‘our protection’. We were allowed a long leash, and we experienced more freedom than most of our counterparts. We knew we were lucky to have parents who did not restrict us from doing what we wanted just because we were girls. We were taught values of love, kindness, generosity and family.

 I was brought up to understand that as a woman, my agency comes from being like a man and ‘making it’ in life.  I believed that education and a ‘good’ career will prove that I am equal. I also understood early on that as a girl, fear will be my constant companion along with shame. I learnt that I have to cover my body in-order to protect myself and that ‘good girls’ don’t have boy-friends. All through adolescence and early adulthood, I was ridden with guilt for being ‘bad’ in many different ways, from having boyfriends to asking too many questions. My life then was a constant struggle to hide my ‘bad-ness’ from my family and society in general. For years I went round and round in confused masochistic circles, trying to make sense of it all. 

It was a long and arduous journey for me to recognise the power within myself, as an individual and as a woman. I had blamed, for a large part, my cultural background for my feelings of powerless-less as a woman. My life in India was ridden with instances and stories of marital violence, abuse, rape and girl-child marriages. It seemed to me that if you were born in to that cultural context, you were doomed to a life of servitude, unless you fight tooth and nail to get out of it, somehow.


Research findings, so far

My Ancestors

Through my research during the last six months, I have learned that most of what I considered to be my cultural tradition is, in fact, only a few generations old, created by the influence of patriarchal Brahmanism, colonial law, and more recently, modernity through western development.

I have learned that my real cultural inheritance is not one of servitude, but one of incredible power. My research took me to a world of matriarchal clan living[3], where women made decisions not only about their own lives, but also for the whole clan. It took me to a world were women had lovers, not husbands[4]; where women, dressed the same as men and lived in an egalitarian clan structure in which men and women were equals[5]. I have learned that equality for women is not a modern concept. There were communities that practised equality in deeper ways than what we experience in our society today[6]; and that I belong to one such community.

I was shocked and felt betrayed by society. “Why didn’t anyone tell me??” In High School, we had two large history text books on the Second World War. I had to memorise who defeated whom in battles that ancient kings of India engaged in for no particular reason. Yet, all through school, university, and most of my life, I was ignorant about the history of my own people.  What shocked me most was the fact that a form of this matriarchal way of living was practised up until 1920s[7] - This was how my great-great grandmother lived.  It was challenging to reconcile with that fact that everything could be forgotten in just four generations; a period of time in which a whole community of women were displaced, from a position of power to that of servitude and shame.

As I investigated further, I began to uncover the depth of meaning of rituals and ceremonies that the Nair community still practise, remnants of more elaborate rituals from the past; most of which served to maintain the close relationship they had with the Earth. Nair clan houses always had a part of their property set aside as sacred groves. They also looked after temple elephants. I began to understand the relevance of stories and instances from my childhood with this perspective of ancient history and mythology.

Every clan house looked after ecologically significant sacred groves that housed many snakes. The oldest woman of the clan maintained a sacred relationship with the snakes and was the priestess of the sacred grove. Although I don’t remember a sacred grove in the house I grew up, I remember that snakes had a constant presence in my childhood, brushing against my feet as I played among the mango trees.  I remember distinctly being told that if I ever chance upon a mating ritual of snakes, I should not disturb them, nor should I stare. I was told that it was their sacred rite and I should respect their privacy.

A typical clan house had several sacred rooms, which housed the clan goddess (Bhagavati and/or Badrakali) as well as figures representing their ancestors[8]. Goddesses worship is still very strong in Kerala, with many goddess temples still preserving ecologically significant scared groves. The kindergarten I attended was inside a small Durga temple that had a sacred grove for the Snake gods. As we played hide-and-seek inside the sacred grove, presence of the fierce goddess felt comforting to my little heart that beat a little too fast with the fear of snakes. As my friend counted to ten with her eyes closed, I would always look up to the sky to spot the Eagle gods, cousins and rivals of Snake Gods, to say a small prayer for extra protection before venturing into the scared grove to hide.  

Nair men had a special relationship with temple elephants; folktales of this elephant-human friendship have been collected and published across Kerala. I remember my grandfather’s fondness for temple elephants, and was fortunate enough to have young temple elephants as playmates for many summers of my childhood. They would come for ten days every year, during the temple festival. We fed them giant rice balls filled with jaggery (palm sugar). I remember rough skin, soft pink tongue, beautiful long eye lashes; tenderness with which they picked me up, giant trunks wound around my small thin body.  

There are other communities in Kerala that used to practise matrifocal[9] kinship. These are mainly the Parayans and the Pulayans, who were subjugated by the warrior-like Nairs and later became slaves and untouchables in the caste hierarchy that was forced by patriarchal Brahmin invaders[10]. With great pain, I have to own up to the unimaginable violence that my ancestors had unleashed upon these communities; it included bonded labour, violence, rape and even beheadings for trivial matters such as crossing the path a Nair man was walking on. This serves as my grounding point in reminding me not to idealise the past. It also, more importantly, makes it crucial for me to investigate and document matrifocal kinship in these communities and their relationship to nature.

Western Ghats and Elephants

The geographical location of these communities, including that of my ancestors, is a dominant feature that cannot be ignored. Even today, the rainforests along the Western Ghats and the mountain range itself has a formidable presence in the life of people of Kerala, and to some extend in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Maharashtra where it spills over in to these states. It served as a protective barrier during different eras of colonisation and also helped preserve the unique cultural identity of the communities that lived here. Matrifocal elements have been recorded in communities all along the Western Ghats, with strong matrifocal regions in Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu[11]. Another interesting feature of this geographical location is the ecological significance of the place itself.  The Western Ghats, a UNESCO world heritage listed site, is one of the ‘eight ‘hottest hotspots’ of biological diversity in the world’[12]. The world’s single largest population of Asian Elephants live here. Encounters with wild Elephants are common occurrences in many parts of the Western Ghats; they are a part of everyday life that children going to school or women going to work have have to be wary of. 

Communities living here have co-existed with Elephants, wild and tame, for centuries. This relationship has become strained in recent times with shrinking forests, increasing human population and encroaching development.  Human-Elephant conflict in the Western Ghats is an issue that has resulted in many fatalities, both of Elephants and humans in the recent past[13].  This strong presence of Elephants in the lives of these communities is a fact that has special significance for my research when viewed from the perspective of matrifocal social organisation. Elephants live in matriarchal clans; matriarchal kin-ship amongst both Asian and African Elephants is well documented[14]. This has led me to look at matrifocal kinship amongst Asian elephants as a non-human version of this particular type of social organisation.  


Next Steps

As I spent more time on this research, I realised that it is now a very important part of my life.  Managing a couple of part time jobs and volunteering for few organisations has meant that it has taken a while - in fact six months - to reach where I am at the moment. I also do not have access to online journals or libraries other than the OASES libraries (which are great resources). This has meant that I have had to spend days in libraries, and lately most of my spare time, trying to find as much written material as available on this topic. As much as this has helped me to build theoretical groundwork, I find myself lacking in resources to continue this research. I have also found many references of relevant books and articles written in Malayalam. Apart from a few articles that I found online, most of these are currently out of my reach simply because they are not available to me here in Melbourne. I have realised that I have reached a stage where I need to go to Kerala to continue this work.

On a personal level, this work has had a deep impact on me and has consumed my mind, my thoughts and my dreams. It has become difficult to continue with my everyday life, as it feels disjointed from the thoughts that occupy my mind most of the time. Conversations with my mother about what she remembers, which is not much; passing on questions to great aunts who remember a lot; thinking of my great grand-mother, Lakshmi-Kutty Amma, my namesake; wondering about a sacred grove in our ancestral home that I have just come to know about; discussions with my sister about our grandmother, who seemed to have remembered in her body even if not in her conscious mind. Conversations with my great aunts have convinced me that I need to record their memories before it is too late. They represent my last link to a culture that is on the verge of disappearing forever. I have realised that I need to be physically present in the place to bring some calm to the storm that is in my mind and my heart. I need to touch the earth of my homeland, feel the weight of the humid air and drink the sweet water from the well in my ancestral home. I need to claim my ancestry. 

For these reasons, I have decided that the next step in my research journey is to visit Kerala.


Financial Support Details

Field Trip to South India from 1st September to 1st November 2014 (60 days)

The total minimum amount that is required for the trip is $1,594.20.

Accommodation

$ 496.20 

Food

$ 288 

Travel (India)
