[1] In examining the philosophy of Bio-mimicry, Freya Matthews (2011) argues that the proponents of the science of Bio-mimicry are not taking their questions far enough. She questions the very method of seeking a biomimetic means to our consumer ends. She claims that we could question of our ends, [or our wants]- Could they be bio-mimetic? She argues that a truly sustainable world could philosophically be a bio-mimetic one, where there is ‘an entire culture of engagement’..[with the Universe].. ‘whereby our sense of our own meaning is suffused with the meanings of …[this living Universe]’. She warns ‘it is crucial to address the question of what the life system wants us to want if we wish to achieve environmental sustainability, because in the longer term we simply will not be able to devise means which systematically nourish the greater life-system unless our ends are cross-referenced to the ends of the other elements of that system.’ She points out that this engagement or cross-referencing of ends happens in a synergistic mode. Principles of this bio-mimetic engagement within a synergistic mode could be used to develop the foundational philosophy for an Eco-Civilisation. Freya Mathews (2011) identifies two such principles: 1) The principle of conativity 2) The principle of least resistance. The Daoist category of Wu-Wei is an example of the latter principle of least- resistance. Reference: Freya Mathews, “Towards a Deeper Philosophy of Biomimicry”, Organization and Environment, 24, 4, 2011

[2] Freya Mathews, “Eco-civilization: a Manifesto”, 2013

[3] Savithri Shankar de Toureill, “Nayars of Kerala and Matriliny revisited,” in Heidi Goettner-Abendroth (eds), Societies of Peace: Matriarchies past, present and future, Inanna Publications, Toronto, 2009

[4] G.Arunima, “There Comes Papa: Colonialism and the Transformation of Matriliny in Kerala, Malabar, c. 1850-1940”, Orient Longman, New Delhi, 2003

[5] Heidi Goettner-Abendroth, “Matriarchal Societies, Studies on Indigenous Cultures Across the Globe”, Peter Lang, 2012

[6] Eleanor Burke Leacock, “Myths of Male Dominance - Collected Articles on Women Cross-Culturally”, Monthly Review Press, New York, 1981.

[7]G.Arunima, “There Comes Papa: Colonialism and the Transformation of Matriliny in Kerala, Malabar, c. 1850-1940”, Orient Longman, New Delhi, 2003

[8]Heidi Goettner-Abendroth, “Matriarchal Societies, Studies on Indigenous Cultures Across the Globe”, Peter Lang, 2012

[9] Matrifocal-meaning mother-centered. I have decided to use this term to encompass matriarchal and/or matrilineal and/or matrilocal ways of social organisation as all of these represent a distinct separation from patriarchy. There are many academic disputes over definitions of these terms, the resolution of which is neither the aim nor scope of this research project.

[10] Heidi Goettner-Abendroth, “Matriarchal Societies, Studies on Indigenous Cultures Across the Globe”, Peter Lang, 2012

[11] Heidi Goettner-Abendroth, “Matriarchal Societies, Studies on Indigenous Cultures Across the Globe”, Peter Lang, 2012

[12] "Western Ghats", Whc.unesco.org, Retrieved 2014-07-08

[13] R. Sukumar, “Wildlife-human conflict in India: an ecological and social perspective”, in Guha, R. (ed.) Social Ecology, Oxford University Press, New Delhi, 1994.

[14] R. Sukumar, “Elephant Days and Nights: Ten Years with the Indian Elephant”, Oxford University Press, New Delhi, 1994.

R. Sukumar, “The Living Elephants: Evolutionary Ecology, Behavior and Conservation” Oxford University Press, New York, 2003.

[15] Christopher Ryan, and Cacilda Jetha, “Sex At Dawn - The Prehistoric Origins of Modern Sexuality”, Harper Collins, New York, 2010.
story_txt:
Investigating matrifocal ways of social organisation (in humans and Elephants) as a means to discover principles that could contribute to a philosophy of Eco-Civilisation.SummarySince December 2013, as an honorary research fellow at OASES graduate school, I have been undertaking research in the field of Eco-civilisation. This work led me to investigate my own community in Kerala, South India and my ancestry to understand their relationship with Earth.  To my astonishment, I discovered a rich heritage of matriarchal clan living with sacred snake groves, Goddess worship, gender equality and a close relationship to elephants. A form of this way of living was practised by my ancestors up until the 1920s in Kerala.  Elephants in particular, with their matriarchal clan living, are important and have a formidable presence in the lives of people living along the Western Ghats of South India.
With my research in Eco-Civilisation, I am trying to find principles for 'a social formation, consistent with the repair and ongoing renewal of the biosphere'. I believe that Matrifocal forms of social organisation are significant with their unique gender relations and deep engagement with the greater living system; the Earth herself.  


This Crowd-funding appeal is for a field trip to South India to:

1) Document living memories of my own ancestors, and also of other matrifocal communities in Kerala and along the Western Ghats.
2) Investigate and record folk-tales, rituals, and other clues that might exist today that might be able to throw light on past ways of matrifocal kinship.
3) Liaise with ecologists working with Asian elephants in these areas to learn about records of particular clan behaviour and matrifocal kinship among elephants in the area.
4) Liaise with researchers in Kerala working in this field.
5) Source relevant books and materials in Malayalam.
6) Employ auto-ethnographic and embodied methods of qualitative research while on the field-trip to record my own journey to claim my ancestry and my inheritance of power.Owing to my ancestral heritage of matrifocal kinship and the geographical location of my ancestral land in the vicinity of the Western Ghats, which is also home to other matrifocal human as well as elephant communities, the focus of my research will be geographically limited to the Western Ghats of India. This gives me the advantage of familiarity and connections to locals in the area.  Further, proficiency in my mother tongue, Malayalam, gives me the privilege of undertaking bilingual research, sourcing materials written in Malayalam and conducting interviews.  Also, access to sacred places, including temples, allows me to record the matrifocal elements with ecological relevance still practised today in the form of rituals, ceremonies and sacred rites.

Why is this important?
The journey so far has been challenging as I learn more about my own heritage and try to understand it’s implications for the world and myself. I have come to realise that this knowledge is not only important for me, but is also very relevant for the world. The reason I started this work was to look for old ways of being that could be recovered and made meaningful in our modern context. As capitalism blurs our vision and blunts our moral and ethical sensibilities, it becomes harder and harder to know how to be in this world. It is important in this conjuncture to explore ways of being together, as a society, to consider steps for moving forward. This is something we forget as we run around trying to come up with political, social and technological solutions to our global problems.
Matrifocal ways of living have been practised by humans and animals for a very long time; Whales and Elephants are mammalian examples while Humans and Bonobos are examples of apes[15]. In this era of globalisation, where cultural identities and boundaries are dissolving, humans are in a position to choose how to be in this world and how to relate to Earth. This research will provide a glimpse in to one way of living and relating that has been abandoned by most humans, but still practised by non-human apes and other mammals. I believe that there are important lessons to be learned that could be made meaningful in our modern context; this will provide one strand of a rope that we, as humans, can use to climb out of the mess we have created for ourselves. I believe what I have stumbled on with my work can be an invaluable resource and an important addition to the growing theory of Eco- civilisation.


Why I need your support
As an honorary research fellow at OASES Graduate School, Melbourne, I have been researching this topic in my own time. I have had incredible support from OASES, without which this work might not have come this far. However, OASES Graduate School is not in a position to fund my field-trip; They are a not-for-profit organisation already stretching their resources to do all the good that they are currently doing in this world. 
Because of my VISA situation, I will be considered an International student if I were to apply for a PHD at any university in Australia. This means that I will have to pay $22,000 per year as an International student. I am not in a financial situation to afford this. I have been told that scholarships for International students who already live and work in Australia, especially in the field of Environmental Philosophy, is hard to come by. This left me in a challenging situation at the end of 2013, having to decide between waiting two years for my VISA situation to change or undertake the research independently with institutional support from OASES Graduate School. I chose the latter as it is very clear to me that this research gives meaning to my life and purpose to my time. 
As mentioned earlier, I have come to a point where I need to go to Kerala to continue my research . This crowd-funding campaign is to raise funds for this field-trip. I have tried getting support through grants from institutions such as the Australia-India Council, but did not meet the eligibility criteria as I am not an Australian Permanent Resident and also because they expect research institutions to fund projects like this. As an immigrant, I also fall through the cracks of most grant-programs that are set up for this sort of research. Being an international student is not an option I can follow even if I decide to borrow money from the bank as Australian Banks do not give loans to immigrants who are not permanent residents. 
Having exhausted all my options I have turned to crowd funding. I do this with the courage that this work has given me and through the conviction that what I am doing is important not only for me, but also for the world. I hope that you are able to see this, that you are moved by my story so far, and that you are inspired to support me through the next leg of my journey.  I thank you from the bottom of my heart for reading my story and for your consideration to support this project.


Research Background
Since December 2013, as an honorary research fellow at OASES Graduate School, I have been undertaking research in the field of Eco-civilisation. What drew me to undertake this research was Freya Matthews’ work on philosophy of bio-mimicry[1] and theory of Eco-civilisation.
Freya Matthews (2013)[2] defines ‘Eco-Civilization’, as a ‘social formation, consistent with the repair and ongoing renewal of the biosphere.’  She also states that an inter-civilisational dialogue will be ‘key in the discovery of cultural and philosophical foundations for Eco-Civilisation in the west.’
Old civilisations of the world, whose philosophies of their engagement with the living Universe were developed far before industrialisation may still hold clues to principles of biomimetic engagement with the universe. These principles, when recovered, could be used to lay the foundational philosophy for an Eco-Civilisation. This requires an inter-civilisational dialogue - to remember and renovate old ideas in new forms that will contribute to a re-awakening of human civilisations through a re-engagement with the living Universe, each through their own unique narratives, yet, together in their goal of Eco-Civilisation.
I wanted to respond to Freya's call for an inter-civilisational dialogue by contributing to this idea of Eco-Civilisation using my background of Indian civilisation.
At the onset of my research, I wanted to look at Indian philosophy to tease out principles that might contribute to an Eco-Civilisation. But it soon became too large and too complex a task to undertake. ‘Indian Philosophy’ encompasses many different philosophies, and Hinduism is a constantly renewing process and can only be called a way of living that changes according to geographic locations, historical migrations and political interventions.
In order to find a grounding point in this revolving chaos that I found myself in, and with invaluable guidance form my supervisors, Freya Matthews and Jacque Boulet, I began to look in to my own ancestry. This was my way into a particular component of Indian philosophy, investigating what particular philosophy influenced my ancestors, what was their relationship with nature, and to see what principles, if any, could be applicable to an Eco-Civilisation in the modern context.
This has turned out to be the most challenging, meaningful and rewarding work that I have ever done. As I began to investigate my own community from Kerala I found out facts that not only astonished me, but also challenged what I knew about this world and who I knew myself to be in this world.

Cultural Background
I belong to a caste/community called ‘Nair’ from Kerala.  Kerala is bounded by the sea on one side and a mountain range called Western Ghats on the other. Growing up, I knew that my community used to be matrilineal and I understood this to mean that women of the family inherited land and had rights to property. I was never given any indication that it meant anything else. Nor did my immediate family structure or circumstances give any clues to a different past. 
I grew up in a conservative and patriarchal household, though modern in its outlook. My parents had accepted modernity with gusto to bring up two daughters, with conservatism liberally sprinkled in for ‘our protection’. We were allowed a long leash, and we experienced more freedom than most of our counterparts. We knew we were lucky to have parents who did not restrict us from doing what we wanted just because we were girls. We were taught values of love, kindness, generosity and family.
 I was brought up to understand that as a woman, my agency comes from being like a man and ‘making it’ in life.  I believed that education and a ‘good’ career will prove that I am equal. I also understood early on that as a girl, fear will be my constant companion along with shame. I learnt that I have to cover my body in-order to protect myself and that ‘good girls’ don’t have boy-friends. All through adolescence and early adulthood, I was ridden with guilt for being ‘bad’ in many different ways, from having boyfriends to asking too many questions. My life then was a constant struggle to hide my ‘bad-ness’ from my family and society in general. For years I went round and round in confused masochistic circles, trying to make sense of it all. 
It was a long and arduous journey for me to recognise the power within myself, as an individual and as a woman. I had blamed, for a large part, my cultural background for my feelings of powerless-less as a woman. My life in India was ridden with instances and stories of marital violence, abuse, rape and girl-child marriages. It seemed to me that if you were born in to that cultural context, you were doomed to a life of servitude, unless you fight tooth and nail to get out of it, somehow.

Research findings, so far
My Ancestors
Through my research during the last six months, I have learned that most of what I considered to be my cultural tradition is, in fact, only a few generations old, created by the influence of patriarchal Brahmanism, colonial law, and more recently, modernity through western development.
I have learned that my real cultural inheritance is not one of servitude, but one of incredible power. My research took me to a world of matriarchal clan living[3], where women made decisions not only about their own lives, but also for the whole clan. It took me to a world were women had lovers, not husbands[4]; where women, dressed the same as men and lived in an egalitarian clan structure in which men and women were equals[5]. I have learned that equality for women is not a modern concept. There were communities that practised equality in deeper ways than what we experience in our society today[6]; and that I belong to one such community.
I was shocked and felt betrayed by society. “Why didn’t anyone tell me??” In High School, we had two large history text books on the Second World War. I had to memorise who defeated whom in battles that ancient kings of India engaged in for no particular reason. Yet, all through school, university, and most of my life, I was ignorant about the history of my own people.  What shocked me most was the fact that a form of this matriarchal way of living was practised up until 1920s[7] - This was how my great-great grandmother lived.  It was challenging to reconcile with that fact that everything could be forgotten in just four generations; a period of time in which a whole community of women were displaced, from a position of power to that of servitude and shame.
As I investigated further, I began to uncover the depth of meaning of rituals and ceremonies that the Nair community still practise, remnants of more elaborate rituals from the past; most of which served to maintain the close relationship they had with the Earth. Nair clan houses always had a part of their property set aside as sacred groves. They also looked after temple elephants. I began to understand the relevance of stories and instances from my childhood with this perspective of ancient history and mythology.
Every clan house looked after ecologically significant sacred groves that housed many snakes. The oldest woman of the clan maintained a sacred relationship with the snakes and was the priestess of the sacred grove. Although I don’t remember a sacred grove in the house I grew up, I remember that snakes had a constant presence in my childhood, brushing against my feet as I played among the mango trees.  I remember distinctly being told that if I ever chance upon a mating ritual of snakes, I should not disturb them, nor should I stare. I was told that it was their sacred rite and I should respect their privacy.
A typical clan house had several sacred rooms, which housed the clan goddess (Bhagavati and/or Badrakali) as well as figures representing their ancestors[8]. Goddesses worship is still very strong in Kerala, with many goddess temples still preserving ecologically significant scared groves. The kindergarten I attended was inside a small Durga temple that had a sacred grove for the Snake gods. As we played hide-and-seek inside the sacred grove, presence of the fierce goddess felt comforting to my little heart that beat a little too fast with the fear of snakes. As my friend counted to ten with her eyes closed, I would always look up to the sky to spot the Eagle gods, cousins and rivals of Snake Gods, to say a small prayer for extra protection before venturing into the scared grove to hide.  
Nair men had a special relationship with temple elephants; folktales of this elephant-human friendship have been collected and published across Kerala. I remember my grandfather’s fondness for temple elephants, and was fortunate enough to have young temple elephants as playmates for many summers of my childhood. They would come for ten days every year, during the temple festival. We fed them giant rice balls filled with jaggery (palm sugar). I remember rough skin, soft pink tongue, beautiful long eye lashes; tenderness with which they picked me up, giant trunks wound around my small thin body.  
There are other communities in Kerala that used to practise matrifocal[9] kinship. These are mainly the Parayans and the Pulayans, who were subjugated by the warrior-like Nairs and later became slaves and untouchables in the caste hierarchy that was forced by patriarchal Brahmin invaders[10]. With great pain, I have to own up to the unimaginable violence that my ancestors had unleashed upon these communities; it included bonded labour, violence, rape and even beheadings for trivial matters such as crossing the path a Nair man was walking on. This serves as my grounding point in reminding me not to idealise the past. It also, more importantly, makes it crucial for me to investigate and document matrifocal kinship in these communities and their relationship to nature.
Western Ghats and Elephants
The geographical location of these communities, including that of my ancestors, is a dominant feature that cannot be ignored. Even today, the rainforests along the Western Ghats and the mountain range itself has a formidable presence in the life of people of Kerala, and to some extend in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Maharashtra where it spills over in to these states. It served as a protective barrier during different eras of colonisation and also helped preserve the unique cultural identity of the communities that lived here. Matrifocal elements have been recorded in communities all along the Western Ghats, with strong matrifocal regions in Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu[11]. Another interesting feature of this geographical location is the ecological significance of the place itself.  The Western Ghats, a UNESCO world heritage listed site, is one of the ‘eight ‘hottest hotspots’ of biological diversity in the world’[12]. The world’s single largest population of Asian Elephants live here. Encounters with wild Elephants are common occurrences in many parts of the Western Ghats; they are a part of everyday life that children going to school or women going to work have have to be wary of. 
Communities living here have co-existed with Elephants, wild and tame, for centuries. This relationship has become strained in recent times with shrinking forests, increasing human population and encroaching development.  Human-Elephant conflict in the Western Ghats is an issue that has resulted in many fatalities, both of Elephants and humans in the recent past[13].  This strong presence of Elephants in the lives of these communities is a fact that has special significance for my research when viewed from the perspective of matrifocal social organisation. Elephants live in matriarchal clans; matriarchal kin-ship amongst both Asian and African Elephants is well documented[14]. This has led me to look at matrifocal kinship amongst Asian elephants as a non-human version of this particular type of social organisation.  

Next Steps


As I spent more time on this research, I realised that it is now a very important part of my life.  Managing a couple of part time jobs and volunteering for few organisations has meant that it has taken a while - in fact six months - to reach where I am at the moment. I also do not have access to online journals or libraries other than the OASES libraries (which are great resources). This has meant that I have had to spend days in libraries, and lately most of my spare time, trying to find as much written material as available on this topic. As much as this has helped me to build theoretical groundwork, I find myself lacking in resources to continue this research. I have also found many references of relevant books and articles written in Malayalam. Apart from a few articles that I found online, most of these are currently out of my reach simply because they are not available to me here in Melbourne. I have realised that I have reached a stage where I need to go to Kerala to continue this work.
On a personal level, this work has had a deep impact on me and has consumed my mind, my thoughts and my dreams. It has become difficult to continue with my everyday life, as it feels disjointed from the thoughts that occupy my mind most of the time. Conversations with my mother about what she remembers, which is not much; passing on questions to great aunts who remember a lot; thinking of my great grand-mother, Lakshmi-Kutty Amma, my namesake; wondering about a sacred grove in our ancestral home that I have just come to know about; discussions with my sister about our grandmother, who seemed to have remembered in her body even if not in her conscious mind. Conversations with my great aunts have convinced me that I need to record their memories before it is too late. They represent my last link to a culture that is on the verge of disappearing forever. I have realised that I need to be physically present in the place to bring some calm to the storm that is in my mind and my heart. I need to touch the earth of my homeland, feel the weight of the humid air and drink the sweet water from the well in my ancestral home. I need to claim my ancestry. 
For these reasons, I have decided that the next step in my research journey is to visit Kerala.

story:
We want to fill a container van with 12, 16-foot yurts stacked in individual shipping crates, prepared for delivery when the next disaster--earthquake, fire, flood, hurricane--strikes in the Pacific Northwest. These yurts will be loaned for 18 months to each family in need, following FEMA disaster relief protocol. 

`We have the resources to distribute comfortable, beautiful yurt homes immediately following a disaster event, when people are at their most vulnerable. 

A 16-foot yurt provides 200 square feet of insulated living space. Each shipping crate unfolds to become the floor of the yurt. In addition to a beautiful handmade door with a half-light window, each yurt has an insulating liner; two opening windows with bug screen; and a four-foot-diameter skylight with a stove-exit safety bracket and a lever-action vent along with a wood stove and stove pipe.

   

LET'S BE READY 

FIRE/EARTHQUAKE/FLOOD/HURRICANE

LET'S BE READY 

A 16-foot yurt is a warm haven during a time of sudden loss, shock, repair and slow renewal.

WHO MAKES THEM?  A hard-working bunch of crazy-for-yurts craftsmen in Homer, Alaska.

Nomad Shelter, Inc. is a company based in Homer, Alaska that has been building yurts for over 20 years.

WHAT IS THE PLAN?   With the achievement of each funding goal ($18,000), we will build two yurts, then REPEAT, until we have filled our Emergency Preparedness Container Van with a stockpile of 12 yurts. 

Our first goal is to build and store yurts to accommodate 12 families ASAP for the Butte California Fire Disaster.  Our larger vision is to create a stockpile of container vans, ready for inevitable future disasters.

Each 16-foot yurt affords housing for four people. By the end of this campaign we will be poised to deliver free housing to 48 disaster victims for a total cost of $108,000. 

WHY DO THIS?  Because homelessness is unnecessary.


OKAY, SAY YOU HAVE YOUR CONTAINER VAN FILLED WITH YURTS, AND THERE IS AN EVENT THAT LEAVES HUNDREDS OR THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE HOMELESS. HOW WILL THE YURTS BE DISTRIBUTED?

Shipping fees are included in the estimate of the cost of each yurt. These fees will be kept in a secure savings account to be used for shipping expenses only. 

We will deliver the yurts to local disaster relief organizations managing distribution to families in need.

Twelve families will receive homes. Yurts provide a beautiful aesthetic, comfort, a sense of security--all important qualities, especially during crisis.

Having a stockpile of yurts to ship as needed during emergency events is not just a pipe dream. Natural disasters happen, and people lose their homes. Nomad Shelter/Alaskan Yurts has the skilled staff and extensively outfitted workshop to make our goal of transitional relief yurts a reality.

Nomad Shelter, Inc. is a company based in Homer, Alaska that has been building yurts for over 20 years. WHAT IS THE PLAN?   With the achievement of each funding goal ($18,000), we will build two yurts, then REPEAT, until we have filled our Emergency Preparedness Container Van with a stockpile of 12 yurts. Our first goal is to build and store yurts to accommodate 12 families ASAP for the Butte California Fire Disaster.  Our larger vision is to create a stockpile of container vans, ready for inevitable future disasters.Each 16-foot yurt affords housing for four people. By the end of this campaign we will be poised to deliver free housing to 48 disaster victims for a total cost of $108,000. WHY DO THIS?  Because homelessness is unnecessary.OKAY, SAY YOU HAVE YOUR CONTAINER VAN FILLED WITH YURTS, AND THERE IS AN EVENT THAT LEAVES HUNDREDS OR THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE HOMELESS. HOW WILL THE YURTS BE DISTRIBUTED?Shipping fees are included in the estimate of the cost of each yurt. These fees will be kept in a secure savings account to be used for shipping expenses only. We will deliver the yurts to local disaster relief organizations managing distribution to families in need.Twelve families will receive homes. Yurts provide a beautiful aesthetic, comfort, a sense of security--all important qualities, especially during crisis.Having a stockpile of yurts to ship as needed during emergency events is not just a pipe dream. Natural disasters happen, and people lose their homes. Nomad Shelter/Alaskan Yurts has the skilled staff and extensively outfitted workshop to make our goal of transitional relief yurts a reality.

story:
To those who will join us to make the dream a reality:

 

As I am preparing and arranging documents for potential donors for the Glendevey Ranch capital campaign I am reading some of what was written two years ago and I am surprised how much has been accomplished. Here, with this opening letter to the proposal package, I want to comment on that and on the current property we seek. And I want to ask you, after exploring the materials and websites we offer, to help us acquire that property now. For the good of all the children who will follow us in the future. If information is repeated in the various documents and media elements, I ask you to remember there is power in repetition.

 

So much growth has happened, which I will document below, we now need the first physical Sanctuary to manifest. As we have ‘felt’ the timing was right for what we have already accomplished, we now feel it is right for this. We have found an amazing property (http://www.sotem.org/prototype-land/) we wish to acquire - quickly. The sense of urgency is with us because several groups and individuals are currently putting together proposals. So time is short. How short, we do not know. But we do know that each step of the growth of SOTEM has happened as needed, even when the resources were not there until we asked. So, we are asking. The price is $1.5 million and the property and buildings seem to have been created for exactly our needs. With closing costs, state taxes, additional solar energy to add, and some repairs to cabins and other infrastructure, we are seeking $2.5 million in this capital campaign. That will allow us to acquire the land, add the elements still needed and create the campus to begin our programs in the spring of 2014. Look at the video in our package Sharon Bar Or has created and visit the web page above and you will see what an amazing bargain this property is. The current low prices in this market favor us.

 

Now I would like to speak to what has been accomplished in two short years and why we of the SOTEM circle know it is time for property to appear so we can serve so many more. Keep in mind all that has been accomplished has been done with very limited resources. We are not an organization coming to people with a good idea and promises of what could be done with funding. We are a growing circle coming to people with amazing accomplishments done with few resources, which demonstrate just how much could be done with ample resources. A huge difference in my view.

 

                  Two years ago three people sat and brainstormed Sanctuaries of the Earth Mother - Sue Graywolf Petruzzi, Jack Martin and myself. We became the board of directors and began creating documents to file as a non-profit. We had the name of the organization and the mission as it had come to me in a vision many years before. That and a dream. A dream to create Sanctuaries where people of all cultures and ages can come together and share as they teach the young. Not unique, but the mix of people and cultures and experiences we have globally is very, very rare. This coming together of such diverse people all interested in the vision tells me we are the ones to now do the work given us. There is a great deal more about the mission and the people on our website, www.SOTEM.org.

 

                  In a Creation Document I did at the time I spoke of creating virtual circles around the world and physical places as well. I spoke of publishing my first book with its’ teachings around nature and the sharing of the Sanctuary vision. I spoke of people around the world joining us. And I spoke of traveling and offering workshops and teachings. And finally, of building the physical Sanctuaries which will serve as training grounds for others, natural laboratories and teaching campuses.

 

                  Now I look at what has happened since. In 4 months we had permanent 501C3 status as an educational non-profit, thanks to the impression our mission made on the IRS people working with us. Having helped create many non-profits in the past, I had never experienced this. We received our approval letters from both the person assigned to us and the director of the non-profit arm of the IRS. Then we focused on the first book and created a small publishing business. Now this book is published and was an award finalist for an international book award. And my second book, Walking With the Earth Mother, is also published. Tools to teach from.

 

                  Our board of three is now a global board of 12, with members in England, Germany, Austria, Israel, the Navajo native lands and across the U.S. The three grandparents who began this now joined by men and women from age 24 to 82. People with amazing skills and talents in technology, natural resources, teaching, spiritual teachings and developing green environmentally focused centers.

 

                  We have grown from an organization with no media presence to one with an amazingly complete website, thousands of followers on Facebook and the other social media, and weekly radio shows around the globe - one in English, another in German and a third Celtic show. All of which, and much more, is accessible from the website, www.SOTEM.org.

 

                  For programs and workshops, Sue and I have travelled Great Britain and all across the U.S. over the past two years, creating interest and teaching as we went. And learning - always more than we teach - from all who join us in these circles. And more expansion seems to happen each day. As we add partners we continue to spread our mission everywhere. And so the virtual growth of Sanctuaries of the Earth Mother I spoke of two years ago is now advancing like a raging fire of growth. Other programs for the land we seek are being created now by those members on the board with experience in that realm - Karen Acerno, Sue Petruzzi, Jim Beard, Barbara Patterson and myself. I will happily share more about the board’s backgrounds with any who wish it. For now, there are brief board bios on the website.

 

                  Thank you for listening and looking and considering. And for giving to make this all real. This thank you is from all the people around the globe who are a part of the work now but, more importantly, it is a thank-you from all our grandchildren, born and not yet born, who watch us.

 

 

Jim Graywolf Petruzzi

President

One of the circle

story:
Our Story

Our story begins as four women, each one of us on our own zero-waste journey. We came together over our knowledge and passion about reducing waste and saw an opportunity to bring something new and exciting to Sudbury.  The concept of “zero-waste living” has been popping up in large Canadian cities such as Ottawa, Vancouver, Montreal, Toronto, and Halifax, and prevalent in European countries. There are so many waste reduction initiatives happening across the city; it is apparent to us that Sudburians are part of the zero-waste movement.

The Nickel Refillery initiative was created in response to the growing demand for a more convenient location when it comes to a sustainable marketplace offering zero-waste products, as well as to foster opportunities to collaborate with others on their journey, no matter green or seasoned.

 

Consumption to Sustainability

Recycling has been labeled the most successful environmental initiative in human history. However, the exponential production of recyclable packaging products has overwhelmed the infrastructure and has created systemic barriers impacting the success of this initiative. 

To adopt the principles of zero-waste living, we need to first discard the idea of waste. Everything is created from a resource, and waste is merely a resource going in the wrong direction. By changing the way resources are thought of, and thereby how they flow through our society and communities, we can reap substantial environmental, economic, and social benefits. This change in thinking is, in effect, the essential framework for a sustainable development model for the community. We save energy, water, resources, and greenspace by shifting our focus from consumption to sustainability. We reduce pollution of air, land, and water by using recycled materials. We create a host of new job opportunities that can benefit those in our society who face some of the greatest barriers to employment. Best of all, these positions can be generated in places like Sudbury, where livelihoods are created instead of landfills. 

 

The Store

The Nickel Refillery (opening late summer of 2019) is a retail shop that will offer customers everyday zero-waste supplies and products that are free of plastic packaging. Our shop will offer only unpackaged or sustainably packaged items, and a variety of bulk products, many of them on tap. Here are some of the products you will find in the store: 

  • personal care and hygiene items for the entire family (hair and body care, mouth care, deodorant, shaving supplies)
  • home cleaning supplies (laundry supplies, dish soap, diswasher tabs, handsoap, multisurface cleaner)
  • ingredients for DIY projects (salts, baking soda, clay)
  • sustainable kitchen goods (wax wraps, metal and glass containers, brushes)
  • products made by local artisans (home and personal care)

Over the past few months, we have sourced a variety of products with a focus on those that are local or Canadian, organic, non-toxic, preservative-free, and cruelty-free, all in bulk and without disposable packaging.  

The Nickel Refillery will also function as a community space for zero-waste workshops with diverse topics, such as clothing and toy swaps, DIY products, composting, waste-free lunches for kids, innovative ways to reuse packaging… the opportunities are endless!

As a local social enterprise, The Nickel Refillery will give back to Sudburians for their continued support. We will work with other community waste reduction groups to assist with their waste reduction initiatives across the city.

 

What We Need

We are looking for at least $15,000 CAD to help with some of the start-up expenses. The selected location required refitting and repairs, with electrical, plumbing, and general restorations. After the renovations are complete, the equipment comes in. We need dispensary equipment, hoppers, commercial dishwasher, and extensive shelving, to name a few.

 

What You Get

Part of adopting a waste free lifestyle is to change the way we shop. Your support will make a huge impact on helping us support you and your community in waste reduction.

As an incentive, we have put together a few zero-waste gifts of some of the items you will find at The Nickel Refillery, and we will also be creating a special sponsor wall. The gifts will be available on our opening day, so stay tuned for that announcement. Supporters who do not live in Sudbury will receive their gifts by mail.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are so grateful for every contribution to our campaign.  Even if you are unable to back this project at this time, it would mean the world to us (and the planet) if you would share this campaign with your friends and family on social media, through email, and talk about it over dinner with friends or coffee at work. No matter how big or small the support, it will all make a difference.

story:
My Challenge:
I have a donation challenge for Dogs for Conservation because we need to buy some GIS/GPS mapping equipment for the fieldwork we will be starting soon. I'd like to challenge you to take 5 minutes and donate ANY amount you are able to to help us reach this goal... and this equipment will last us many, many years while we assist in very real environment issues...

Many people know how dogs can be used to sniff out or detect such things as drugs, bombs, agricultural products at ports of entry, human remains and live people. You may have even heard more recently that dogs are being used to detect cancer!!

It is obvious that dogs have an incredible sense of smell, but what may not be so obvious is all the applications where this talent can be used. This organization’s primary goal is to train and provide dogs to assist people working in the fields of Wildlife Conservation, Rangeland Science and Habitat Management. Scientists, Students and Managers often require lengthy surveys to detect the presence, or lack there-of, of certain species. It may be a highly endangered and rare species of plant or animal. It may be an invasive or exotic species of plant or animal that is threatening native species. It may be a diseased plant or animal that needs to be confined before an outbreak occurs.

These surveys are not only limited to landmasses. Search and Rescue dogs are routinely trained to search water bodies from boats for human remains. Dogs have been trained to detect whale feces in the OCEAN working from boats. Feces, otherwise known as “poop” is a useful tool for scientists because a sample, once sent to a laboratory, can tell them many things including hormone levels, stress levels, disease, gender and more. There has been enough work and scientific publications using dogs in these fields to prove that it does work and the dogs are highly accurate and reduce man hours significantly.


Dogs for Conservation is in need of some specialized equipment that will help map out our surveys and follow the dogs' as they search out their target. We would like to purchase this GIS/GPS equipment soon so we can have it ready for our first projects which will be starting soon!!

The retail price of a handheld GPS (Trimble Juno SB) that runs ESRI ArcPad along with all of the needed accessories is approximately $1825.

The  primary desktop GIS software that we need is ESRI ArcGIS Desktop Basic, which retails for $1500.

Finally, we need a Garmin ASTRO dog tracking system which is about $600.

Please read more about our VERY unique organization at www.dogsforconservation.org and feel free to contact us with any questions you may have!!

story:
Hey Folks . . . 

  • For the past seven years, I have been perfecting proprietary methods of growing and propagating perennial native wildflowers. With an inventory of well over ten thousand plants, I am ready to open a large Pollinator Park. To learn more about me, my background, experiences, and related accomplishments, click here.
  • I am launching this campaign to help me close on a beautiful 56 acres of land, and will immediately begin planting my flowers . . . which will all bloom this year. Along with paid admissions, each spring we will have to harvest up to 100,000 new plant shoots, in order to maintain proper spacing. These will be sold or used to create additional Pollinator Habitat across the southeast.
  • I will plant, open, maintain, manage, and fully develop the park over the next five years. After five years I will give the Pollinator Park to a deserving organization, institution, or other entity. Every dollar invested in the park now, will equal one vote to determine who the park will be donated to in five years.  If the recipient of the park does not want to take over ownership, they can sell it, or defer to the second place winner.
  • A highly successful campaign will allow me to purchase the land, plant my flowers, and next spring plant up to 15 acres of pick-your-own berries. Plus . . . we will also be building working models of everything that can be powered by the heat of the sun, including space heating, water heating, cooking, drying, and much more. Plus . . . we will be planting native trees, shrubs, and vines. Did I mention total rain water harvesting with bio-sand filtration and solar sterilization?
  • Web site home page:  www.poln8rsplus.org

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are under contract for a 56 acre tract.  I would like to raise $300,000 so that the land will be paid off in full, and we will have enough in reserve to purchase equipment needed, purchase berry plants for next spring, and cover all operating expenses for one year.
  • We are offering discounted admission passes, specially priced vehicle passes, and an opportunity to cover the costs of school field trips. 
  • We will donate the Pollinator Park including all of the plants, all of the revenue streams, and all of the features that have been built to the non profit entity that receives the most votes through this opening fundraising campaign.

The Impact

  • By investing in this project, you will be helping raise awareness about the crucial role Pollinators play in our world, raise awareness about the devastation that invasive plants can have on eco-systems, and help thousands develop a deep love and appreciation for the natural world.
  • Many people will learn how to mow less grass, and plant for wildlife.
  • Many people will learn how they can easily supplement their heating, water heating, cooking,  and cooling expenses with solar powered apparatuses.

Risks & Challenges

I am passionate and driven, radically resourceful, creative and innovative and am more than ready to take this on. Along with my own personal inventory of perennial native wildflowers, I am always collecting more, and will be able to fill this park by 2022. On the solar heat and sustainability portion, I have been studying and experimenting with solar heat since the mid 1980's.  Although the first staff position I hire for the park will be someone to help plant, the second position will be someone to begin building the many solar heat utilizing devices we will have on display in the park.

Other Ways You Can Help

For every dollar invested in this project, a vote can be cast to decide who the Pollinator Park will be donated to in five years.  By sharing this campaign within a specific network, you can increase the odds that the organization you would like to see tale over the park will finish first in the voting. In other words, purchase deeply discounted passes to vote, and share the campaign so that others can purchase deeply discounted passes and vote.

We will donate the Pollinator Park including all of the plants, all of the revenue streams, and all of the features that have been built to the non profit entity that receives the most votes through this opening fundraising campaign.


The Impact

By investing in this project, you will be helping raise awareness about the crucial role Pollinators play in our world, raise awareness about the devastation that invasive plants can have on eco-systems, and help thousands develop a deep love and appreciation for the natural world.
Many people will learn how to mow less grass, and plant for wildlife.
Many people will learn how they can easily supplement their heating, water heating, cooking,  and cooling expenses with solar powered apparatuses.


Risks & Challenges
I am passionate and driven, radically resourceful, creative and innovative and am more than ready to take this on. Along with my own personal inventory of perennial native wildflowers, I am always collecting more, and will be able to fill this park by 2022. On the solar heat and sustainability portion, I have been studying and experimenting with solar heat since the mid 1980's.  Although the first staff position I hire for the park will be someone to help plant, the second position will be someone to begin building the many solar heat utilizing devices we will have on display in the park.

Other Ways You Can Help
For every dollar invested in this project, a vote can be cast to decide who the Pollinator Park will be donated to in five years.  By sharing this campaign within a specific network, you can increase the odds that the organization you would like to see tale over the park will finish first in the voting. In other words, purchase deeply discounted passes to vote, and share the campaign so that others can purchase deeply discounted passes and vote.

story:
About Us

The Indo CorALliance is an environmental and social initiative based on the island of Nusa Penida, Indonesia. It was formed in response of the effects of COVID-19 policy on a tourism dependent island. The outbreak of the corona virus and the extreme but necessary measures taken around the world has hit the tourism industry hard. Although the break comes as welcome news to conservationists and our marine friends, millions of people have lost their livelihoods overnight.

Nusa Penida is a small island located 20 minutes south of the popular tourist destination, Bali. 80% of Bali’s economy relies on tourism and this loss of income has severely effected the local community. With the future of tourism so uncertain we have developed a new program to help both the coral reefs and coastal communities.

Coral reefs are a vital ecosystem to support both marine and terrestrial inhabitants by providing food, shelter, and a nursery ground. Economically, coral reefs have a key roll to support the livelihoods of coastal communities through fisheries and tourism. One of the leading causes to coral damage is high human activity and improper handling. Corona Virus has given our coral reefs the much-needed break they deserve and a chance to regrow in the absence of human activity. 

Since early 2019 Indo Ocean Project’s lead marine biologist, Pascal Sebastian MSc, has implemented and managed a coral restoration project in Nusa Penida, Bali. He recently completed his Coral Propagation Instructor course and has developed a unique community project during these uncertain times.

 

There are 3 aims of this project:

  • To educate the community with a focus on local tourism operators in coral conservation and propagation methods. Sustainable and responsible tourism is the only way forward and we will use this break to empower local tourism industry workers to manage and monitor their own coral nursery. We will host multiple workshops to apply to their business practices when tourism returns to the island. We will train the local community in coral propagation methods under the supervision of a coral expert. 
  • To create jobs for those who are unemployed due to COVID-19 policy. We have started by hiring 3 Indonesian dive professionals for the title of “Coral Ranger” and 3 "Research Assistants” nominated from the coral nurseries corresponding villages. We offer complete training and certification in coral propagation and empower these individuals to care for their nurseries and communities livelihoods through citizen science and coral gardening.
  • To help our coral reefs thrive! Research approaches that can incorporate the social-ecological dynamics of reefs are increasingly seen as essential for understanding the future of our coral reefs (Williams et al., 2019). Research shows us that coral reef fisheries in some tropical Indo-Pacific countries will be unable to meet local demands long term due to climate change, but a more immediate concern is increased human activity. (Bell et al., 2013). We need to seize this opportunity of the absence of tourism on an otherwise high traffic island and regrow damaged areas of our fringing reef during these optimal growth conditions. Using a methodology tried and tested around the world we will restore damaged sections of reef along the northern coast of Nusa Penida with an eco friendly methodology. Over the next 6 months our CorAliance team will develop and monitor their nurseries noting growth rate, coral disease, mortality, and the effect on the surrounding ecosystem. 

 

But we need your help!

 

To purchase the items required and to help our local community we ask for donations to run this program successfully. 

What your donations means to us:

$1/10,000 IDR– data sheet printing or office supplies

$5/50,000 IDR – Buckets or measuring calliper

$10/100,000 IDR – 1 month supplies of coral catalyst

$50/500,000 IDR – Months supplies of materials for up to 3 nurseries

$100/1,000,000 IDR – Contribute to the livelihoods of our Indonesian coral team

$200/2,000,000 IDR – Launch of a new nursery site and involve more local workers

 

Monthly Subscriptions (6 months):

$50/500,000 IDR/month – support 1/4 of nursery costs (honorary coral ambassador and receive a handmade coconut coral jewelry from a local artist)

$100/1,000,000 IDR/month – support 1/2 a nursery costs (honorary coral ambassador and sent an Indo Ocean Project reusable water bottle)

$200/2,000,000 IDR/month – sponsor 1 full nursery costs (honorary coral ambassador, name your nursery, regular nursery updates, and sent an Indo Ocean Project Research Team T-shirt)

For all monthly subscribers:

  • To organize please contact info@indooceanproject.org
  • Special mention on website as leading supporter
  • Monthly Corporate sponsorship will have logo displayed on website partner page and certificate of sponsorship.

 

Terima kasih banyak for your contributions and support! 

 

“Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It’s not.”

 – The Lorax, Dr Sues

 

CLICK HERE FOR MORE INFORMATION ON THIS CAMPAIGN   

 

-------------------------------

 

Tentang Kami

Indo CorAlliance adalah sebuah program untuk lingkungan dan sosial yang dilakukan di pulau Nusa Penida, Bali. Program ini dibentuk dalam respon terhadap pembatasan kegiatan masyarakat dikarenakan pandemi COVID-19 yang mengakibatkan tutupnya usaha-usaha seperti perhotelan dan wisata bahari. Banyak dari para pekerja yang kehilangan pekerjaan dan penghasilan pada masa sulit ini.

Nusa Penida adalah sebuah pulau kecil yang berjarak sekitar 20 menit ke arah tenggara dari Pulau Bali. Pulau ini sangat terkenal oleh keindahan alamnya, terurama keindahan bawah laut seperti terumbu karang dan ikan-ikan karang. Terumbu karang adalah ekosistem yang sangat penting untuk menunjang kehidupan di laut dengan menyediakan makanan dan juga tempat tinggal untuk makhluk-mahkluk laut. Secara ekonomi, terumbu karang juga berperan penting untuk menunjang kehidupan masyarakat pesisir melalui sektor perikanan dan juga pariwisata bahari.

Salah satu dari penyebab kerusakan ekosistem terumbu karang adalah praktek pariwisata yang tidak bertanggung jawab dan tidak berkelanjutan. Dengan behentinya semua kegiatan pariwisata, inilah saat yang baik untuk ekosistem terumbu karang untuk bertumbuh kembali.

Sejak 2019, Lembaga Swadaya Masyarakat Indo Ocean Project bersama ahli biologi laut, Pascal Sebastian, telah mengimplementasikan aktifitas restorasi terumbu karang di Nusa Penida. Pascal telah merancang sebuah program yang memberi manfaat bagi komunitas lokal dan juga ekosistem terumbu karang di masa yang tidak menentu ini.


Tiga tujuan utama dari program ini:

  • ﻿﻿Mengedukasi ﻿komunitas lokal, khususnya bagi para pelaku pariwisata mengenai konservasi terumbu karang dan metode pengembangbiakannya. Pengelolaan yang berkelanjutan dan bertanggung jawab adalah filosofi yang akan dibagikan dalam bentuk seminar dan workshop. Mereka akan diberikan tanggung jawab untuk mengelola sebuah wilayah untuk perkembangbiakan terumbu karang (nursery), didampingi oleh ahli terumbu karang. Pada akhirnya, ilmu yang mereka dapat akan menjadi bekal untuk mengedukasi masyarakat sekitar dan juga turis-turis yang akan datang setelah pandemi berakhir.
  • ﻿﻿Menciptakan lapangan perkerjaan﻿ bagi para pelaku pariwisata yang kehilangan pekerjaan dan penghasilang karena COVID-19. Kami memulai dengan tiga orang dari komunitas lokal dengan latar belakang pemandu selam dan tiga ﻿asisten dari area desa sesuai dengan lokasi pengembangbiakan. Kami akan membekali dengan sertifikasi pengembangbiakan koral﻿, pelatihan untuk mengelola ﻿nursery﻿-nya masing-masing﻿ dan berperan aktif dalam ﻿mengedukasi tentang pentingnya ekosistem terumbu karang untuk penghidupan masyarakat sekitar.
  • ﻿Membantu pertumbuhan terumbu karang Nusa Penida. ﻿Program penelitian yang ﻿melibatkan aspek sosial-ekologi terumbu karang menjadi hal yang sangat penting untuk mempelajari masa depan dari terumbu karang (Williams ﻿et al﻿., 2019). Sebuah penelitian juga menunjukan bahwa kegiatan perikanan di sekitar terumbu karang di wilayah negara tropis Indo-Pasifik tidak akan bertahan lama dikarenakan oleh perubahan iklim, namun kerusakan ini dipercepat oleh adanya penambahan tekanan dari aktifitas manusia (Bell ﻿et al.,﻿ 2013). Kita harus memanfaatkan momen ini, dimana aktifitas manusia sangat minimal sehingga kualitas lingkungan menjadi sangat optimal untuk terumbu karang berkembangbiak. Menggunakan metode yang telah diuji dan berhasil di lapangan, kami akan merestorasi wilayah-wilayah terumbu karang yang rusak di bagian pesisir pantai utara Nusa Penida dengan menggunakan metode yang 100% ramah lingkungan. Dalam waktu 6 bulan, tim CorAlliance akan terus mengembangkan dan memelihara ﻿nursery﻿, mengambil data pertumbuhan dan mengamati gangguan yang mungkin ada.

﻿
﻿﻿Kami membutuhkan dukungan anda.
﻿Untuk membeli peralatan, biaya operasional dan menolong penghidupan dari komunitas lokal, kami membutuhkan donasi anda untuk memastikan keberlangsungan program ini.
﻿

﻿Donasi anda sangat berarti bagi kami:

Sekecil apapun donasi yang anda berikan dapat membantu kami untuk:﻿﻿﻿

﻿Rp. 10.000 - ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿pencetakan lembar data dan peralatan tulis
﻿Rp. 50.000 - Wadah pemindah terumbu karang atau alat ukur pertumbuhan
﻿Rp. 100.000 - Suplai 1 bulan untuk katalis koral
﻿Rp. 500.000 - Suplai 1-2 bulan untuk mengelola ﻿nursery﻿ ﻿﻿tiga lokasi yang berbeda
﻿Rp. 1.000.000 - Kontribusi untuk sumber penghasilan dari anggota kami
﻿Rp 2.000.000 - Pengembangan ﻿lokasi ﻿nursery ﻿baru dan lebih banyak komunitas lokal yang dapat kami libatkan

Bagi donatur yang berkontribusi rutin setiap bulan:
﻿﻿Kami akan mencantumkan dukungan anda di website kami
﻿Apabila donasi diatasnamakan oleh sebuah perusahaan, logo perusahaan akan kami tampilkan di website kami.
Email info@indooceanproject.org untuk melakukan donasi rutin.

Terima kasih atas kontribusi dan dukungan anda.

"﻿Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not"

﻿- ﻿The Lorax, Dr. Seus

story:
Summary

Endangered baleen whales -- including the fin whale, second largest animal on earth -- have begun reinvading the temperate fjords of British Columbia's north coast, where they forage intensively and socialize, just as a suite of oil and natural gas tanker routes have been proposed for the area. We must rush to document this unprecedented concentration of inland whales before any impacts from maritime development can take effect. 

As a PhD student at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, I have devoted my dissertation to learning more about the whales of the Great Bear before that opportunity is lost. In summer 2013, I conducted four months of visual, acoustic, and oceanographic surveys within a broad transect of the northern fjords aboard my 12m research sloop, the SV Bangarang. I now have a proof of concept for this project, a fine-tuned survey design, preliminary data, and some remarkable stories. I now need the means of getting back out there for Season Two. 

Impact

Academic: This is a project in pure discovery. Many aspects of this remote fjordland's ecosystem are poorly studied, and BC is the only place fin whales have been studied in a fjord setting.  As baleen whale populations continue to recover from 20th century whaling, how and to what extent will they come to rely on this habitat? Conversely, what is the potential importance of these whales to the ecological function of BC's north coast?

Applied: My research will provide a baseline for the pre-tanker ecology of their habitat, as well as a basis for mitigating possible impacts. These remarkable inland whale populations are facing developments that would impact economies -- both human and natural -- across North America. This remote sanctuary is now of public concern, and to study them I am looking for public support. 

Personal: It may be a rare thing that a PhD project is also a dream come true. I am unbelievably fortunate that I have found such a project, and I'm on fire about it. I can’t wait to get back out there. 

Needs

I've designed my project to be high-impact at low-cost. For a full season (4 months) of PhD-level ecosystem research on the SV Bangarang, my budget is less than that of operating a Scripps research vessel for half a day. Unfortunately, as a PhD student operating my own research vessel, my project falls between the cracks of small student grants and large post-doctoral grants. 

Barebones Needs: $10,000

For Season Two to happen at all, this minimum would cover the cost of fuel, food for three crew, and a few essential pieces of equipment.

High-Value Improvements: An additional $20,000.

In addition to these necessities, there are some small investments that would substantially improve the quality, consistency, and impact of the data I collect. These include:

  • Engine replace/rebuild: In 2013, we lost several weeks of critical research days to repairing the SV Bangarang's 33-year old 45 hp diesel. Improving the reliability of our vessel is the single-most effective change I could make for 2014. 
  • Travel assistance for crew: The crew of the Bangarang are some of the most dedicated, enthusiastic, and hard-working researchers I know, and they fight for this project without pay or compensation. As a meager thanks, I want to cover their travel expenses to and from the remote study site in 2014.
  • Equipment Improvements: Specific items that will allow us to sample farther, deeper, longer, and more precisely than in season one. These include: A motorized line hauler to increase the number of zooplankton tows we can take;  back-up underwater microphones so that we don't become paralyzed by equipment breakdown; a raised sighting platform for visual surveys; a net and imaging system that allows us to sample for phytoplankton. 

Overhead: An additional $5,000 to cover Indiegogo fees, third-party payment service charges, and UCSD overhead costs. No support will go towards salaries, wages, or non-business-related expenses.

Regardless of whether I reach my fundraising mark, all support I receive will go a long, long way in making Season Two happen. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and stay informed. Word of mouth, email, fb, twitter, Indiegogo's share tools, improvised songs, sky-writing, human statues, whatever!

All photographs are by crew of the SV Bangarang, with the exception of the "Summary" photo (vessel with the two fin whales) by Janie Wray, North Coast Cetacean Society.

I can’t wait to get back out there. NeedsI've designed my project to be high-impact at low-cost. For a full season (4 months) of PhD-level ecosystem research on the SV Bangarang, my budget is less than that of operating a Scripps research vessel for half a day. Unfortunately, as a PhD student operating my own research vessel, my project falls between the cracks of small student grants and large post-doctoral grants. 
Barebones Needs: $10,000For Season Two to happen at all, this minimum would cover the cost of fuel, food for three crew, and a few essential pieces of equipment.
High-Value Improvements: An additional $20,000.In addition to these necessities, there are some small investments that would substantially improve the quality, consistency, and impact of the data I collect. These include:

Engine replace/rebuild: In 2013, we lost several weeks of critical research days to repairing the SV Bangarang's 33-year old 45 hp diesel. Improving the reliability of our vessel is the single-most effective change I could make for 2014. 

Travel assistance for crew: The crew of the Bangarang are some of the most dedicated, enthusiastic, and hard-working researchers I know, and they fight for this project without pay or compensation. As a meager thanks, I want to cover their travel expenses to and from the remote study site in 2014.

Equipment Improvements: Specific items that will allow us to sample farther, deeper, longer, and more precisely than in season one. These include: A motorized line hauler to increase the number of zooplankton tows we can take;  back-up underwater microphones so that we don't become paralyzed by equipment breakdown; a raised sighting platform for visual surveys; a net and imaging system that allows us to sample for phytoplankton. 
Overhead: An additional $5,000 to cover Indiegogo fees, third-party payment service charges, and UCSD overhead costs. No support will go towards salaries, wages, or non-business-related expenses.Regardless of whether I reach my fundraising mark, all support I receive will go a long, long way in making Season Two happen. Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word and stay informed. Word of mouth, email, fb, twitter, Indiegogo's share tools, improvised songs, sky-writing, human statues, whatever!All photographs are by crew of the SV Bangarang, with the exception of the "Summary" photo (vessel with the two fin whales) by Janie Wray, North Coast Cetacean Society.

story:
The 501Carbon Story

501Carbon is a not-for-profit climate services firm started by 3 graduate students at Duke University who were tired of hearing about the overwhelming problems related to global energy  poverty and the impacts of climate change, and decided to do something.


The Durham based start-up utilizes partnerships with project developers, investors, and Corporate Social Responsibility officers from various companies to provide a network of stakeholders that work together to finance and build small-scale renewable energy projects in the communities that are most affected by energy poverty and the initial impacts of climate change.


501Carbon is asking for funding to help develop a new marketing approach that will generate project finance by incorporating retail companies and the average US consumer. We call it The Climate Golden Rule: basically, as a consumer, you get tangible rewards for helping us address climate change and energy poverty. 


Our campaign, if successful, will allow us to create both a digital and physical pilot for the Climate Card, which when purchased will provide a significant amount of investment in renewable energy in a least developed country; we currently have projects in both rural Uganda and China (seen in the video above). Membership in The Climate Golden Rule and possession of a Climate Card will then get you discounts on the things you spend your money on most, such as organic groceries, monthly smartphone bills, and even airline flights and electricity!


501Carbon wants to not only motivate the average US consumer to consider how their purchases can contribute to climate change, but also provide incentives for thoughtful consumerism and support of renewable energy.


Funding and Perks

Our funding goal was developed in order to provide the most benefit to our rural community stakeholders, while generating enough capital to get our pilot for The Climate Golden Rule off the ground. As a registered not-for-profit we maintain at least a 4:1 ratio of money going to building and financing projects that help people with no access to reliable energy compared to our administrative costs. That means out of our $25,000 goal, we will be spending $20,000 on expanding on our current projects in Uganda and China, and only $5,000 on the Climate Golden Rule pilot!


This is all absent the costs of the great perks available to our supporters. We have painstakingly sourced the best possible items that will help you demonstrate your commitment to the environment, by demonstrating your commitment to us!


The 501Carbon Impact

Created with our engineering and development partners, our projects currently operating in rural Uganda and China have delivered over 140,000 cookstoves and 400,000 small scale biogas digesters to those in need. These incredible efforts have already reduced global CO2 emissions by 705,000 tons to date. For reference, these emissions are equivalent to taking 70% of all the taxi-cabs operating in the entire United States off the road for a year!


Next Steps

With your help we can grow our current projects, and create a new marketing platform that will enable us to create new projects. Please consider supporting our efforts to create new ways to address global problems. Visit us on Facebook, Twitter, and our website www.501Carbon.org.


Thank you,


The 501Carbon Team


P.S. If you or your friends are interested in supporting our efforts via tax deductible charitable donations, please consider making payments through the online marketplace at our website. Most of the perks are similar, and there are payment plans and options for offsetting activities not included here.

story:
We are the Pagan Environmental Coalition of New York. We represent many different traditions and practices, but we all want the same thing. We want sustainable and green energy that does not deplete the Earth. We want to bring people from all over the country and from other nations to a very important UN Climate Summit in September 2014. We want our presence known and our voices heard. If you can't be there to march the People's Climate March on September 21, 2014, consider donating to support a marcher! 

Your contribution will help us provide clean water, lunch and protein snacks for marchers on the day of the Climate March, September 21, 2014. We will also use some of the funds raised to purchase supplies to make signs for march, as well as incidentals such as bandages and sunscreen. 
Most importantly, we want to contribute money to individuals who wish to be at the march in person but live far away. Presence is the most important part of this weekend of Climate Summit events. We want as many people marching with us as possible! Your contribution puts bodies in the crowd, which is what the UN needs to see!
We have some pretty fantastic perks, too! Oh yes, we do! 

If you can't help, spread the word, and fast! The Climate March is fast upon us, and we want to purchase bus/train tickets for volunteers and marchers!

story:
Save Port Westward Family Farms and Wildlife Habitat!

Help us protect working family farms, the Columbia River, and our environment by contributing today to help us stop the rezone of Port Westward.

Hi! My name is Tracy Prescott-MacGregor. My husband and I are self sufficient farmers in a beautiful corner of the world on the Columbia River in Clatskanie, Oregon. We are surrounded by other beautiful farms growing blueberries, cottonwood trees, mint and raising cattle. This area has some of the finest soils in North America laid down by thousands of years of periodic flooding. Near my home, 837 acres of working farmland owned by the Port of St Helens, on Port Westward, have recently been rezoned from Prime Agricultural to Rural Industrial. The Port of St. Helens has plans to double the size of their existing Industrial terminal.

Several months ago, the Port of St. Helens began using a defunct Ethanol plant at Port Westward to ship crude oil from the Bakken Shale in North Dakota. From Port Westward it is pumped into barges and shipped down the Columbia River to refineries in Washington and California.  The Port purchased the surrounding agricultural land adjacent to it's existing terminal. In order to expand, they needed to rezone the land from Prime Agricultural to Rural Industrial. Our Columbia County Planning Commission voted 5-1 against this rezone in support of the farms and wildlife.  A few months later the Columbia County Commissioners voted unanimously to rezone this farmland in favor of Industry. 

At risk are several hundred acres of farmland currently being used to grow food. This land will be industrialized in order to build the expanded rail loop and oil terminal. In light of the many recent horrific accidents involving the caustic Bakken crude shipped by rail in poorly designed tank cars this is obviously a hazardous procedure. We risk toxic spills and explosive fire anywhere along the rail lines used to deliver this oil thus endangering communities from North Dakota to the refineries. A local disaster in Port Westward will not only devastate our farmland, but because of the interconnected tidal nature of the dike lands will result in a widespread ecological catastrophe.

Additionally, the rezoning encompasses about two miles of wildlife habitat along the Columbia River shore where expanded docks are planned. This development threatens salmon, eagle, heron and kingfisher populations to name only a few. 

Many folks use this area for fishing, hunting and recreation like boating, swimming and birding. We need to preserve the beauty and the bounty of what's here. There are not many more places along the Columbia that can boast this peaceful coexistence between man and wildlife. We want this to be here for our grand kids...for YOUR grand kids.

Help us protect this land by contributing today.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $2,000 to help with legal costs appealing the rezone of Port Westward.
  • We believe in providing perks that are handmade or experience oriented. We feel that there is too much corporate "stuff" out there already so for you who donate we are providing things that have been made in the Pacific Northwest. For a $10 donation we have Native hand made cedar woven roses. For a $25 donation we have peppermint patties made right here at the Seely mint farm next to Port Westward. For a $50 donation we have native American hand woven salt and pepper shaker holders (shakers included). For a $500 donation we have a night at the Sylvia Beach Hotel for book lovers in Newport, Oregon. and finally we will give the first person who donates $1,000 our hand built adjustable thermometer prop. 
  • These funds will go to the non-profit group Columbia Riverkeeper which is committed to helping our community appeal the rezoning. Learn more about Columbia Riverkeeper at www.ColumbiaRiverkeeper.org.

The Impact

Your contribution will make it possible for us to file an appeal to reverse the rezoning. Help us protect our precious farm land and river habitat that we ALL benefit from!

  • So much of our prime agricultural land is gone. The world is quickly losing it's ability to feed us. We need to protect our food producing land now.
  • Columbia Riverkeeper has a track record of success in preventing river and land from becoming terminals at other sites, including stopping a Liquefied Natural Gas terminal at Bradwood Landing.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't give money spread the word through social media. Use Facebook, twitter, you name it! Help us stop more dangerous crude from coming onto our lands and waterways.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! It all works to help us make a difference!

Thank you!

Use the Indiegogo share tools! It all works to help us make a difference!
Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

I am a repeat visitor to Cambodia's Virachey National Park. My friends and I started a new conservation group caplled Habitat ID, and our plan is to go into national parks and protected areas in Southeast Asia and set up motion-triggered camera-traps to produce evidence of the preseence of endangered species such as tigers, elephants, and clouded leopards -species which have been written off as locally extinct by the big NGOs. Our first project is Virachey. 

  • I have a PhD in Bio-regionalism from Tamkang University, Taipei, Taiwan, and I did my doctoral field work in and around Virachey National Park.
  • I believe that tigers and even "extinct" species such as the kouprey and the Javan rhinoceros can still be found in Virachey NP. 
  • If we can produce photographic evidence of tigers and elephants, or kouprey or rhinoceros, I am confident that we can get the big NGOs to come back to Virachey and invest in long-term protection programs.
  • I want to make it clear that we will not publicize wildlife photos on the Internet or in the news. We will share them Cambodia's Ministry of Environment, Virachey Park Staff, selected NGOs, and donors only. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need more camera-traps. This is the model that we need, and we need as many more as possible. We plan to leave these cameras in the park for one year. 
  • We also need to purchase protective metal casings, steel cables, memory cards, and batteries for this expedition. If anyone would prefer to purchase the equipment and mail it to an expedition member, please contact me via email and I can provide instructions: greg@habitatid.org
  • We also need funding to pay for expedition expenses such as guide and porter fees, national park fees, provisions, and a return trip in late March to check the cameras (we will be able to obtain some early results!)

The Impact

You can find out more about my involvement in Virachey by having a look at the following webpages:

  • "Exploring Asia's Lost World" -my interview with Mongabay.com
  • "Into the Unknown Mountains of Cambodia" -birder Howie Nielsen's trip report on our trek earlier this year to the remote Yak Yeuk Grasslands in Virachey. 
  • Called Away by a Mountain Spirit -my book about my travels in Virachey and Northeastern Cambodia. The Taipei Times wrote a review of the book, which you can read here. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Visit Virachey NP and contribute to sustainable ecotourism there
  • Visit us on Facebook and "like" our page. You can also follow us on Twitter.
