story:
ENGLISH VERSION

    What is this project all about?
    THE GARDEN ESTATE is a social eco farming project in Sri Lanka. Originally a brownfield site within about three years we have planted hundreds of plants (especially fruit trees and coconut palms), created a large lake, built a house of clay, timber and bamboo as well as established a renewable power supply with a small wind turbine and solar panels.

    We refrain from using any artificial fertilizers and pesticides on THE GARDEN ESTATE. The name of the project shall be our program: We are working to create a large and diverse garden. The project gives people work and feeds them.

    THE GARDEN ESTATE is adjacent to the largest national park in Sri Lanka – the Wilpattu Forest Reserve. Above all having a national park next door for us means tranquility and the view towards a huge forest. With the ecological management of THE GARDEN ESTATE, we do our part that less agricultural chemicals get into the National Park.

    Why crowdfunding for cows?
    Rathie is already there! Our first cow lives at THE GARDEN ESTATE since 2013, and had her first calf Wasana in January. The natural land with it's juicy grass is a paradise for Rathie and Wasana. But our single mum Rathie is lonely and only has a temporary shelter. Therefore we want to bring in some cow friends and build a proper barn.

    For our project, cows are very valuable and provide a good basis in the long run:

    • Regular milk sales enable us to feed at least two families (given 5 dairy cows).
    • These families can maintain the plants, grow vegetables, fruits and spices. Generating income from these products will enable us to pay more workers and more families can profit from THE GARDEN ESTATE.
    • Cows also help us to keep the lush sprouting grass short, which we would otherwise have to mow by hand or consume fossil fuel for a lawn mower.
    • Finally, we can collect dung in the barn: cow dung is great fertilizer! At the moment we have to buy it, and we want to save these costs.
    What is the project goal and who is the project for?
    Within about 30 years - since the Sri Lankan government has approved the import of seeds and fertilizers - almost the entire knowledge of local farmers about organic farming methods got lost. We are disturbed about how mainly small farmers have become dependent on agrochemicals.

    Our goals with THE GARDEN ESTATE are:

    • create jobs to secure several families' income,
    • create jobs in a healthy working environment,
    • spread the knowledge of organic farming methods (again)
    • set an example with THE GARDEN ESTATE: "Look, it works. We can feed ourselves without agrochemicals and even make money.",
    • create a place of equality and integration in a country with a long civil war history: We welcome people of all ethnics, religions and genders!

    How will we use the money if the project is successfully funded?
    We will transfer the funded amount directly to Sri Lanka and will immediately
    • buy three more cows,
    • start building a barn,
    • transport one bull, one cow and a calf, that we were given from the city of Negombo to THE GARDEN ESTATE and
    • buy milking equipment (milking machine, buckets, cans)

    Who are the people behind the project?

    THE GARDEN ESTATE was founded by Suresh and Anne Dittrich. Suresh grew up in Sri Lanka, but is living in Europe since many years. Anne comes from Germany and has spent many months in Sri Lanka. The island is our second home. THE GARDEN ESTATE is merely funded through our salaries in Germany so far. We are surrounded by friends and family around the world, who follow our vision, share the same values as well as support and encourage us with ideas, practical help and advice.
    We have found people on site, who work with us to turn THE GARDEN ESTATE into a green oasis. First of all Nilantha, Suresh's cousin works with us. He lives with his family under simple conditions in the newly built house on the land.

    Why would you support this project?

    If your heart is with eco farming, permaculture, independency of small farmers and last but not least peacemaking, then THE GARDEN ESTATE is YOUR project to support. Adequate living and working conditions as well as appropriate pay are the basis for the prevention of conflicts and finally the flows of refugees.

    For this next step on our way to the oasis we need you help!
    Be part of this great idea!
    Become a part of THE GARDEN ESTATE!

    For more info please visit: www.thegardenestate.com

    (THE GARDEN ESTATE is a non profit social project, we would like to use as much money as possible from the campaign to fund the campaign goal. However, we wish to express our appreciation for your support with small gifts! -> see right column)


    DEUTSCHE VERSION

    Worum geht es in diesem Projekt?

    THE GARDEN ESTATE ist ein soziales Ökolandbauprojekt in Sri Lanka. Beginnend mit einer großen Brachfläche, haben wir innerhalb von gut drei Jahren viele hundert Pflanzen (vor allem Obstbäume und Kokospalmen) gesetzt, einen großen See angelegt, ein Wohnhaus aus Lehm, Holz und Bambus gebaut sowie eine unabhängige Stromversorgung mit kleinem Windrad und Solarzellen eingerichtet.
    Wir verzichten auf THE GARDEN ESTATE nicht nur auf den Einsatz von künstlichem Dünger und Pestiziden, für uns ist vor allem der Name Programm: Wir arbeiten daran, einen großen, vielfältigen Garten zu schaffen. Das Projekt gibt Menschen Arbeit und soll sie ernähren.

    THE GARDEN ESTATE grenzt direkt an den größten Nationalpark Sri Lankas – das Wilpattu Forest Reserve. Für uns bedeutet die Nähe zum Nationalpark vor allem Ruhe und den Blick auf einen riesigen Wald. Mit der ökologischen Bewirtschaftung von THE GARDEN ESTATE tragen wir dazu bei, dass keine Agrochemikalien in den Nationalpark gelangen.

    Warum Crowdfunding für Kühe?

    Rathie ist schon da! Unsere erste Kuh wohnt seit 2013 auf THE GARDEN ESTATE, und im Januar hat sie ihr Kälbchen Wasana geboren. Das naturnahe Land mit seinem saftigen Gras ist ein Paradies für Rathie und Wasana. Aber unsere alleinerziehende Rathie ist einsam und hat nur einen provisorischen Unterstand. Wir wollen ihr deshalb Freunde besorgen und einen richtigen Stall bauen.

    Für unser Projekt sind Kühe sehr wertvoll und sogar auf längere Sicht eine Basis:

    • Von regelmäßigem Milchverkauf können wir mindestens zwei Familien ernähren (bei 5 Milchkühen).
    • Diese Familien können die Pflanzen pflegen, Gemüse, Früchte und Gewürze anbauen. Vom Erlös daraus können weitere Arbeiter bezahlt werden und noch mehr Familien von THE GARDEN ESTATE leben.
    • Kühe helfen uns auch, das üppig sprießende Gras kurz zu halten, das wir sonst von Hand mähen müssten, um nicht fossilen Treibstoff für einen Rasenmäher zu verbrauchen.
    • Und schließlich können wir im Kuhstall Extremente sammeln: Kuhmist ist super Dünger! Im Moment kaufen wir diesen ein, und die Kosten dafür wollen wir einsparen.


    Was sind die Ziele und wer die Zielgruppe?

    Innerhalb von rund 30 Jahren – seit die Sri Lankische Regierung den Import von Saatgut und Düngemitteln freigegeben hat – ist beinahe das gesamte Wissen der heimischen Bauern um ökologische Landbaumethoden verloren gegangen. Wir sind bestürzt, wie sich vor allem Kleinbauern von der Agrochemie abhängig machen.
    Unsere Ziele mit THE GARDEN ESTATE sind:

    • Arbeitsplätze schaffen, die mehreren Familien ein Einkommen sichern,
    • Arbeitsplätze in einem gesunden Arbeitsumfeld schaffen,
    • das Wissen um ökologische Anbaumethoden (wieder) verbreiten,
    • mit THE GARDEN ESTATE ein Exempel statuieren: „Seht her, es funktioniert. Wir können uns ohne Agrochemie ernähren und sogar noch Geld verdienen.“,
    • in einem Land mit langer Bürgerkriegsgeschichte einen Ort der Gleichberechtigung und Integration schaffen: Uns sind Menschen aller Ethnien, Religionen und Geschlechter willkommen!


    Was passiert mit dem Geld bei erfolgreicher Finanzierung?

    Ohne Umwege werden wir den Fundingbetrag nach Sri Lanka überweisen und unmittelbar

    • drei Kühe kaufen,
    • beginnen, einen Stall zu bauen,
    • einen Bullen, eine Kuh und ihr Kalb, die wir geschenkt bekommen haben, aus dem Ort Negombo zum Land transportieren und
    • Ausrüstung zum Melken kaufen (Melkmaschine, Eimer, Kannen)


    Wer steht hinter dem Projekt?

    THE GARDEN ESTATE wurde von Suresh und Anne Dittrich gegründet. Suresh ist in Sri Lanka aufgewachsen, lebt aber seit vielen Jahren in Europa. Anne kommt aus Deutschland und hat schon viele Monate in Sri Lanka verbracht. Die Insel ist unsere zweite Heimat.
    THE GARDEN ESTATE finanzieren wir bisher ausschließlich aus unseren Gehältern in Deutschland. Wir sind umgeben von Familie und Freunden auf der ganzen Welt, die unserer Vision folgen, unsere Werte teilen und uns mit Ideen, praktischer Hilfe und Ratschlägen unterstützen.
    Vor Ort haben wir Menschen eingestellt, die mit uns daran arbeiten, THE GARDEN ESTATE zu einer ökologischen Oase zu machen. Allen voran arbeitet Nilantha, Sureshs Cousin mit uns. Er wohnt mit seiner Familie unter einfachen Bedingungen in dem neu gebauten Haus auf dem Land.

    Warum solltest Du dieses Projekt unterstützen?

    Wenn Euch die Themen Ökolandbau, Permakultur, Unabhängigkeit von Kleinbauern und damit nicht zuletzt Friedensstiftung am Herzen liegen, seid Ihr bei THE GARDEN ESTATE richtig. Angemessene Lebens-, Arbeits- und Einkommensbedingungen sind die Grundlage für die Vermeidung von Konflikten und schließlich auch von Flüchtlingsströmen.

    Für den nächsten Schritt auf dem Weg zu unserer Oase brauchen wir Eure Hilfe! Seid Teil dieser großartigen Idee, werdet Teil von THE GARDEN ESTATE!

    Mehr Informationen unter: www.thegardenestate.com

    (THE GARDEN ESTATE ist ein gemeinnütziges Sozialprojekt, wir möchten so viel Gelf wie möglich aus der Kampagne für die Finanzierung des Kampagnenziels einsetzen. Dennoch möchten wir unsere Wertschätzung für Eure Unterstützung mit kleinen Dankeschöns ausdrücken! -> siehe rechte Spalte)

story:
This-Is-My-Earth.org

We are a group of environmentalists, scientists and leaders, from various countries and continents around the world. We have spent our lives working to protect nature and the environment on the planet. We are deeply concerned by the inability of existing actions and organizations to halt the sharp decline in global biodiversity. 

Our goal is to significantly broaden international participation in protecting lands located in the most precious biodiversity hot spots on earth.

How will we do it? 

We have launched an internet tool (TIME, This-Is-My-Earth.org) that will enable every person on this planet to personally participate in conservation action by purchasing land in biodiversity hot spots. This might sound familiar as there are many other organizations that are already involved with land purchasing. However, we offer several innovative concepts: 

  • a low (only $1 minimum!) membership fee; 
  • a right to vote on where the money will be invested, enabling each member to be part of a democratic conservation movement; 
  • an assurance that 100% of membership money will actually be allocated for land purchasing (as opposed to personnel salaries or other expenses); and 
  • an array of professional volunteers that will assist in directing the funds to where land conservation are most pressing. 

Most of the world’s hotspots are in poor countries. After TIME becomes established, we will offer members the opportunity to fund the membership of citizens from low-income countries.  Later, supporters will have the opportunity to provide isolated communities with the needed technological infrastructure, to assist them in joining this global venture. 

A prototype of our website is already on the air: 

http://This-Is-My-Earth.org

Your contribution will support the development of a full operative website. Once the website is fully developed, this non-profit organization will be run and maintained by volunteers, primarily from academia, whom are able to contribute their time to such a significant cause. 

We need your support!

We need $25,000 (USD) to build the website and infrastructure and to pay the salary of a web manager to maintain, build and promote the site during its first year of operation. At this point, we plan on pursuing two alternative routes: Continue on our own with volunteers or have a well-established international organization (such as a UN agency) support the website maintenance. 

Additional money raised in this campaign beyond our $25,000 (USD) target will go to land purchasing!

Every donor to this campaign will have his/her name on the site's founders page. Donators of $25 and more will receive a life-time membership in the organization. 

In case we do not reach our goal, your money will be refunded.

Let's save the world together

This-Is-My-Earth has the potential to bring millions of people from around the world to participate in nature conservation. By providing a democratic platform for citizens of the world to act and influence decision making via the single most important conservation management tool, preserving land and biodiversity, our new organization can help lead global conservation into a new era. 

What is our biggest challenge?

Our biggest challenge is to market this new initiative throughout the world. This is where we need you! You can spread the word among family members, friends and colleagues through mails and social media tools. Our association in local and international organizations will allow us to enlist the participation of schools, churches, civic groups, companies and institutions. We will encourage people everywhere to  make a modest recurrent commitment to this global effort to save the world’s most critical habitats.

Every contribution counts now, but mostly we need your help in spreading the word. Please tell your friends and family and please come join us on this journey to a better future. This Is My Earth: It's the only one we have!

Who are we? 

Dr. Uri Shanas is a professor of conservation biology at the University of Haifa - Oranim, currently a visiting researcher at the Portland State University in Oregon. Previously, he was the chair of the Department of Biology and Environment at the University of Haifa.

Ms. Wanjira Mathai has been directing International Affairs for more than a decade at the Green Belt Movement in Kenya which was founded by her mother, the late Nobel Peace Laureate Wangari Maathai. She currently serves on the Board of Directors of both GBM and the Wangari Maathai Institute for Peace & Environmental Studies.

Dr. Konstantinos Makris is a faculty member at the Cyprus International Institute for Enironmental and Public Health and an adjunct assistant professor at Harvard University.  He specializes in environmental health and habitat protection.

Mr. David Baldock is the long-time Executive Director of the London and Brussels based “Institute for European Environmental Policy”.  He has been involved in researching and helping to draft European directives and policies in a range of environmental areas involving agriculture and the environment, biodiversity and climate change and natural resources.

Dr. Alon Tal is a professor of environmental policy from Ben Gurion University with past appointments at Harvard, Stanford and Otago universities.  For the past decade he has chaired the international conference in Drylands and Desertification in conjunction with the United Nations and Sede Boqer Campus.

Mr. Eyal Shani is a senior software and technology consultant and an entrepreneur. Currently working on a start-up in the field of Out of Home advertising. Previously founded a company developing innovative CMS solutions.  He has been awarded many prizes, including the Sofaer International Strategic Case Competition and Intel Honors Award.

Dr. Clive G Jones is an ecologist and Senior Scientist at the Cary
Institute of ecosystem studies in New York State. His research studies
ecosystem engineering by species, including how they create habitats for
other species and the consequences for biodiversity. He is an elected
Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the
recipient of a number of awards, and the author of 200 publications
including 6 books.

Dr. Nick M. Haddad is a William Neal Reynold Distinguished Professor at the Department of Biology in North Carolina State University. His studies focus on habitat loss and fragmentation ecological effects. Dr. Haddad has received the Aldo Leopold Leadership Fellow award.

Dr. Jian Wu is a Professor of Economics at Renmin University of China in Beijing. As one of China’s leading environmental economists, she serves as the board member of the East Asian Association of Environmental and Resource Economics (EAAERE).  Recently, Dr. Wu completed a sabbatical year as a Fulbright Scholar at Stanford University’s Woods Environment Institute and Center for Conservation Biology where she pursued research regarding the Economics and Policy Analysis of Nature and Biodiversity Conservation.  In the past she has been a visiting scholar at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government. Since 2012 Professor Wu has served as a team leader to establish methods and tools for evaluating genetic resources at China’s Ministry of Science and Technology.

Dr. Bill Ripple is a distinguished professor in the Department of Forest Ecosystems and Society at Oregon State University where he serves as the Director of the “Global Trophic Cascades Program”. Trophic cascades include nature’s domino effects such as how predators affect plants as mediated by prey (herbivores). His research also involves studying the status and ecological effects of megafauna (large carnivores & large herbivores) globally, especially in developing countries.
story_txt:
This-Is-My-Earth.org We are a group of environmentalists, scientists and leaders, from various countries and continents around the world. We have spent our lives working to protect nature and the environment on the planet. We are deeply concerned by the inability of existing actions and organizations to halt the sharp decline in global biodiversity. 
Our goal is to significantly broaden international participation in protecting lands located in the most precious biodiversity hot spots on earth.
How will we do it? 
We have launched an internet tool (TIME, This-Is-My-Earth.org) that will enable every person on
this planet to personally participate in conservation action by purchasing land in biodiversity hot
spots. This might sound familiar as there are many other organizations that are already involved with land purchasing. However, we offer several innovative concepts: 



a low (only $1 minimum!) membership fee; 


a right to vote on where the money will be invested, enabling each member to be
part of a democratic conservation movement; 


an assurance that 100% of membership
money will actually be allocated for land purchasing (as opposed to personnel
salaries or other expenses); and 


an array of professional volunteers that will assist in
directing the funds to where land conservation are most pressing. 



Most of the world’s hotspots are in poor
countries. After TIME becomes established, we will offer members the
opportunity to fund the membership of citizens from low-income countries.  Later, supporters will have the opportunity to provide isolated communities with the needed technological infrastructure, to assist them in joining this global
venture. 
A prototype of our website is already on the air: 
http://This-Is-My-Earth.org
Your contribution will support the development of a full operative website. Once the website is fully developed, this non-profit organization will be run and maintained by volunteers, primarily from academia, whom are able to contribute their time to such a significant cause.    We need your support! We need $25,000 (USD) to build the website and infrastructure and to pay the salary of a web manager to maintain, build and promote the site during its first year of operation. At this point, we plan on pursuing two alternative routes: Continue on our own with volunteers or have a well-established international organization (such as a UN agency) support the website maintenance. 
Additional money raised in this campaign beyond our $25,000 (USD) target will go to land purchasing!
Every donor to this campaign will have his/her name on the site's founders page. Donators of $25 and more will receive a life-time membership in the organization. 
In case we do not reach our goal, your money will be refunded.
    Let's save the world together 

This-Is-My-Earth has the potential to bring
millions of people from around the world to participate in nature conservation.
By providing a democratic platform for citizens of the world to act and influence decision making via the single most important conservation management tool,
preserving land and biodiversity, our new organization can help lead global conservation into a new era. 

What is our biggest challenge? Our biggest challenge is to market this new initiative throughout the world. This is where we need you! You can spread the word among family members, friends and colleagues through mails and social media tools. Our association in local and international organizations will allow us to enlist the participation of schools, churches, civic groups,
companies and institutions. We will encourage people everywhere to  make a modest recurrent
commitment to this global effort to save the world’s most critical
habitats.
 Every contribution counts now, but mostly we need your help in spreading the word. Please tell your friends and family and please come join us on this journey to a better future. This Is My Earth: It's the only one we have!

Who are we? 
Dr. Uri Shanas is
a professor of conservation biology at the University of Haifa - Oranim,
currently a visiting researcher at the Portland State University in Oregon.
Previously, he was the chair of the Department of Biology and Environment at
the University of Haifa.

been directing International Affairs for more than a decade at the Green

Nobel Peace Laureate Wangari Maathai. She currently serves on the Board of
Directors of both GBM and the Wangari
Maathai Institute for Peace & Environmental Studies.
Dr. Konstantinos
Makris is a faculty member at the Cyprus International Institute for
Enironmental and Public Health and an adjunct assistant professor at Harvard
University.  He specializes in environmental health and habitat
protection.
Mr. David Baldock
is the long-time Executive Director of the London and Brussels based “Institute
for European Environmental Policy”.  He has been involved in researching
and helping to draft European directives and policies in a range of
environmental areas involving agriculture and the environment, biodiversity and
climate change and natural resources.
Dr. Alon Tal is a professor of environmental
policy from Ben Gurion University with past appointments at Harvard, Stanford
and Otago universities.  For the past
decade he has chaired the international conference in Drylands and
Desertification in conjunction with the United Nations and Sede Boqer Campus. 
Mr. Eyal Shani is
a senior software and technology consultant and an entrepreneur. Currently
working on a start-up in the field of Out of Home advertising. Previously

story:
About Me

Hi! I am a Boy Scout in Troop 103 Burlington, MA and a sophomore at Burlington High School. I am working towards my Eagle rank which is the highest rank you can get in scouting. This rank requires me to lead a group of people in a substantial project that benefits my local community. This is that project. I am going to lead my troop, friends, and family in constructing 3 large planting boxes and a fence behind Pine Glen Elementary School.

What We Need

The plan is to build 3 - 16ft by 6ft raised planting boxes with a 22ft by 36ft fence to surround and protect the whole area from deer and rabbits. This area will be wheelchair accessible from the gate to the spacing between the boxes. All of this is being put together with cedar boards, which are very good for surviving the harsh conditions of the New England weather. The fence will be constructed with cedar boards and chicken wire and is designed to keep out unwanted animals. The planting boxes are also going to be filled with loam. This also means, however, that the materials and tools are projected to cost $2,100 USD. All money not used will go directly to the elementary school for purchasing gardening tools and plants. This is where you are going to make a big difference.

The Impact

This will allow all 6 grades (K - 5) in the elementary school to go out and plant their own plants. It will allow them to learn all about agriculture and how to actually grow the plants. It may inspire the kids to go on and help do things for the environment, which is much needed at this point.

story:
We are Juan Santillan and Kristen Krash. Our mission is to build Sueño de Vida: an eco-lodge, retreat destination, and learning center specializing in organic farming, permaculture, sustainable building, and creative solutions for environmental challenges.

We envision a garden of Eden where people are free to create, work, rest, play, and act on the ideas that spring forth from thoughtful observation of the natural world.  As Einstein said, "a quiet life stimulates the creative mind." Our dream of life is a place where freedom, happiness, and ingenuity come together to create a positive change in the world and show people the benefits of healthful, harmonious, and sustainable living.

Why donate to this project?

Imagine your life more simple and less cluttered, but brimming with abundance and connection to nature, your self, and community. Imagine the sense of satisfaction you could feel going out to your garden to pick a fresh salad, or make fertile soil with kitchen scraps and other "waste", or build a playhouse for your children with natural and renewable materials, or reduce your dependence on fossil fuels. Now imagine a place set amidst stunning biodiversity and beauty where you can rest, rejuvenate, be inspired, and learn how to do these things yourself.  We ask you to help us build this place, this dream of life, and then join us there in making the imagined real.

Why us?

We are not only creative and passionate people, Juan and I are those gutsy survivor types who simply do not give up. We have learned what we need to learn to build our  dream, we have worked to save enough money to purchase a plot of land and live in Ecuador during the buildout...and we will be doing much of that work ourselves and with the help of volunteers! Your contribution will go DIRECTLY to the costs of construction.

Kristen has been teaching yoga and Pilates for fourteen years and is dedicated to sharing their health restoring benefits. She is passionate about putting that strength and vitality to good use: planting gardens and building sustainably! Kristen firmly believes that a good life is one lived in service to good work.

"I feel a certainty like I've never felt before--that everything in my life has led me to this project, to Sueño de Vida. It's an opportunity to put all my strength and skills into something so much bigger than myself. I've taught thousands of students how to feel better physically and energetically. I've dug and grown gardens all over the city, from alleys and curbsides to backyards and community centers. The time has come, the time is now, to create a space where people can experience a deep and real connection to themselves, to each other, to nature, and learn to live more lightly on the Earth."

A gifted builder, musician, and jack-of-all-trades, Juan takes after both his artist father and carpenter grandfather, whose craftsmanship earned him the title "el cientifico" in Quito. Juan's mantra for living is "There's a solution to every problem. If I can't find it, I'll make it." As an Ecuadorian citizen living abroad for over fifteen years, Juan is optimistic and and determined to be part of his country's initiatives towards sustainability.

"I really believe my country is a key place to work for a sustainable future. I'm happy and proud to see my country taking actions to reforest and regenerate the land, teach ecology and permaculture in elementary schools, and protect our native species and their habitat. For a small country, Ecuador has an incredible biodiversity to preserve and promote. We are home to a huge variety of flora and fauna, important ecosystems, distinct micro-climates, and the Galápagos Islands.   If you want to join the movement for a greener and healthier world, what better place to be than Ecuador?"

Our Vision:
At Sueño de Vida we invite you to:

Experience life where ecological design evolves in harmony with nature in peaceful surroundings amidst the incredible biodiversity of Ecuador.

Nourish your body, clear your mind, and awaken your soul. We will provide organic garden-to-plate meals, and plenty of space for yoga, meditation, music, the arts, and relaxing walks through our gardens and groves.

Join a community cultivating a brighter, greener, sustainable world for ourselves and future generations. We offer volunteer-exchange programs, internships, and hands-on courses in natural building, organic gardening, and home crafting. 

Heal our relationships with each other and the Earth through cooperation, compassion, and connection. 

Our Mission:
To be a vibrant eco-tourist and -learning destination inspiring and teaching creative ways to live with a smaller footprint. 

Our Objectives:
1-2 years:
Establish Sueño de Vida  as an eco-lodging and yoga retreat destination.  
Build out early modules moving toward self-sufficiency: rainwater harvesting, grey water recycling, annual vegetables and grains, domestic animals. Plant cash crops like nut trees, balsam, and bamboo to produce yields in future years. Aim to generate 30-50% of power through renewable energy. 
Engage with local sources to augment our supplies of food, power, and other necessities to what we can initially produce ourselves. 
Set up referral network with other tourism based businesses (surfing, boating, guided tours, etc) in our area. 
Develop our services and products to reach a wider audience through educational programs. 

2-4 years:
Expand our scope of services to courses on all the methods of sustainable living employed at Sueño de Vida: natural building, permaculture design, gardening, cooking, fermenting, crafting, and DIY solutions.
Reduce our dependence on external inputs of food by expanding our own production to perennial crops and early maturing fruit trees, increasing our domestic animals, and harvesting biomass we produce for compost and fertilizer. 
Reduce/eliminate our dependence on external power inputs. Increase energy used from renewable sources to 80 percent

5-10 years
Be recognized as an eco-tourist hub and resource for learning ways of sustainable living.
Expand our knowledge and services to help less-advantaged people build their own homes with readily available materials and grow their own food. 
Generate additional revenues through harvest and sales of maturing cash crops. 
Move to 100% renewable energy usage.
Continue to seek and create adaptive solutions to live simply yet abundantly--our dream life, Sueño de Vida

Like all ideas whose time has come, we have been bolstered by moments of synchronicity and discovery of communities, global and local, working for social, economic, and environmental justice--all of which are intertwining threads in this great ball of humanity. In Five Ways of Being that Can Change the World, Johanna Macy writes,

When you know where to look, you begin to see an unprecedented phenomenon now happening in this world of ours. Be they teachers in favelas, forest defenders, urban farmers...the fact is people from all walks of life are coming alive and coming together, impelled to create a more just and sustainable society...In this defining moment, countless choices are being made, habits relinquished, friendships forged, and gateways opened to unforeseen collaborations and capacities...when future generations look back at this historical moment, they will see, more clearly than we can right now, just how revolutionary it is. They may well call it the time of the Great Turning.

We are so grateful for the connections we've made our journey so far. Once we set ourselves on this path, it quickly widened into a road streaming with inventive, resourceful, and helpful people glad to help us practice the skills we have and learn the ones we will need. We've gone on "builds" and learned how to make houses from earth and rock, talked to permaculturists, cob builders, architects of straw-bale homes, and found many like-minded souls on the way. And this is only the beginning.

We are ready. Join us. Come build with us. Be part of our dream, part of the Great Turning. Together, we can renew ourselves and the earth.  Help us make our dream a new kind of reality, a real place where people and our planet can flourish.

It's a deeper calling I have, deep in my DNA...and I think it's the same for everyone, that we were put on this earth to be be caretakers, to nourish this beautiful garden... that's why humans were created, to be the caretakers of this planet. And I think we'll come to our true joy when we embrace that as a species. That's my dream. And as long as I'm here, I'll keep dreaming.--Sun Ray Kelly, natural builder, Gardener of Eden

story:
Trumpet for Topsoil!: Make Your "shout out for topsoil" pledge Now!

NOTE: One 'Loveable Loo' unassembled kit cost $185.. then we buid the privacy structure round it. In this setting we are going with these (take 6 gallon bucket) combined with self-build bigger seat-structure to contain 20 gallon bins.

The 'Loveable Loo' toilet is just one example of a 'humanure' toilet system; a system that is designed to deliver nutrient-rich sweet-smelling, safe soil; so, different from a straight-up compost toilet; humanure becomes soil and Yes; you can grow food in  :)

In contrast, poop in a porta potty is classified as  'hazardous waste', 'blackwater' (dangerous/deadly), when actually everything you eliminate is designed to turn into healthy soil, given half a chance!!

"It's proper to refer to this as 'nutrients" says John Forrest Dohlin, of fabulous Bronx Zoo humanure toilets (no red-tagging needed here!)
'TOILETS OF WHIMSY' is the funnest, most rad thing since the pogo stick. Poop is proving pure and popular in its profound and pollution-free particulates, gracefully fulfilling Rob Brezsny's Pronoia* prediction. 

We are inspired by Loveable Loos & Bronx Zoo & 'Natural Event', to show-by-design that non-chemical cradle-to-cradle** portable/mobile latrines are an inspirational and paradigm-shifting alternative to chemical 'porta-potties', most especially at natural events where folk gather together to eat, pray, love, and poop.

We are building Toilets of Whimsy.

This is a Mooovement; Elimination is a NATURAL EVENT...; which is why Australian environmental chemist Hamish Skermer calls his operation 'Natural Event' -"changing the world from the bottom up!" (see link to Hamish documentary trailer below, inlcuding bringing this knowledge to Haiti). Hamish is a true Profound Fool. 

 

Thank You Hamish also for the encouragement to re-think elimination time {being Peace as you s(h)it}.

"I am goodness and mercy and compassion and understanding.. peace and joy and light.. forgiveness and patience, strength and courage, a helper in time of need, a comforter in time of sorrow, a healer in time of injury, a teacher in times of confusion... the deepest wisdom and the highest truth; the greatest peace and the grandest love..." "You are these things. And in moments of your life you have known yourself as these things. Choose now to know yourself as these things always."; {from CWG)

RELIEVE YOURSELF ~ SWEET RELIEF 
Who knew that human poop could turn into sweet-smelling loamy compost in a season, with all pathogens rendered utterly harmless. Sweet rich loam soil  restored to us; that's Cradle-To-Cradle!

 
Everybody Knows; access to clean drinking water saves lives, particularly children's lives {thank Goodness for every tenderhearted man and woman in the archaic battlefields of our World}. 

Sanitation, like water, is a keystone for thrival-survival. Poorly handled poop gets into groundwater and thus, access to clean drinking water is UNDONE. 

This knowledge has EVERYTHING to do with the Waters of the Earth and access to clean drinking water for all - talk to 1000 Hummingbird women for the waters and they will tell you (bless their hearts). 
 

We are learning anew the tenets of natural law and it is changing governmental health & safety regulations for the 21st Century.

In this project we are bringing beautiful toilets to 1000 Hummingbirds late Spring event out in the field.  We are fashioning little shrine/thrones(4) with colors and whimsy. Total funds we raise will determine fabrication options but asthetically pleasing is a core criteria.

The Damanhur Temples of Humankind in Italy were built without power tools. We may not be quite so purist but still, we are building shrines.

Note this is a 'flexible funding' campaign, meaning we get to keep whatever level of funds we raise, and will create these toilets for 1000 Hummingbirds come what may!

“Another world is not only possible, she is on her way. On a quiet day, I can hear her breathing.” Arundhati Roy
*~*~*

*'PRONOIA' how the Universe is conspiring to shower you with blessings (Rob Brezsny book & definition)

** 'CRADLE-TO-CRADLE': 

"Cradle-to-cradle design (sometimes abbreviated to C2C, or cradle 2 cradle, or in some circles referred to as regenerative) is a biomimetic approach to the design of systems. It models human industry on nature's processes in which materials are viewed as nutrients circulating in healthy, safe metabolisms."  For the book, see Cradle to Cradle: Remaking the Way We Make Things.

*~*~*~ 

Note that Bronx Zoo has a 'Clivus Multrum' system: Clivus multrum is a type of composting toilet and the name of a company that markets this brandname of composting toilets. "Clivus" is Latin for incline or slope; "multrum" is a Swedish composite word meaning "compost room," thus a "Clivus Multrum" is an inclining compost room.[1]

*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~
BLUE POSTER - GRAPHIC ARTIST CREDIT: With special thanks to Jason Hendricks of Shadowline Graphics for my original electric blue "SPIRIT OF HUMMINGBIRD" {gift for Corrina} pictured above. Five lucky backers will receive canvas print with special message on back.

*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~**~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~**~*~**
ENDNOTE on photo: "U.S. Army Sergeant Kornelia Rachwal gives a young Pakistani girl a drink of water as they are airlifted from Muzaffarabad to Islamabad, Pakistan, aboard a U.S. Army CH-47 Chinook helicopter on the 19 October, 2005" - from Wikimedia Commons: Technical Sergeant Mike Buytas of the United States Air Force: "This image or file is a work of a U.S. Air Force Airman or employee, taken or made during the course of the person's official duties. As a work of the U.S. federal government, the image or file is in the public domain."
story_txt:
Trumpet for Topsoil!: Make Your "shout out for topsoil" pledge Now!
NOTE: One 'Loveable Loo' unassembled kit cost $185.. then we buid the privacy structure round it. In this setting we are going with these (take 6 gallon bucket) combined with self-build bigger seat-structure to contain 20 gallon bins.

The 'Loveable Loo' toilet is just one example of a 'humanure' toilet system; a system that is designed to deliver nutrient-rich sweet-smelling, safe soil; so, different from a straight-up compost toilet; humanure becomes soil and Yes; you can grow food in  :)

In contrast, poop in a porta potty is classified as  'hazardous waste', 'blackwater' (dangerous/deadly), when actually everything you eliminate is designed to turn into healthy soil, given half a chance!!
"It's proper to refer to this as 'nutrients" says John Forrest Dohlin, of fabulous Bronx Zoo humanure toilets (no red-tagging needed here!)'TOILETS OF WHIMSY' is the funnest, most rad thing since the pogo stick. Poop is proving pure and popular in its profound and pollution-free particulates, gracefully fulfilling Rob Brezsny's Pronoia* prediction. 
We are inspired by Loveable Loos & Bronx Zoo & 'Natural Event', to show-by-design that non-chemical cradle-to-cradle** portable/mobile latrines are an inspirational and paradigm-shifting alternative to chemical 'porta-potties', most especially at natural events where folk gather together to eat, pray, love, and poop.

We are building Toilets of Whimsy.
This is a Mooovement; Elimination is a NATURAL EVENT...; which is why Australian environmental chemist Hamish Skermer calls his operation 'Natural Event' -"changing the world from the bottom up!" (see link to Hamish documentary trailer below, inlcuding bringing this knowledge to Haiti). Hamish is a true Profound Fool. 
 
Thank You Hamish also for the encouragement to re-think elimination time {being Peace as you s(h)it}.
"I am goodness and mercy and compassion and understanding.. peace and joy and light.. forgiveness and patience, strength and courage, a helper in time of need, a comforter in time of sorrow, a healer in time of injury, a teacher in times of confusion... the deepest wisdom and the highest truth; the greatest peace and the grandest love..." "You are these things. And in moments of your life you have known yourself as these things. Choose now to know yourself as these things always."; {from CWG) 
RELIEVE YOURSELF ~ SWEET RELIEF Who knew that human poop could turn into sweet-smelling loamy compost in a season, with all pathogens rendered utterly harmless. Sweet rich loam soil  restored to us; that's Cradle-To-Cradle!
 Everybody Knows; access to clean drinking water saves lives, particularly children's lives {thank Goodness for every tenderhearted man and woman in the archaic battlefields of our World}. 
Sanitation, like water, is a keystone for thrival-survival. Poorly handled poop gets into groundwater and thus, access to clean drinking water is UNDONE. 
This knowledge has EVERYTHING to do with the Waters of the Earth and access to clean drinking water for all - talk to 1000 Hummingbird women for the waters and they will tell you (bless their hearts).  
We are learning anew the tenets of natural law and it is changing governmental health & safety regulations for the 21st Century.
In this project we are bringing beautiful toilets to 1000 Hummingbirds late Spring event out in the field.  We are fashioning little shrine/thrones(4) with colors and whimsy. Total funds we raise will determine fabrication options but asthetically pleasing is a core criteria.
The Damanhur Temples of Humankind in Italy were built without power tools. We may not be quite so purist but still, we are building shrines.
Note this is a 'flexible funding' campaign, meaning we get to keep whatever level of funds we raise, and will create these toilets for 1000 Hummingbirds come what may!
“Another world is not only possible, she is on her way. On a quiet day, I can hear her breathing.” Arundhati Roy*~*~*
*'PRONOIA' how the Universe is conspiring to shower you with blessings (Rob Brezsny book & definition)
** 'CRADLE-TO-CRADLE': 
"Cradle-to-cradle design (sometimes abbreviated to C2C, or cradle 2 cradle, or in some circles referred to as regenerative) is a biomimetic approach to the design of systems. It models human industry on nature's processes in which materials are viewed as nutrients circulating in healthy, safe metabolisms."  For the book, see Cradle to Cradle: Remaking the Way We Make Things.
*~*~*~ 
Note that Bronx Zoo has a 'Clivus Multrum' system: Clivus multrum is a type of composting toilet and the name of a company that markets this brandname of composting toilets. "Clivus" is Latin for incline or slope; "multrum" is a Swedish composite word meaning "compost room," thus a "Clivus Multrum" is an inclining compost room.[1]

story:
Short Summary

Together we can bring back the bees by creating 100 new colonies.

Bee Friends Farm is a family and friends enterprise dedicated to preserving bees and producing the finest all natural raw honey. Since 2006 about a third of all Amercan honeybees have vanished, victims of pesticides, mites, climate change and preditors. Without bees and their polination of a wide variety of food and plants, all living creatures suffer. Recently we lost hundreds of thousands, perhaps even millions of our bees to pesticides from a nearby farm. We want to do all we can to restore and increase our bees, but we need your help. 

We have the expertise and we are willing to do the hard work. 

It costs about $225 to create a new bee colony, and we plan to create 100. We know how to do it, and we certainly are willing to work hard to make it happen. Fortunately, with your help, we know we can restore our bee populations and even increase them. 

The bees have wonderful rewards for you.

Amazingly, it is the bees themselves who will show their appreciation by producing incredibly healthy and delicous all natural raw honey that we will help them share with you. For as little as a $25 contribution, you can get a bottle of some of the finest honey in America delivered right to your door anywhere in the continental US. If you are able to contribute even more, we have other excellent rewards, including our smooth, spreadable creamed honey. Let the bees show their undying thanks. 

Even if you are not able to contribute, we appreciate your concern for the plight of the bees. Like so many of the complex components of our environment, the bees play a vital role in the health of us all. So, bee happy, bee healthy and bee friends with the bees!

story:
Crepsi trees before...

To create a wild lands preserve..

   In July of 2012 farmers, homesteaders and committed neighbors stopped a savage 110 acre cut of second growth Siskiyou mountain trees... but that is another story (which you will find recorded below). Of the 110 acres that commercial timber came to take, they ran saw in only 8. As citizens of this planet, we (you and i) have the opportunity to turn the remaining 102 acres of beautiful, high country Oregon land into a combination restoration project/preserve. 110 acres for $156,000, of which we have raised already over $12,000. If Speak for the Trees is unable to raise these funds, the land will be sold to a larger timber company, Plum Creek Logging, who plan to clearcut the remaining trees. Our goal is to take this land out of the aggressive harvest of timbers, that the dogwood, the pine martin and the spotted owl might continue to flourish in and above this healthy, diverse forest. We will replant the 8 acres that have been cut, and will put the whole lot in the hands of Speak for the Trees nonprofit, under a conservation easment as a preserve, never to be logged again!

  On the second day of logging a giant black bear wandered up to where to we stood. He sat down behind a stump, with his legs around it and his paws on top. This bear looked both tired and strong. For one minute the bear looked at me, massive fir trees falling in the woods behind him. As the felling of trees continued to shake the earth, the bear turned and ran uphill, away from the logging and toward the wild Siskiyou Crest. It is for this bear that we fight. For the bear, the cougar, the owl, and all trees, from cedar to pacific yew,let us take this land forever from the rotation of clearcut, that the next generations of Americans may revel in it's beauty, from sea to shining sea! IN DEFENSE OF OUR WORLD!!

***********************************************************************

 

and after...

 

How We Got to Here

Spalding Timber began to fell 110 acres of second growth trees in Crepsi Gulch on June 18th, 2012. In the following week a well-coordinated community responded by holding commercial logging responsible for its negative impact on the land. As millions of dollars of heavy machinery began to crush the hillside, hundreds of calls and letters began to flood the Oregon Department of Forestry, the Forest Service, Fish and Wildlife, and the Water Resource Department ofJackson county.

The first victory required Spalding Timber and the contracted loggin company, Rick Robertson Inc., to preform dust abatement on Yale Creek, spraying water on 6 miles of dirt road daily. The Oregon Forest Practices Act requires dust abatement during timber harvests, but as Otis Blankenship at the Forest Service said to Jonathan Major a resident of Yale Creek, "We have caved in to the residents demands, now we must concede to timber." Otis' concession to timber was that, without proper multi agency approval Spalding and Rick Robertson Logging Inc. would be able to punch a road through protected owl corridor along the creeks in order to siphon water. In this scenario a national forest creek will be drained to keep costs down on the harvest and marketing of a private entity. In the words of Mr. Blankenship, this was “protocol!”

Not so fast, dude! In the days to follow, farmers and homesteaders with deeded water rights on Yale Creek got in contact with the Water Resource Department. On Tuesday, June 26th, a representative of the Water Master visited Yale Creek, and informed Spalding and company that they were indeed siphoning water illegally. Spalding would now be required to bring water from Medford, 25 miles away, for dust abatement in order to legally move 600,000 board feet of Crepsi timber from the hill to the mill, a cost of tens of thousands of dollars.

That same day Lydia Doleman, another Yale Creek resident,  documented and presented a power point presentation to Bob Marku at ODF regarding turbidity in Crepsi Creek as a result of logging equipment routinely driving directly through an "F" class fish-bearing stream, in deference to the timber harvest plan. Turns out that after 20 years with the forest service Bob Marku had become pretty close with the Spalding operator, and in lieu of citing Spalding for an obvious breech of contract, ODF required that Spalding bring 2 more dump loads of rock to line the creek. Things were beginning to add up for Spalding. At a paltry of 500 dollars per thousand board feet of lumber this job was not panning out. Protest banners were beginning to adorn the roadways, the neighborhood promising that the local population would not pay to finance any part of this operation.

On June 27th Spalding offered to sell 110 acres of mature forest adjacent to the Siskiyou Crest for $156,000, and one wek later they withdrew from the property, having harvested a painful 8 acres, while leaving a breathtaking 102 acres intact, full of life, fertility and wild song.

   The task ahead of us is the purchasing and placement into trust the 110 acres. Can you help? The Applegate Partnership Watershed Council has agreed to hold the funds as a nonprofit, 501(c)3, making all donations tax deductible. With your help Speak for the Trees can take 110 acres of high mountain Siskiyou forest, the habit that it provides, and the water that it filters out of the cycle of industrial logging, placing it into the hands of a non-profit with a diverse board of directors, of which you will be an integral part. In the name of all who come next, animals, trees, humans, fish, birds wind and water, FOREVER WILD, FOREVER FREE!!

story:
Our Story, and the expected impact of our campaign


Nicolas Rivoire, 29 years old, French photographer.

"My current project is about Patagonia. I have already been there and I know how beautiful, wild, remote, and intense it can be.

But today, this part of the world, one of the last wild places that exist on this planet, is threatened. Chile's government has started a project, called HidroAysÃ©n, which consists in building 5 huge dams on two major Chilean Patagonian rivers. 



Fortunately, Chilean people have struggled and the project is now interrupted, suspended to the decision of the Supreme Court of Chile, waiting for additional data about the ecological impact that such a project could have....recently the Chilean government started to discuss with Argentina to send electrical power lines through their country.


Then, with one of my best friends, Abdel, who has already spent 18 months in the southern part of Argentina, I want to do a report in this region. Abdel will write and I will take the pictures.


Far from the clichÃ©s, the postal card pictures of the traditional gauchos (i.e.: the Patagonian cow-boys), what I would like to discover is the actual way of life of the inhabitants of this region. What I would like to show is the unknown and under-covered story: how the people over there manage to live a quite simply life with still a strong relationship with nature, which is a knowledge that most of us have lost over the past decades. What are their dreams?


What do they expect for their future since they refuse the so-call progress? Could an alternative exist to meet the government's goal of a 6% percent growth per year?  Would the people take advantage of it ?


By helping us, funding this campaign, you would not only help two young reporters to do their job and hopefully, be published, but you would also help to spread the word, you will help people to be aware of one ignored and major both environmental and human issue, and I think that it is worth it !

Thank you !"


Abdelbassat Abdelbaki, 28 years old, French researcher and blogger.

"Forget about the long name and surname, let's stick with Abdel! As Nicolas mentioned before, I've been living in Argentina, in the Santa Cruz province, for a bit more than 18 months, and I love it. To claim knowing Patagonia, you have to travel through it, discover it, and take your time to do so. As a 'researcher' here in an Argentinian public university, I'm very interested in energy, renewables especially. I've nothing more to add, but that we'll be as objective as possible, for misinformation is sadly commonly spread nowadays, the work of informing people getting polluted by political and economical interests. I know it's naive, but this is the way we chose!

More than your contribution, we also urge you to spread the word. Send it to whoever you want, please!"


Abdel

Resources :
http://www.conservacionpatagonica.org/
http://www.patagoniasinrepresas.cl/final/index.php
http://video.patagonia.com/video/Patagonia-Sin-RepresasPatagonia



What We Need

What You Get

A fine art print on baryte paper is something rather special. Executed manually, each print can last for years, and make you feel emotions than you can't experiment on a computer screen !


Check the movie on this webpage to discover the complex process of printing a true Black & White photography. By one of the last master of the technique !


Other Ways You Can Help

Let your friends, girlfriend(s), grand pa', doctor, butcher, boss, car valet, etc... know about our campaign, and tell them that if they like it they MUST also spread the word...or support it with a donation ! 


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


La Patagonie, un mot qui immÃ©diatement vous transporte, vous plonge dans des rÃªves aussi profonds et sauvage que le territoire lui-mÃªme. La Patagonie, aujourdâ€™hui menacÃ©e par des projets fous, faits de barrages gÃ©ants et de lignes haute-tension.


Tout au long des derniers mois, la population du sud Chilien a fait savoir son dÃ©saccord et a organisÃ© des manifestations qui peu Ã  peu ont gagnÃ© tout le pays (et dont les traces sont encore visibles par endroits dans la capitale, Santiago).


Â« Patagonia sin represas Â», tel est donc le mot dâ€™ordre des opposants aux barrages, et tel est aussi le sujet qui divise le Chili, pays en plein dÃ©veloppement, dont le gouvernement voit dans les cours dâ€™eau patagons un moyen de subvenir aux besoins Ã©nergÃ©tiques Ã  long terme et maintenir une croissance Ã©levÃ©e (objectif affichÃ© : 6%/an).


PoussÃ© par le dÃ©sir dâ€™en savoir plus sur un sujet qui manque de visibilitÃ© dans les mÃ©dias, nous avons dÃ©cidÃ© de consacrer deux semaines de notre pÃ©riple patagon Ã  la rÃ©alisation dâ€™un reportage. Conscient que derriÃ¨re les paysages merveilleux de Patagonie se cachent Ã©galement des hommes, nous souhaitons aller Ã  leur rencontre, dÃ©couvrir leur quotidien, leurs craintes et leurs espoirs, pour essayer de mieux comprendre ce conflit. Conflit qui par ailleurs symbolise les choix cornÃ©liens auxquels un pays est bien souvent confrontÃ© lorsqu'il souhaite poursuivre sa croissance : sacrifier une partie de son patrimoine naturel, quitte Ã  renouveler les erreurs des pays qui ont dÃ©jÃ  suivi cette voie, ou inventer un nouveau modÃ¨le de dÃ©veloppement et assumer la part de risque que cela comporte ?


Nicolas, 29 ans, photographe, se chargera de donner vie au reportage, tout cela en (belles) images. Quant Ã  Abdel, 28 ans, chercheur en Argentine, il s'occupera de vous informer Ã  la rÃ©daction des articles, tout en faisant en sorte que vous ne vous ennuyiez pas !


Souhaitant nous donner les moyens de rÃ©ussir, nous lanÃ§ons donc une campagne de financement via IndieGogo. Nous apprÃ©cierons, aussi modeste soit-elle, une contribution de votre part Ã  notre projet bien sur, mais nous serons dâ€™autant plus heureux si vous nous aidez Ã  diffuser, Ã  faire circuler lâ€™information : câ€™est le moment de Twitter, de faire chauffer sa boite mail ou sa page Facebook ! Qui sait, lâ€™un dâ€™entre vous possÃ¨de peut-Ãªtre un lointain cousin dans la presse qui serait potentiellement intÃ©ressÃ© par le projet de ces deux jeunes qui en veulent ?


Merci dâ€™avance les amis !


Abdel & Nico


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Patagonia water no get enemy en EspaÃ±ol !


La Patagonia. Cuantos la habrÃ¡n recorrido, cuantos habrÃ¡n descubierto, o pensado descubrir, sus territorios vÃ­rgenesâ€¦ Sin embargo, la patagonia es sumamente extensa, y uno puede viajar allÃ­ varias veces, tomando rutas distintas, y cada vez conocer algo diferente. La patagonia tambiÃ©n es sinÃ³nima de recursos valiosos, viento, minerales, oro, plataâ€¦ y tal vez el mas importante, el agua. Indispensable para vivir, componente clave del cuerpo humano, el agua es a su vez una tremenda fuente de energÃ­a.

En Chile, se ha decidido explotar este recurso, instalando grandes represas en las zonas de los rÃ­os Baker y Pascua. El proyecto HidroAysÃ©n serÃ¡ llevado a cabo por el consorcio Endesa-Colbun, si es que se acepta. Liderando un movimiento de protesta cada dÃ­a mas fuerte oponiendose a la construcciÃ³n, el presidente del Senado Guido Girardi afirma que el proceso es poco transparente. Mucha gente desaprueba estas â€˜megarepresasâ€™, a travÃ©s de organizaciones como Patagonia sin represas. Es cierto, el tema da mucho para reflexionar sobre las acciones a realizar y decisiones a tomar.

Sin embargo, un paÃ­s como Chile, que pretende mantener una tasa de crecimiento anunciada alrededor de los 6% anuales, un paÃ­s importando mucha de su energÃ­a, se puede permitir rechazar en bloque esta propuesta? La explotaciÃ³n turÃ­stica descontrolada no serÃ¡ igual de daÃ±ina para la diversidad de fauna y flora patagÃ³nica? No existen soluciones que satisfagan ambas partes? Y que tal de las lineas de transmisiÃ³n de esta energÃ­a, cuyo recorrido incluirÃ¡ probablemente Argentina?

Pues intentaremos saber mas del asunto y relatar lo mas objetivamente esta ardiente polÃ©mica. Pero quienes somos nosotros? Nicolas, 29 aÃ±os, fotÃ³grafo francÃ©s, proveerÃ¡, a travÃ©s de la mirada de su lente, imÃ¡genes de lo que ve. Abdel, 28 aÃ±os, investigador francÃ©s radicado en Argentina, harÃ¡ todo lo posible para que no se aburran y que que sigan esta aventura/reportaje !


Nico y Abdel
story_txt:
Our Story, and the expected impact of our campaign


Nicolas Rivoire, 29 years
old, French photographer.


"My current project is about Patagonia. I
have already been there and I know how beautiful, wild, remote, and intense it
can be. 
But today, this part of the world, one of the last wild places that
exist on this planet, is threatened. Chile's government has started a project, called
HidroAysÃ©n, which consists in building 5 huge dams on two major
Chilean Patagonian rivers. 



Fortunately, Chilean people have struggled and the project
is now interrupted, suspended to the decision of the Supreme Court of Chile, waiting
for additional data about the ecological impact that such a project could have....recently the Chilean government started to discuss with Argentina to send
electrical power lines through their country. 

Then, with one of my best friends, Abdel,
who has already spent 18 months in the southern part of Argentina, I want to do
a report in this region. Abdel will write and I will take the pictures. 

Far
from the clichÃ©s, the postal card pictures of the traditional gauchos (i.e.: the
Patagonian cow-boys), what I would like to discover is the actual way of life
of the inhabitants of this region. What I would like to show is the unknown and
under-covered story: how the people over there manage to live a quite simply
life with still a strong relationship with nature, which is a knowledge that
most of us have lost over the past decades. What are their dreams? 

What do they
expect for their future since they refuse the so-call progress? Could an
alternative exist to meet the government's goal of a 6% percent growth per
year?  Would the people take advantage of it
?

By helping us, funding this campaign, you
would not only help two young reporters to do their job and hopefully, be
published, but you would also help to spread the word, you will help people to
be aware of one ignored and major both environmental and human issue, and I
think that it is worth it ! 
Thank you !"





Abdelbassat Abdelbaki, 28 years old, French researcher and blogger.

"Forget about the long name and surname, let's stick with Abdel! As Nicolas mentioned before, I've been living in Argentina, in the Santa Cruz province, for a bit more than 18 months, and I love it. To claim knowing Patagonia, you have to travel through it, discover it, and take your time to do so. As a 'researcher' here in an Argentinian public university, I'm very interested in energy, renewables especially. I've nothing more to add, but that we'll be as objective as possible, for misinformation is sadly commonly spread nowadays, the work of informing people getting polluted by political and economical interests. I know it's naive, but this is the way we chose!


More than your contribution, we also urge you to spread the word. Send it to whoever you want, please!"



AbdelResources :http://www.conservacionpatagonica.org/http://www.patagoniasinrepresas.cl/final/index.phphttp://video.patagonia.com/video/Patagonia-Sin-RepresasPatagonia



What We Need

story:
Help us get to the White House!

Hey all, Rodman here. Nearly a year ago I had a life-altering awakening. I had never been the kind of guy who intentionally abused the planet on which I live, but when I took a step back and looked really hard at the carbon footprint that I had developed, I became quite alarmed. Where I would typically think, "what difference can one person make", I started to realize that if everyone thought this way, our planet would be in dire straights!

So, I set out on a mission to learn about how I can be a better steward of our planet. I decided to learn about the most extreme sustainable practices (from the most extreme people), then decide which of these practices are practical, and can have the most positive impact. In doing so, I began to learn that there are hundreds of small changes I can make, that will have a considerable positive impact on our world.

But why go through this process alone? If I could make a positive global impact by myself, why not bring these practices to the world so that we can make change on a global level? This is where PBS comes in. PBS has agreed to air The Urban Conversion. However, due to limited PBS funding, we need your help bringing this mission alive. We need your to help us change the world, and bring about positive environmental change!

The Urban Conversion was recently invited to the White House, to learn about the White House garden, and what is being done on a federal level to educate the nation on eating healthly.  This is a message that is being passed to adults and children alike.

Being invited to the White House is a tremendous opportunity, which will allow us to work with White House Chef Sam Kass, and educate our audience about urban agriculture at the highest level.  Our staff is very excited about this opportunity and ready to bring a tremendous show to the PBS audience.  In order to produce the show, we are looking to raise $20,000.  This covers the hard costs associated with the full production, from travel, to videography to the final edit.  We have assembled a crew of incredible professionals to bring this one-hour special episode of the program to life.

We invite you to come along for the ride, and join us in these critical efforts to bring positive change to our world.

What is The Urban Conversion Series?

First and foremost, The Urban Conversion is not another "preachy" environmental television series. The show educates viewers in a fun and light hearted manner. It brings a "city-slicker" out of his office, and into a world of change.

From raising chickens and goats in the city, to the most unique green lifestyles, host Rodman Schley makes the ultimate conversion from his current urban business lifestyle, to an off-the-grid urban homestead.

The Urban Conversion is best described as homesteading in an urban environment for dummies, and show host Rodman Schley is the ultimate dummy! Rodman is a fiscally conservative businessman, who is on a socially responsible quest to reduce his own current carbon footprint. In doing so, he inserts himself into “extreme green” situations to learn the ins and outs of an off-the-grid sustainable homestead lifestyle in the city.

Experience the internal conflict and humor that ensues, as the worlds of the extreme green and conservative city slicker collide. The Urban Conversion is about educating the dummy (Rodman), and ultimately educating urbanites about making small changes that can significantly reduce environmental impact. Ever raised chickens in your back yard? How about milked a goat or raised bees? Well, neither has Rodman! Travel across the country with us as we seek out the extremes of going green!

Episode 1 - Sizzle Reel

In Episode 1, Rodman visits an urban farm in Denver, Colorado. Sundari Kraft (Author of The Idiots Guide to Urban Homesteading), show him the ins and outs of raising vegetables, goats and chicken in the city!

Other Season 1 Episodes include:

Episode 2:   The Backyard Beekeeper

Episode 3:   A Visit to the White House Garden

Episode 4:   Harnessing Solar Power

Episode 5:   Farm to Table and Organic Farming

Episode 6:   Getting Dirty with Recycling and Zero Waste

Episode 7:   Discovering Alternative Transportation

Episode 8:   Electric and Hybrid Vehicles

Episode 9:   Exploring Wind Energy

Episode 10: Building Green

I'm Bob Charles a Broadcaster on the www.kinetichifi.com Worldwide Broadcasting Network. I have for a Year been growing personally funded Radio Broadcastings on many Subjects and it is now time to ask the PUBLIC for help.

Organic farmers and our food supply have a huge environmental hazard to contend with compliments of the U.S. government – chemtrails. Chemtrails are chemical or biological agents deliberately sprayed at high altitudes for purposes undisclosed to the general public in programs directed by various government officials. These sprays pollute the soil, water and air while compromising the health of humans, animals and plants. But wait – Monsanto has developed seeds that will weather the effect of the sprays, creating a tidy profit for the corporation while organics suffer.

OUR NEW NETWORK IS "PYRAMID ONE NETWORK" WHICH WAS DESIGNED TO GET THE "WORD OUT" HOWEVER LIKE ALL THE REGULAR NEWS YOU SEE THIS IS NOT REGULATED COMMERCIALLY SO WE CAN TELL YOU THE REAL TRUTH WITHOUT LOOSING JOBS OR BEING SANCTIONED.

WATCH THIS CLIP - WE NEED HELP TO GET THE WORD OUT !     http://youtu.be/1rwmD4c_NxI  


THESE RADIO BROADCASTS ARE ALL THROUGH THE INTERNET AND WE WILL PROCEED TO CONNECT AROUND THE WORLD USING NEW TECHNOLOGY THAT WILL ENABLE HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS IN OUR WORLD TO LEARN AND BE EDUCATED. NO THIS IS NOT TO START RIOTS, FIGHTS, OR WARS, IT IS BEING FORMED TO GIVE YOU THE INFORMATION YOU NEED TO SURVIVE.  HELP US TO HELP YOU !

story:
Short Summary

Our not-for-profit organisation, RiverSmart Australia, working with the local community, is setting up an education, recreation and cultural centre in Warren (far west NSW, Australia), a bit over an hours' drive from the iconic and partly Ramsar-listed Macquarie Marshes.  

We've called it the Window on the Wetlands (WOW) Centre as it sits beside the Tiger Bay Wetlands, a wonderful boutique wetland with walking trails, interpretive signage and a bird hide. While I'm now the CEO of RiverSmart, previously I was the Deputy Secretary-General of the Ramsar Wetlands Convention and so I've seen centres like the one we're trying to create here all over the World. We're taking the best ideas from those other centres and trying to apply them here. 

Last year, with crowd funding support, local donations and fund-raisers, plus a benefit concert by Australian country music star Sara Storer, we raised $60,000 to save from demolition, and then relocate, a 120 years old timber church to our site. It has now been refurbished with the help of funds from the NSW Government, local community organisations and tradies. 

The next stage, for which we are seeking crowd funding help again, is to add covered verandas to the former church hall (to protect our interpretive boards) and to install seven outdoor information shelters.  Each shelter will have eight panels and the themes proposed for these include the amazing biodiversity of the region, the Macquarie marshes, introduced pests and weeds, catch and release fishing (this river has several threatened fish species), regional farming enterprises and how to be a RiverSmart farmer, early European explorers and history and the cultural connections of the Indigenous Wailwan people of Warren and surrounds to the river and  wetlands. Through grants we've received the Aboriginal artists of Warren are currently painting several totem poles to be part of the outdoor exhibitions (see Youtube clip), plus the local lead-lighting group are working to create lead-light windows of wetland species to be installed in the Centre. 

We've estimated we'll need $Aud 50,000  to undertake these installations. This is just for the construction and we will provide our own time and resources, with help from experts, to develop the content of the interpretive signage.  Each stand-alone interpretive shelter is estimated to cost $Aud 4,000 to build and the two verandas, with ramps for disabled person access, approximately $Aud 22,000 for the materials.  A local business has already pledged support for constructing the verandas by donating the labour. 

Our vision is to have over 1,000 school children per year coming to the site for hands-on education at our Centre made even more real by being able to take them to the Tiger Bay Wetlands beside our site.  Plus, we hope to attract up to 5,000 visitors annually to our Centre to help them learn about the critical importance of sustaining rivers and wetlands, and how the threats to them could escalate, including if climate change predictions for this region are realised. 

Through our related Macquarie River Trails initiative (www.rivertrails.com.au) we promote sustainable eco-tourism of the river and surrounds, plus in a few months we hope to be able to offer visitors the opportunity to 'get up close and personal' with the Macquarie Marshes through guided tours. 

We are moving at present to form a locally-based Task Force to oversee this stage of developing the WOW Centre and to then act as an ongoing management committee. This will ensure sound use of any funds raised and further enhance local ownership for this venture and all it seeks to achieve. 

Even if we don't reach our full funding raising target, smaller amounts will allow progress to be made. For example, each $4,000 will build one interpretive shelter. 

Why is this project important?  Globally wetlands are increasingly under threat. Much of this is caused by small decisions in river, or nearby land management, that when combined magnify to increase pressure on wetlands which sees them slowly degraded or reduced in size.  The WOW Centre aims to educate people from all walks of life about why wetlands are so vital and what they can do individually, as a family or business operator, to make a difference.  

We also see the WOW Centre as being a place to offer adult education and training programs targeting those working in water and land management including the farming community. These programs will help encourage application of best practice management to lessen the threats to the Macquarie River and Marshes, which the locals all openly state are the lifeblood of this region. 

The WOW Centre is also important for the small community of Warren, with a population of about 2,500. Such communities across the inland of Australia are struggling as their populations age, the younger people move to the bigger centres for jobs and small businesses struggle to stay open faced with competition from the larger regional centres (in this case Dubbo in particular). Warren is a community built on agriculture and while this will remain the case into the future, climatic and market uncertainties mean this community must diversify it's income streams if it is to remain viable. By encouraging people to visit the WOW Centre, and to stay a few nights to absorb all about the river and Marshes, plus the rich cultural heritage of the region, there will be significant economic and social benefits for the town. 

So, please consider helping us achieve our vision. Plus, also tell your friends about us and our dream of creating the WOW Centre in Warren and to put on their 'bucket list' to visit to this town and take the chance to see the remarkable Macquarie Marshes.
