We've estimated we'll need $Aud 50,000  to undertake these installations. This is just for the construction and we will provide our own time and resources, with help from experts, to develop the content of the interpretive signage.  Each stand-alone interpretive shelter is estimated to cost $Aud 4,000 to build and the two verandas, with ramps for disabled person access, approximately $Aud 22,000 for the materials.  A local business has already pledged support for constructing the verandas by donating the labour. 
Our vision is to have over 1,000 school children per year coming to the site for hands-on education at our Centre made even more real by being able to take them to the Tiger Bay Wetlands beside our site.  Plus, we hope to attract up to 5,000 visitors annually to our Centre to help them learn about the critical importance of sustaining rivers and wetlands, and how the threats to them could escalate, including if climate change predictions for this region are realised. 
Through our related Macquarie River Trails initiative (www.rivertrails.com.au) we promote sustainable eco-tourism of the river and surrounds, plus in a few months we hope to be able to offer visitors the opportunity to 'get up close and personal' with the Macquarie Marshes through guided tours. 
We are moving at present to form a locally-based Task Force to oversee this stage of developing the WOW Centre and to then act as an ongoing management committee. This will ensure sound use of any funds raised and further enhance local ownership for this venture and all it seeks to achieve. 
Even if we don't reach our full funding raising target, smaller amounts will allow progress to be made. For example, each $4,000 will build one interpretive shelter. 
Why is this project important?  Globally wetlands are increasingly under threat. Much of this is caused by small decisions in river, or nearby land management, that when combined magnify to increase pressure on wetlands which sees them slowly degraded or reduced in size.  The WOW Centre aims to educate people from all walks of life about why wetlands are so vital and what they can do individually, as a family or business operator, to make a difference.  
We also see the WOW Centre as being a place to offer adult education and training programs targeting those working in water and land management including the farming community. These programs will help encourage application of best practice management to lessen the threats to the Macquarie River and Marshes, which the locals all openly state are the lifeblood of this region. 
The WOW Centre is also important for the small community of Warren, with a population of about 2,500. Such communities across the inland of Australia are struggling as their populations age, the younger people move to the bigger centres for jobs and small businesses struggle to stay open faced with competition from the larger regional centres (in this case Dubbo in particular). Warren is a community built on agriculture and while this will remain the case into the future, climatic and market uncertainties mean this community must diversify it's income streams if it is to remain viable. By encouraging people to visit the WOW Centre, and to stay a few nights to absorb all about the river and Marshes, plus the rich cultural heritage of the region, there will be significant economic and social benefits for the town. 
So, please consider helping us achieve our vision. Plus, also tell your friends about us and our dream of creating the WOW Centre in Warren and to put on their 'bucket list' to visit to this town and take the chance to see the remarkable Macquarie Marshes.

story:
My name is Herb Nolan and I help direct the Lawrence and Lillian Solomon Foundation, committed to delivering innovative park projects for Greater Boston neighborhoods. The Solomon Foundation, in close partnership with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and others, is seeking to narrow a dangerous and excessively wide roadway in Cambridge and Watertown.  This will make room for the Greenough Greenway: a new mile long path along the Charles River lined with shade trees, lush lawns, and wildflower meadows. 

This ambitious million dollar+ project is being funded in large part through the generosity of the Commonwealth and major private donors but we still have a funding gap to bridge in order to build it.   The design is complete, the permits are in hand, and the DCR staff is poised and ready to get this project out to bid.  All we are missing is your support.   Please make a contribution and help spread the word!

(News flash:  We  have already achieved our $40,000 goal thanks to the generosity of donors some of whom donated off line.  Thank you!  These funds will be applied to the first phase of the Greenough Greenway project which includes the narrowing of Greenough Boulevard and the construction of the new tree lined path.  On his last week in office Governor Duval Patrick announced implementation of this now fully funded phase.  All future donations will be applied to Phase 2 which includes a 1500 foot path around the Hell's Half Acre marsh and the Pond to River Walk linking Fresh Pond to the River which we plan to add back into the project this year.  Several images of Phase 2 and the Governor's press release can be seen by going to the "Gallery"  at the top of this page.   Future donations can be made here on the indiegogo site or - if you wish to avoid a service change - at our Solomon Foundation web site.  Go to www.solomonfoundation.org )

Benefits

Greenough Boulevard, located between the Eliot Bridge and Arsenal Street, crowds the river today, leaving little room for pedestrians and cyclists.  Its wide expanse of asphalt drains directly to the river degrading water quality.  This ambitious plan will fix Greenough Boulevard while:

  • Creating better park access for the 80,000 people who live or work within walking distance and for the hundreds of thousands who recreate or commute along the Charles River.
  • Taming speeding traffic and increasing pedestrian safety.
  • Converting close to three acres of crumbling pavement to new parkland.
  • Planting 135 shade trees.
  • Establishing over an acre of wild flower meadows.
  • Mitigating climate change by cooling the city and soaking up storm water .
  • Filtering surface run off and improving water quality.  
  • Completing one of the best five kilometer recreational loops in the region.

Our goal is to put this project out to bid in January so time is short.   How often do you get a chance to transform a mile of riverfront in the heart of our city and leave a legacy for future generations?   This is a rare opportunity that could be lost if we don't raise at least $40,000 by the end of January. With your generous donation we can break ground in the spring and cut a ribbon in the fall.  Please watch our seven minute video and join the campaign.

story:
Who We Are...

We are residents of the Village of New Paltz who feel strongly about sustainability and protecting our environment. In 2014 the Village of New Paltz Board of Trustees unanimously passed a law banning all single use plastic check out bags in the village. This law will go into effect on Earth Day, 2015. It is our hope that through this campaign, we can spread the word about the detrimental impact of these single use plastic bags and raise funds which we will use to purchase reusable shopping bags to give out to the community to help make the transition as seamless as possible.

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $3,000 through this campaign and all of the money raised will go to purchasing reusable shopping bags to be given out to the community.

Individuals who donate $25 or more will receive a Bag Free NPZ ceramic mug

Individuals who donate $50 or more will receive a Bag Free NPZ t-shirt

Individuals who donate $75 or more will receive a Bag Free NPZ travel mug

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing our video and our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family via email or social media is a great way to get the word out!

story:
Who We Are and What We Do:

The North Oakland Headwaters Land Conservancy (NOHLC) is a private, non-profit, community supported, citizen run organization with 40 years experience in preserving open space in northwest Oakland County and nearby communities. During our existence, we have successfully acquired over 1,400 acres in six townships and two counties. These land parcels range from 1/2 acre to over 100 acres. Our ongoing mission is to conserve the woods, fields, streams, and other natural resources in the headwaters area of the Clinton, Shiawassee, Huron, and Flint Rivers.  

What We Need:

NOHLC needs to update its technology by acquiring three hand held GPS units at a cost of $1300.00. These GPS units will in turn grant our site inspectors the ability to accurately document such things as rare plants, the location of dumped refuse and boundary violations that threaten our sanctuaries.  This will greatly improve NOHLC's ability to accurately monitor and take neccessary action in protecting our special natural areas. Our region of Michigan demands the best care now to protect its unique environments, established 13,000 years ago when the glaciers retreated.

NOHLC will begin a comprehensive survey of its preservation sites using both the GPS and photographic features of these Garmin units. The 2013 survey will include the location and documentation of threatened/endanged flora and fauna, property violations, and invasive species. Additionally, the survey will inform the conservancy of where additional boundary posts and signs are needed so as to better inform the public of our ongoing preservation efforts.  Help us update our technology to better protect the environment.

The Impact:

As mentioned above, your donation will fund the acquisition of GPS equipment that will in turn be used not only to enhance the efforts of preserving natural areas for the enjoyment of future generations but also creating sustainable habitats for native Michigan species  to thrive and grow. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you are unable to donate, you can still help us out in many ways! Many an Indiegogo campaign has succeeded because caring people like you have worked to spread to word to friends and family via facebook, email, Indiegogo, or by old fashioned word of mouth! Or, if you'd like to volunteer with us we'd LOVE to meet you! Just check out our website and drop us a line!

Every bit helps regardless of size and all of it is greatly appreciated!

story:
COOKING WITH JUST THE SUN

The Solar Stove is a solar cooker than can fully cook food using only the sun’s energy. It is light-weight, portable, water & tear resistant and uses zero fossil fuels. It produces zero emissions and It can be set up within seconds by a child. The Solar Stove can also pasteurize water, sterilize tools and utensils.

Shahee Solar teamed up with the American Relief Agency for the Horn of Africa (ARAHA), a 501(c)3 Not-for-profit organization, to implement a game-changing solar relief operation. ARAHA has 14 years experience helping those in need in Africa. Theyare a game changer amongst a world of relief organizations and the Shahjee Team was thrilled to partner with them on this project.


Solar Stove Specs: 

• Approx. Dimensions Folded - 14" x 14" x 3"
• Weight: Approx 1 pound
• Material: Fire, water and tear resistant aluminum bubble foil insulation
• Easy-fold process
• Capacity: two cooking pots at a time
• Cooking Time: approximately 30 min (fish, beans) - 2 hour (chicken, potatoes) after pot is preheated.

 

Story: 

My father recently retired after over 40 years in the civil engineering mostly in the energy sector. With a lot of time on his hands, I encouraged him to give something back. He called me over to his house one day and brought me into his backyard beholding a shiny object in the middle of the yard. I asked what it was, he said, “it’s a solar cooker I made.” I was baffled until he explained that, yes, you can cook with ONLY the energy of the sun. With a pitch-black pot in the middle absorbing maximum heat, he was able to cook rice, lentils, fish, and vegetables with only this source of energy. Zero emissions, zero cost for fuel, zero hassle.
He explained to me that anyone can use this product, but the people who need it most are the needy people of the world who can only cook with coal and firewood, which causes repertory problems. As a full-time non-profit relief worker, I was ecstatic about what this means to the people all over the world. No more risk of kidnapping while gathering wood. No more depleting of scarce forestry. No more wasted nutrients because of high heat cooking. This was the solution, right in front of me. The vision overtook my peripheral and the family is now on a path to provide this to the whole world, along with other cutting edge innovations for solar relief (i.e. solar kettle, solar lantern etc.).

 


OBJECTIVES 

We need your help to launch this survey that will be published all around the world for everyone to see how easy and powerful that adopting the solar solution truly is. We can change the world together, one meal at a time.
Goal: Our goal for the Solar Stove Survey project is a minimum of 200 Solar Stoves shipped to Sudan for the field team and fund the survey implementation. To do this we need 200 Solar Stoves with optimal black cooking pots. The more we raise, the more families we can provide the solar solution and the more of you can receive the tool revolutionizing the world. 

 

 

BENEFITS

SOLAR STOVE

1) Preserve moisture and nutrients with a slow, solar cooked meal.
2) Cook without the need for gas, wood, charcoal or Super Mario magic flower.
3) Show your family and friends what they've never seen, a solar cooked meal.

STUDY

1) Provide hundreds of families with an amazing tool that will change the entire region.
2) Vital information about its use in the field for refinement of the distribution and training process.
3) Show the world raw data that the sun can heal the world while saving the planet.


CAPABILITIES

story:
Our Indiegogo Campaign is now finished. If you wish to support our project please visit www.waterwomenfilm.com

 

 A Message from the Producer

I am a cultural anthropologist with a specialty in the English speaking Caribbean. I am a Professor at Bridgewater State University in Bridgewater MA. I have been committed to environmental issues since I was a child, and this film unites many interests and passions of mine including environmental and gender issues.

I have dedicated Water Woman to the memory of my late mother, Vivian C. Fox who was a passionate advocate for women's rights, social justice and environmental causes worldwide.

About the Film

The film tells the inspiring story of a sustainable agro-forestry community in Trinidad, West Indies, called Fondes Amandes, led by a charismatic woman, Akilah Jaramogi (pictured above). Three decades ago Akilah settled on a barren, deforested hillside, blighted with floods in the rainy season and fires in the dry season. Together with her late husband, Tecumah, they started a family and reforested over 150 acres, restoring health to the hills and the watershed just outside the capital city of Port-of-Spain. When her husband died, Akilah continued this great work, initiating the Fondes Amandes Community Reforestation Project (FACRP), training community members as stewards of the forests and waters. Today Fondes Amandes is a thriving village atop a flourishing forest of 150 acres where residents have planted thousands of seedlings over the past thirty years. The community is visited by international dignitaries and Akilah is heralded as the Wangari Maathai of Trinidad. This film will tell the story of Akilah, the Fondes Amandes villagers and their remarkable achievements, serving as an educational, activist and inspirational tool for students, educators, NGOs and other communities worldwide.

 

Funding Needs

In order to complete and market this documentary, ensuring that it reaches a wide audience and has maximum impact, the film team and I need to raise $25,000. We would be so appreciative if you could help us in any amount you can!

 

The Impact

By supporting the production and marketing of the film you will assist the Fondes Amandes Community as well. By donating you will help us to bring awareness to the environmental problems and degradation of natural systems which many communities in Trinidad face. With combined efforts we can work together to inform people of the inspirational acts of one woman and a community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to make monetary contributions. We would greatly appreciate it if you could reach out to at least five friends and colleagues who may share these concerns and wish to contribute to our efforts. Spread the word! We need all the help we can get!

 

The Team

Diana Fox (Executive Producer)

Sarah Feinbloom (Producer, Co-Director)

Swati Guild (Co-Director, Camera, Editor)

Lydia Landim (Campaign Manager)

story:
We need a GATOR (and not for Buffalo Bayou!)

Last year, the Memorial Park Conservancy Volunteer Management Program mobilized over 2,000 volunteers resulting in 6,800 hours of work.  This translated to $153,476 in value—an incredible impact on Memorial Park.

We equip our volunteers with tools and equipment.  Quite simply, our golf cart is insufficient for carrying such a large amount of supplies, and often even gets stuck in the mud.  We need a vehicle that can handle the variety of terrain in this 1500-acre park.  This campaign will allow us to purchase one John Deere Gator and a 5x8 trailer.  A maintenance and operating fund of $1000 will also be established.  Any proceeds raised exceeding goal will be added to this fund.

Please spread the word—it’s an easy way to help your Park and it makes our ability to improve it even better!  And when you see staff driving around the Park doing good, you can know you helped make that happen.

Any amount makes a difference.  Start supporting Memorial Park today!

story:
Help us protect 11,000 hectares of Amazon rainforest and create a conservation lab for research, community learning, and sustainable business innovation.

It Begins With A Dream

“Dreams are today's answers to tomorrow's questions.”
– Edgar Cayce

The dream is to protect 11,000 hectares (27,000+ acres) of primary old-growth forest in the southeastern Peruvian Amazon, part of the Tropical Andes Biodiversity Hotspot – the most biologically diverse habitat on Earth.  Home to 1,400 species of butterfly and 45,000 plant species (the next most diverse location hosts 25,000 plant species, by comparison) – as well as many threatened and endangered species including the giant river otter, spider monkey, black caiman, and harpy eagle – it also serves as a buffer between civilization and uncontacted indigenous tribespeople.

This area is located near the newly paved Interoceanic Highway, a major trade route across South America. The highway brings serious threats to the ecosystem and threats to the long-term economic stability of the region.


Making This Dream A Reality

The dream of protecting this important region of the rainforest is within reach. With support from both local and global communities, the ARCC team has engaged a solid strategy to ensure the success of this project.

Phase 1: Completed

Engage the community to understand local needs, develop networks, and program priorities. Lay the legal groundwork for the land purchase. Set up an organization to manage and facilitate the conservation efforts once the land has been purchased. Create media aimed at sharing the beauty and importance of this magical place. (Visit ARCtv for more videos.)

Phase 2: March 2014

Purchase the first 1,000 hectares, the eco-tourism concession. This is the future home of ARCC, the Amazon Research and Conservation Center. Your contributions will make this phase possible. US based non-profit, Wild Forests and Fauna, will match your donation to ARCC. Together we can raise the last 25% needed to purchase the first 1,000 hectares!

Phase 3: December 2015

Protect the resource rich 10,000 hectares, conservation concession surrounding the first 1,000 hectares. The entire area is over 27,000 acres. See Context and Maps. We have a strategy in place to secure this second land purchase and continue to work with local and international partners in order to protect the Madre de Dios Region of Peru and other threatened environments.


Where Will Your Money Go?

Phase 2...the purchase of the initial 1,000ha. We have a couple months to secure the last 25% - $50,000. If we raise $25,000 for Phase 2 by March 2014, Wild Forests and Fauna will match our donations dollar for dollar and we can purchase the first 1,000ha!  If we exceed our goal, the money goes to purchasing the additional 10,000 hectares surrounding the first concession.


What If We Don’t Reach Our Campaign Goal?

Even if we don’t achieve the goal for this campaign, this land is too important to stop trying.  This campaign is just one of several fundraising strategies we will engage over the next year. Stay in touch with us on Facebook and our website. We will keep you posted on our future efforts.


What Is The Long Term Impact of ARCC?

  • Conserving 11,000 hectares of primary rainforest.

  • Providing unique rainforest wilderness experiences for thousands of new visitors.

  • Preserving the lives and cultures of indigenous communities.

  • Generating opportunities for communities and businesses here in Peru and all over the world.

  • Creating a center for research, community learning, and sustainable business innovation.

  • Educating through multimedia efforts such as photography and filmmaking.

  • Protection of 13+ threatened and endangered species, including the harpy eagle, giant river otter, giant armadillo, and blue-headed macaw.






The Team Behind The Dream

“Teamwork is the secret that makes common people achieve uncommon results.”

– Ifeanyi Enoch Onuoha

This project is a collaborative effort of scientists, artists, conservationists, writers, entrepreneurs, musicians, and dreamers working on four continents -

including these individuals and organizations:


ARCC (Amazon Research and Conservation Center)

Fauna Forever

ARCA (Amazon Research and Conservation Alliance)

Wild Forests and Fauna

Relevant Films

Tamandua Expeditions

ProPiedras

Papadosio

Tom Ambrose Photography

Ian Markham Photography

Matthew Champoux Photography

Las Piedras Amazon Tours



Thank you for giving this your time and attention. Even if you are unable to contribute to ARCC at this time, you can still help us reach our goal to preserve one of the planet’s last and most important wild places by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and other media.


If you are a member of the press and would like to cover our story, please contact us here.
story_txt:
Help us protect 11,000 hectares of Amazon rainforest and create a conservation lab for research, community learning, and sustainable business innovation.It Begins With A Dream“Dreams are today's answers to tomorrow's questions.”
– Edgar CayceThe dream is to protect 11,000 hectares (27,000+ acres) of primary old-growth forest in the southeastern Peruvian Amazon, part of the Tropical Andes Biodiversity Hotspot – the most biologically diverse habitat on Earth.  Home to 1,400 species of butterfly and 45,000 plant species (the next most diverse location hosts 25,000 plant species, by comparison) – as well as many threatened and endangered species including the giant river otter, spider monkey, black caiman, and harpy eagle – it also serves as a buffer between civilization and uncontacted indigenous tribespeople.This area is located near the newly paved Interoceanic Highway, a major trade route across South America. The highway brings serious threats to the ecosystem and threats to the long-term economic stability of the region.Making This Dream A RealityThe dream of protecting this important region of the rainforest is within reach. With support from both local and global communities, the ARCC team has engaged a solid strategy to ensure the success of this project.Phase 1: CompletedEngage the community to understand local needs, develop networks, and program priorities. Lay the legal groundwork for the land purchase. Set up an organization to manage and facilitate the conservation efforts once the land has been purchased. Create media aimed at sharing the beauty and importance of this magical place. (Visit ARCtv for more videos.)Phase 2: March 2014Purchase the first 1,000 hectares, the eco-tourism concession. This is the future home of ARCC, the Amazon Research and Conservation Center. Your contributions will make this phase possible. US based non-profit, Wild Forests and Fauna, will match your donation to ARCC. Together we can raise the last 25% needed to purchase the first 1,000 hectares!Phase 3: December 2015Protect the resource rich 10,000 hectares, conservation concession surrounding the first 1,000 hectares. The entire area is over 27,000 acres. See Context and Maps. We have a strategy in place to secure this second land purchase and continue to work with local and international partners in order to protect the Madre de Dios Region of Peru and other threatened environments.Where Will Your Money Go?Phase 2...the purchase of the initial 1,000ha. We have a couple months to secure the last 25% - $50,000. If we raise $25,000 for Phase 2 by March 2014, Wild Forests and Fauna will match our donations dollar for dollar and we can purchase the first 1,000ha!  If we exceed our goal, the money goes to purchasing the additional 10,000 hectares surrounding the first concession.What If We Don’t Reach Our Campaign Goal?Even if we don’t achieve the goal for this campaign, this land is too important to stop trying.  This campaign is just one of several fundraising strategies we will engage over the next year. Stay in touch with us on Facebook and our website. We will keep you posted on our future efforts.What Is The Long Term Impact of ARCC?
Conserving 11,000 hectares of primary rainforest.
Providing unique rainforest wilderness experiences for thousands of new visitors.
Preserving the lives and cultures of indigenous communities.
Generating opportunities for communities and businesses here in Peru and all over the world.
Creating a center for research, community learning, and sustainable business innovation.
Educating through multimedia efforts such as photography and filmmaking.
Protection of 13+ threatened and endangered species, including the harpy eagle, giant river otter, giant armadillo, and blue-headed macaw.

“Teamwork is the secret that makes common people achieve uncommon results.”

– Ifeanyi Enoch Onuoha

story:
Don't Let Ottawa Go To Waste - Legal Defense

Fundraising Goal: $60,000

Organization: Richardson Corridor Community Association in support of the Don’t Let Ottawa Go To Waste Campaign – Legal Defense Fund.

Purpose of Funding:  To help fund our legal fight against Waste Management and the Ontario Ministry of Environment’s decision to approve a new mega landfill on Carp Rd. in Ottawa, Canada.

Background: 

A Brief History of the Carp Rd. Landfill

The dump was first licensed over 40 years ago (1971)

 It has had an extensive history of air and groundwater contamination

 The landfill is operated by Waste Management of Canada

  The old Carp Dump was closed in 2011

  An Environmental Assessment (EA) for a new landfill, just north of the existing dump, was launched in 2010

 The Ontario Minister of the Environment announced approval of the EA in September 2013

For some seven years, the community has been fighting this mega dump that threatens the local aquifer. The landfill sits on fractured limeston, the WORST place for a landfill.  It’s also increasingly surrounded by nearby subdivisions and businesses including Canadian Tire Place (formerly Scotiabank Place) home of the NHL Ottawa Centres.  The dump is only three kilometres downwind of the giant landfill.

What’s wrong with a dump on Carp Rd.

It’s polluting the water. The dump is built on fractured limestone and groundwater contamination around the landfill is a growing problem.  A new dump will only worsen the already shameful situation.  Hundreds of local residents rely on the aquifer for water.

It will STINK. Odour from the old landfill was a health concern and nuisance to residents in nearby neighbourhoods. Odour from a new landfill will only affect more residents and businesses.

It’s too close to too many people. The landfill is situated in the middle of three growing suburbs of Ottawa: Kanata, West Carleton and Stittsville. It is simply too close to too many people.  Truck traffic and environmental issues related to the landfill will only cause harm and conflict to the community.

Why give to this campaign:  By helping our legal fight you will help prevent yet another giant mountain of industrial, commercial and institutional garbage in the middle of some of Ottawa’s fastest growing communities: Kanata, Stittsville and West Carleton. Y

You will also help force changes to Ontario waste management policy. Did you know that less than 15% or ICI waste is recycled?  This is embarrassingly unacceptable!

Current legislation to encourage recycling in this sector is not enforced and desperately needs updating.  If the Carp Landfill approval is not overturned, the status quo of most ICI waste heading to landfill will continue and so will Ontario’s wasteful policies.

Perks:

Donations of $25 will receive a No Dump lawn sign

Donations of $50 will receive a complete dump fighting kit that includes a No-Dump lawn sign as well as a No Dump/Don’t Let Ottawa Go To Waste t-shirt. 

Donations of $100 or more will get a complete dump fighting kit as well as recognition (with permission) on the NoDump.ca website.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

  • Բարի Առավոտ Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
A Lifetime...Ein Leben Lang

After a lifetime of working in and exploring just about every continent except Antarctica, I was rich in experiences beyond imagine...technological marvels and nature at its finest.

Mein Leben wurde durch mein Arbeiten in fast jedem Kontinent der Erde mit Ausnahme von Antarktika und Erforschen der Orte durch technologische Wunderwerke und die außergewöhnliche Schönheit der Natur immens bereichert.

Hi, my name is Don and I believe that we can help the Planet to clean up the back yard we have messed up.

Hallo, ich heiße Don Stein. Ich glaube, daß wir unserem Planeten helfen können, sich zu erholen und  unseren irdischen Paradiesgarten, den wir gewaltig verunreinigt haben wiederherzustellen.

I have been fortunate to have gathered a team of experts and dedicated professionals that have identified technology that is readily available to create a clean, renewable and pollution free fuel. Mother nature has provided us with her secret recipe for clean pure energy and we need your help to bake this cake. 

Ich bin sehr froh in einem  Team von Experten und engagierten Profis an einer Technologie zu arbeiten, die einen erneuerbare und frei von umweltbelastenden Schadstoffen Treibstoff generiert. 

I was raised a country boy and am an equestrian rider with a horse named Betelgeuse and wooly Irish Wolfhound known as Bill. I have dived in many sea's and living along side nature has provided me with the conviction that man is the curator and voice for the animals on this Planet and we haven't done a very good job of looking after many of them.

Ich bin auf dem Land aufgewachsen und und bin passionierter Reiter von meinem Pferd Betelgeuse. Außerdem habe ich einen Irischen Wolfhound, Bill. Ich bin in vielen Gewässern getaucht und habe naturverbunden gelebt. Aus diesen Erfahrungen spricht in mir die Stimme, dass der Mensch als Stimme und Konservator der Tierwelt auf unserem Planeten eingesetzt ist. Bislang haben wir unsere Verantwortung dahingehend nicht ausreichend erfüllt.

With your donation's you can help us to construct and test the BLU LITE plasma hydrogen fuel system and begin to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. 

Mit Ihrem Beitrag können Sie uns helfen das BLU LITE Plasma Hydrogen Antriebssystem zu bauen und damit anzufangen, unsere Abhängigkeit von den fossilen Brennstoffen zu reduzieren.

We have completed the R&D phase of the Blu Lite hydrogen fuel system with great success and now move to the more costly phase of running a prototype jet engine running on water fuel.

Wir haben die Forschungs-und Entwicklungsphase des BLU LITE Hydrogen Antriebssystems mit großem Erfolg abgeschlossen und sind jetzt in der kostenintensiveren Phase der Herstellung des Prototyps des Triebwerks das auf Wasserstoff läuft. 

Your donations will also be matched by Blu Lite to an animal rescue or wildlife foundation, let's give back to our voiceless companions we share this Earth with and take a breath of fresh air once again.

Teile Ihrer Dotation warden von Blu Lite auch an eine Artenschutz oder einer renommierten Tierschutzsorganisation weitergespendet. Lassen Sie uns gemeinsam mit diesen Zeitgenossen, die sich nicht über Sprache artikulieren wieder in klarer und reiner Luft durchatmen.

 

Blu Lite

Blu Lite is looking for $333,000 in funding:

  • to purchase components for the plasma fuel system
  • to manufacture components and installation
  • to test the plasma hydrogen fuel system in a gas turbine engine
  • certification and patents
  • to take Blu Lite to market
  • for documentary video about this evolutionary technology

Blu Lite benötigt €333,000 fur:

  • Die Beschaffung von Komponenten für das Plasmatreibstoffsystem
  • Die Produktion der Komponenten und deren Installation
  • Den Test des Plasmahydrogenantriebssystems einem Gasturbinen system
  • Zertifizierungen und Patentangelegenheiten
  • Die Vermarktung Blu Lite
  • Ein Dokumentarvideo über diese evolutionäre Technologie

 

Blu Lite goes to market: **

  • donor's will be rewarded with this amazing burst of positive energy
  • donor's begin to receive their perks for contributing to clean energy and the welfare of the animals that we share this Planet with
  • all perks will be recieved regardless of Blu Lite reaching final goal

 

Blu Lite kommt auf den Markt: **

  • Geldgeber und Unterstützende  werden mit einem immensen Schub von positiver Energie bereichert
  • Geldgeber und Unterstützende erhalten folgende Anreize für Ihre Beiträge

  • Alle Vergünstigungen werden unabhängig von Blu Lite empfangen werden Erreichen Endziel

 

 

The Impact

We have come to a tipping point on mankind's mismanagement of the Earth's resources and the well being of all that inhabit this Planet, our only home in the expanse of the Universe. 

A new paradigm is required if we are going to be sustainable for future generations and I believe that a clean renewable energy source is the key to the solution. I believe that man, nature and technology can work hand in hand to shape our World to a better place.

Blu Lite technology takes all the goodness nature has given us and we can return it back to its natural state...how good is that.

Die Auswirkungen

Wir sind an einem Wendepunkt der Menschheit Missmanagement von Ressourcen der Erde und dem Wohlergehen aller, die diesen Planeten bewohnen, unsere einzige Heimat, in der Weite des Universums kommen.

Ein neues Paradigma ist erforderlich,wenn wir nachhaltig für künftige Generationen sind, und ich glaube, dass eine saubere, erneuerbare Energiequelle der Schlüssel zur Lösung ist. Ich glaube, dass der Mensch, Natur und Technik Hand in Hand arbeiten, um unsere Welt zu einem besseren Ort zu gestalten.

Blu Lite Technologie nimmt all die Güte der Natur uns gegeben hat, und wir können es wieder zurück zu seinem natürlichen Zustand ... wie gut das ist

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask your friends and work mates to get the word out about the Blu Lite clean energy campaign and make some noise about cleaning up our Planet
  • Use your Social networking to spread the word about Blu Lite and use the Indiegogo share tools!

Weitere Möglichkeiten zu helfen

Manche Menschen können einfach nicht leisten, aber das bedeutet nicht, dass sie nicht helfen kann:
• Bitten Sie Ihren Freunden und Arbeitskollegen, um das Wort aus über den Blu Lite saubere Energie-Kampagne und machen Lärm über die Reinigung bis unser Planet
• Verwenden Sie Ihre Social-Networking, um das Wort zu verbreiten und Blu Lite verwenden Indiegogo share-Tools!

 

The grace of great things...creativity and innovation... restless, curious, playful, contriving...the innovative mind feeds on challenge and makes its home in the province of mystery...one can no more set limits for the mind than one can trap starlight in a bag or convince a yearling not to run.....

Die Gnade der großen Dinge ... Kreativität und Innovation ... ruhelos, neugierig, verspielt, Einfädeln ... die innovative Geist ernährt Herausforderung und macht seine Heimat in der Provinz Geheimnis ... kann man nicht mehr Grenzen für den Kopf gesetzt, als ein Sternenlicht in einer Tasche oder einfangen kann überzeugen einen Jährling nicht zu laufen .....

Kreativität und Innovation ... ruhelos, neugierig, verspielt, Einfädeln ... die innovative Geist ernährt Herausforderung und macht seine Heimat in der Provinz Geheimnis ... kann man nicht mehr Grenzen für den Kopf gesetzt, als ein Sternenlicht in einer Tasche oder einfangen kann überzeugen einen Jährling nicht zu laufen .....

story:
About the Pasig River

The Pasig River has always been an important part of Manila. During the Philippines' early history, prominent kingdoms were based along its banks, making this waterway an important trade route and economic lifeline. When the Spaniards established Manila as their colonial capital in the Far East, they built the walled city of Intramuros at the river’s mouth that leads to Manila Bay.


After World War II, due to the lack of proper disposal facility for the massive amounts of waste produced from the mass urbanization and rapid infrastructure development, the river was turned into a huge sewer system. The deterioration was first observed when fish migration from Laguna de Bay declined during the 1930s. By the 1960s, people had stopped using the river's water for bathing or washing. Ferry services also started to decrease, and by the 1980s, the water started giving off an offensive smell, while fishing activities practically stopped. The river was considered biologically dead by the 1990's. According to an article from the Philippine Information Agency, around 330 tons of industrial and domestic wastes are expelled into the river daily.


The Documentary Project

Pasig River Seen is an ongoing documentary project that aims to raise awareness of the Pasig River's condition and solicit support for its rehabilitation through photography. The images present a photographer’s observations and impressions of the river's current conditions, the cause of the deterioration, ongoing efforts in rehabilitation, and show how all these affect lives.


The initial set of images produced for this project was displayed at the Manila Collective Gallery last August 2010 as part of a group exhibit.


The Photo Exhibit

Selected images from the documentary project will be exhibited at the Filipinas Heritage Library in Makati, Metro Manila, Philippines, from January 17–28, 2011. The event aims to raise awareness and support for the Pasig River rehabilitation effort. Hopefully, this will be the start of a long-term plan to hold a series of traveling exhibits in other public spaces in Metro Manila.


A speaker from Kapit Bisig Para Sa Ilog Pasig, a private-sector advocacy group is involve in river clean-up activities will be invited to give a talk during the exhibit opening. Advocacy materials that will provide information on how to support the rehabilitation effort through donations and volunteer work will also be distributed during the exhibit.


What I Need

I have been doing this documentary project on my own time and financial resources. I am seeking funding support to put together this exhibit. Filipinas Heritage Library is waiving the rental fees for the venue as a primary sponsor. Additional funds is needed for printing, framing, promotional materials and cocktails during the opening.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word. Share this on Facebook. If you are in Manila, Philippines, attend the exhibit opening on January 17 at the Filipinas Heritage Library and learn how you can help save the Pasig River.

story:
Butterfly Farming Will Promote Employment, Education and Conservation for the Tribes of Oklahoma

Be a part of making history!  We are a coalition of Native people developing a first-ever program for tribal members to become butterfly farmers.  This program will provide much-needed employment in rural Oklahoma, but just as importantly it's also about conservation and education. 

Our tribes feel a deep commitment towards protecting the environment and the precipitous decline in the numbers of butterflies in the wild, particularly Monarchs, is the "canary in the coal mine" for warning about the dangers of disappearing pollinators in our fragile ecosystems.  By promoting an awareness of our beautiful species of native butterflies, we hope to inspire people everywhere about how important it is for us to protect them through habitat conservation.  Through butterfly farming we also hope to connect our youth in a hands-on way to the wonders of the natural world and their duties to protect the ecosystems of our tribal lands in the future.  Butterflies are also a hands-on teaching tool to spark their interest in science, an issue of vital importance given that Native people are almost absent from the scientific fields of study at the university level and beyond.


The funds we raise will provide all of the necessary training, equipment and supplies at no-cost for participants to begin butterfly farming. All butterflies raised by the project will be purchased by the Euchee Butterfly Farm, with 100% of payments going directly to the farmers. 

The Natives Raising Natives Project was created by Jane Breckinridge, a Muscogee (Creek) citizen, butterfly farmer, business woman and the fifth generation of her family to live and work on the tribal allotment land where her farm is located.  The project is being sponsored and assisted by The Thlopthlocco Tribal Town, which has also agreed to devote a portion of their tribal land to protecting and preserving threatened species of native butterflies.  All funds raised will be administered through The Learning Center at the Euchee Butterfly Farm, a non-profit corporation registered through the Muscogee (Creek) Nation.




What We Need

We want to raise enough funding for 100 tribal members to start butterfly farming this year.  We have participants signed up and ready to go, and we have contracts in place to purchase every butterfly raised in the program.  All we need to make this project a success is funding for initial start-up supplies and a summer intern to help with training and support.

For every starting butterfly farmer we need the following supplies:

  • “Pop-up” enclosures (2 large, 2 medium, 2 small) = $60.40
  • Seeds and flats for plants = $12.00
  • Dirt to grow host plants for caterpillars = $9.00
  • Initial butterfly breeding stock = $35.00
  • Bleach to sanitize supplies and prevent disease = $14.00
  • Sanitizing tub to sterilize pop-ups and plants = $12.00
  • Storage containers for chrysalides = $12.00

Total start-up cost per butterfly farmer = $151.40

Cost for 100 starting farmers = $15,140

Salary cost for one summer intern = $4800   (40 hours per week helping with training and support for 12 weeks, at $10 per hour) 

  • Total Start-Up Funds Needed = $19,940

If we reach our funding goal, we will be able to raise enough butterflies to generate $75,000 in income directly back to our farmers in 2014.  Even if we fall short, we will still be able to start one farmer in Natives Raising Natives for every $151.40 that we raise.



Our Partners

In addition to the Thlopthlocco Tribal Town, we have had an outpouring of support from many tribes and organizations interested in participating or helping the Natives Raising Natives Project. A few of them include:

  • Langston University
  • The Yuchi/Euchee Tribe
  • The Eufaula Indian Community
  • Kialegee Tribal Town
  • Alabama-Quassarte Tribal Town
  • The Muscogee (Creek) Nation Small Business Development Center
  • The Mvskoke Food Sovereignty Initiative
  • Seminole Indigenous Foods Project
  • The Cockrell Butterfly Center at the Houston Museum of Natural History
  • The Science Museum of Minnesota
  • The University of Minnesota Landscape Arboretum
  • The Desert Botanical Garden


Why Your Contribution is Important

Your gift will make a difference in so many ways.

It will allow a Native in rural Oklahoma to earn income who otherwise might not be able to – a disabled Veteran, a stay-at-home mom, a senior citizen of limited financial means.

It will allow visitors at butterfly houses all over the United States to see gorgeous, rare native butterflies firsthand, to experience for themselves why these treasures of the natural world are worth protecting.

It will allow a Native child to witness the miracle of metamorphosis, possibly inspiring them to shoot for a career in biology, ecology or medicine.

It will provide summer employment to a youth where jobs are scarce, giving him or her a crucial early introduction to the satisfaction and responsibilities of being a paid worker.

It will give children everywhere touched by this project the chance to connect with a butterfly instead of a video game, possibly being the single most important reason why one day in the future they will choose to take a stand for protecting our threatened animals, plants and ecosystems.


Even If You Can't Donate, Please Consider Helping Us In Other Ways

We understand that you may not be able to make a financial donation.  However, you can still make a very valuable contribution towards our success when you spread the word about Natives Raising Natives to your friends, family and co-workers by sharing this Indiegogo page.  Additional exposure will help us to achieve our goals sooner, and it’s easy, too – just use the Indiegogo share tools found on this page.

story:
Short Summary

Hello,

My name is Joe and I am a graduate student at Duke University studying Coastal Environmental Management. My background is biology, however for the last six years I have worked as a boat captain and fishing guide in Alaska. I am also an avid diver and waterman. My latest project involves working with a small group of eco-villas near Sumber Sari, Bali (Indonesia) to restore the near shore marine ecosystem and provide new habitat for coral and benthic communities. The community of eco-villas began the Sumber Sari Reef Project back in 2012, however this project has been mostly stalled. My team and I plan to re-energize this project accomplish the following objectives:

1) Gather baseline data on the pre-existing reef community on the Sumber Sari beachfront and use GIS (geographical information systems) to map the reef extent.

2) Provide recommended site selection for deploying additional reef substrate (locally sourced limestone).

3) Assist in deployment of additional limeston substrate

4) Develop and implement a reef monitoring plan for the Sumber Sari Community. At the moment, no monitoring plan exists for the local reef. The community cannot manage what they cannot measure.

By accomplishing these four objectives, we plan to bring sustainable value to the Sumber Sari coast by increasing diving and snorkeling locations and enhancing the small scale fishery.


Hello,

My name is Alyssa and I am a Master of Environmental Management candidate at Duke University's Nicholas School of the Environmental. I am concentrating in Coastal Environmental Management, and my interests lie within community-based management and geospatial analysis (GIS). Having experience as an AAUS Scientific Diver and living close to the ocean my whole life, I love all things dealing with the ocean. With respect to the Sumber Sari project, I am particularly interested in establishing sustainable tourism operations via the implementation of ecosystem-based management and through the use of GIS. 


What We Need & What You Get

A majority of this funding will go towards dive equipment rental, fiiling scuba tanks and necessary data collection equipment not available through our University. The team and I are not being directly compensated for this project.

Donors will receive a free eco-tour/Dive trip in Sumber Sari. 

The Impact

This project is a pilot project that essentially seeks to answer the question: Is it possible bring sustainable value to a coastal community through ecosystem enhancement?

We are confident that our project will be a success due to our team’s background in environmental science and deep understanding of coastal ecology, economics and project management. We then hope that the model developed by our team can be adopted by other developing coastal communities in the area.


Risks & Challenges

 

For this project, the team will be staying in Bali for seven weeks. We understand that the goals we have outlined are subject to change upon arriving in Bali. We have worked closely with the local stakeholders develop a plan that is attainable given the time constraints. However, most of our time in Bali will be used for data collection, much of this data can then be analyzed here in Durham, NC. If necessary, we will return to Bali during the winter of 2015 to gather more data.

Likely the most difficult challenge the team will face is the cohesiveness of the Sumber Sari community and the willingness to accept and implement our recommendations with regard to reef monitoring. Historically this area has been plagued by unsustainable fishing practices. It is our hope and the hope of the community to increase the sustainable use of their resource by providing economic opportunities in the form of eco-tourism activity diversification. We believe, if the locals can see the value of their resource, they will be more likely to protect it from unsustainable practices. We plan to overcome this hurdle by engaging and educating the community on their valuable resources and maintain contact throughout the monitoring process.

story:
Visit us 

at http://www.thealamedaaesthetic.com


Summary


I grew up in the Napa and Sonoma Valleys, roaming and exploring the outdoors with my father and developing a deep intimacy with and adoration for the natural world.
After serving in the Air Force, going back to school for arboriculture and with trees and the design of nature as my calling, I have endeavored to create an exceptional livelihood in my home region of Northern California and my beloved community of Alameda.
I love Alameda, pruning trees & riding my bicycle. My dream job is pruning trees on my bicycle in Alameda. To do this, I need a custom made bicycle trailer. With your help we can make it happen. 
By donating you will help a dream job come true and start a hyper-local ecological business in Alameda! 


What We Need & What You Get


I need a custom made bicycle trailer capable of hauling all my tools plus 600lbs of tree debris. It will be 8 feet long, 30 inches high and wide. I already have a fabricator and the design ready to go. 

In addition to contributing to a hyper-local ecological business model that improves the community by promoting the beauty and importance of trees as well as the value of bicycling, we have other incentives for your donation. For a donation of only $5 &/or simply sharing this campaign with friends, you get a 10% discount on any of my services in the future (if you have tree(s) in the local area). At least a $25 donation gets you an invitation to our business launch party. At least $75 gets you an in person consultation (if you have tree(s) in the local area) plus an invitation to our launch party. A donation of $150 plus gets you an hour of small tree or shrub pruning/demonstration/consultation (if you have tree(s) in the local area) and a launch party invitation. 

If the funding goal is not reached we will still be contributing the funds towards greening the business in furtherance of obtaining the bicycle trailer to pedal power aesthetic small tree pruning in Alameda. 

Other Ways You Can Help


Share this campaign! Especially with your Alameda or San Francisco Bay area friends.

Since the business is just starting and is not yet well known, please spread the word by visiting and sharing http://www.thealamedaaesthetic.com. Subscribe to my tree blog and follow / share us on social media.

story:
Monarch Waystation Project Summary

Hi we're Nic & Kat. Nic is an arborist and has a great vision for creating habitat for wildlife. Kat is a recent graduate in landscape architecture and wants to apply good design to environmental matters. We have quite a passion to garden and to transform land into something practical, creative, and fun. What could be more fun than seeing a lot of butterflies soaking up nectar in the sun? We want to build a Monarch Waystation.

We want to build a Monarch Waystation and educate others about the importance of these gardens that can be built by anyone. These waystation gardens are like small ponds of water within a desert to the butterflies. These gardens are needed because of habitat depletion due to row crops, roadside mowing, and development. Monarchs need these waystations for food and habitat as they take their long trip across the US to Mexico and Southern California to survive winter in a warmer climate. This little flutter of color needs a lot of energy to fly that far! 

This Monarch Waystation we want to build will provide for hundreds of butterflies and will contain specific plants needed by them, including the milkweed which is the only plant they lay eggs on. The waystation will also benefit many other species of insects and birds. 

Your contribution will fund the purchase of specific plants needed for the waystation garden to be built Summer 2014. The more funds we secure, the bigger and better habitat we will be able to build for the flora and fauna we and our community want to see. In the big picture this project will be benefiting the entirety of the USA and Mexico by keeping the Monarch population in check. We are also going to write about the Monarch Waystation and teach others about building their own through our blog.

What We Need & What You Get

Our design vision for this Monarch Waystation requires us to raise $500 to purchase plant materials. The native plants needed for the garden are typically $8 a piece. For this 200 square foot waystation, we will need about 60 plants. $500 is our goal, but any extra funding will allow us to create a larger waystation and to cover costs of other supplies such as mulch, stone, watering areas for the butterflies, and certification with the Monarch Watch. Even if we don't reach our goal of $500 we can use any funds we receive for purchasing plants. We hope to use as many salvageable materials we can find for hardscaping and creative art in the garden.

For your contribution you will receive some awesome goodies! For your contribution we will send you some nice professional handmade things from our very crafty selves. Including, handmade tote bag, jewelry, postcards, original art inspired by the waystation we create, or a package to start your own Monarch Waystation. Some of these things will be made from flowers we harvest from the garden. Of course, all contributors will be kept up on our blog with how the Monarch Waystation is coming along including tips on creating your own.

If you contribute and would like your name/website on our blog, then send that info to kat.polkadot (at) gmail.com

The Impact

Your contribution will increase the population of Monarch Butterflies. Each dollar will go directly to purchase a plant that gives food and shelter for the Monarch for many seasons to come. This Monarch Waystation will be created this summer of 2014, so your dollar will have an impact very soon.

This waystation will be built within a neighborhood in a community where people will be able to witness and learn about the Monarch Waystation. We hope to not only inspire our community of adults and children to create wildlife habitat, but to also educate others through our blog about the Monarch Waystation.

Other Ways You Can Help

We also thank all the folks clicking the 'share' button to spread the word!
story_txt: Monarch Waystation Project SummaryHi we're Nic & Kat. Nic is an arborist and has a great vision for creating habitat for wildlife. Kat is a recent graduate in landscape architecture and wants to apply good design to environmental matters. We have quite a passion to garden and to transform land into something practical, creative, and fun. What could be more fun than seeing a lot of butterflies soaking up nectar in the sun? We want to build a Monarch Waystation.We want to build a Monarch Waystation and educate others about the importance of these gardens that can be built by anyone. These waystation gardens are like small ponds of water within a desert to the butterflies. These gardens are needed because of habitat depletion due to row crops, roadside mowing, and development. Monarchs need these waystations for food and habitat as they take their long trip across the US to Mexico and Southern California to survive winter in a warmer climate. This little flutter of color needs a lot of energy to fly that far! This Monarch Waystation we want to build will provide for hundreds of butterflies and will contain specific plants needed by them, including the milkweed which is the only plant they lay eggs on. The waystation will also benefit many other species of insects and birds. Your contribution will fund the purchase of specific plants needed for the waystation garden to be built Summer 2014. The more funds we secure, the bigger and better habitat we will be able to build for the flora and fauna we and our community want to see. In the big picture this project will be benefiting the entirety of the USA and Mexico by keeping the Monarch population in check. We are also going to write about the Monarch Waystation and teach others about building their own through our blog.What We Need & What You GetOur design vision for this Monarch Waystation requires us to raise $500 to purchase plant materials. The native plants needed for the garden are typically $8 a piece. For this 200 square foot waystation, we will need about 60 plants. $500 is our goal, but any extra funding will allow us to create a larger waystation and to cover costs of other supplies such as mulch, stone, watering areas for the butterflies, and certification with the Monarch Watch. Even if we don't reach our goal of $500 we can use any funds we receive for purchasing plants. We hope to use as many salvageable materials we can find for hardscaping and creative art in the garden.For your contribution you will receive some awesome goodies! For your contribution we will send you some nice professional handmade things from our very crafty selves. Including, handmade tote bag, jewelry, postcards, original art inspired by the waystation we create, or a package to start your own Monarch Waystation. Some of these things will be made from flowers we harvest from the garden. Of course, all contributors will be kept up on our blog with how the Monarch Waystation is coming along including tips on creating your own.If you contribute and would like your name/website on our blog, then send that info to kat.polkadot (at) gmail.comThe ImpactYour contribution will increase the population of Monarch Butterflies. Each dollar will go directly to purchase a plant that gives food and shelter for the Monarch for many seasons to come. This Monarch Waystation will be created this summer of 2014, so your dollar will have an impact very soon.This waystation will be built within a neighborhood in a community where people will be able to witness and learn about the Monarch Waystation. We hope to not only inspire our community of adults and children to create wildlife habitat, but to also educate others through our blog about the Monarch Waystation.Other Ways You Can HelpWe also thank all the folks clicking the 'share' button to spread the word!

story:
The Mongolian Khulan / Mongolian wild donkey

The Mongolian Khulan - also known as Mongolian Wild Donkey (Equus hemionus hemionus) – is an endangered Asiatic wild Equid which is still less known that the Przewalski's horse.

The Mongolian Khulan is one the 5 recognized sub-species of the Asiatic Wild Donkey and represents the largest population of this species in the world (80% of the species). Its population is now mainly concentrated in south of Mongolia (Gobi Desert) with small populations in north of China (Xinjiang province and Inner Mongolia).

Mongolia represents a very important place for the conservation of the whole species.


The Mongolian Khulan is listed as Endangered in the IUCN Red List and in the Mongolian red list of Mammals.

And is listed in Appendix I of the CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora) and in Appendix II of the CMS (Convention on Migratory Species).


The Gobi Desert 

The ecosystem of the Gobi is very specific and also vulnerable but very few actions have been conducted until now to conserve it, especially in the south-eastern part of the Gobi Desert of Mongolia. 



Why is the Mongolian Khulan endangered ? 

Main threats affecting the survival of the Mongolian Khulan are:

a) Habitat diminution and fragmentation,

b) Illegal hunting and trade for its meat and skin (some organs seem to be also used in traditional medicine),

c) Competition with domestic livestock to access to natural resources (water and pastures) that are limited in the Gobi Desert,

d) Lack of knowledge by herders about this species ecology, 

e) possible impact of climate change. 


About the organizations 

Association GOVIIN KHULAN 

The Association GOVIIN KHULAN, which is a French nonprofit organization, has been established in 2007 with the aim to enhance protection of the endangered Mongolian Khulan and its habitat in partnership with local rangers and communities. This organization has been created in response of the lack of actions conducted to protect the endangered Mongolian Khulan, and this particularly in the southeast Gobi (Mongolia), where there were fewer actions towards this species protection before. Goviin Khulan has built a multidisciplinary approach that will help ensure this species protection on a long term, with respect for local culture and traditions. We have secured support since the beginning from some local rangers, local governments, schools, two Buddhist monasteries and the local community of our study area.

To know more about the Association Goviin khulan and its activities: www.goviinkhulan.com


Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia 

Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia is a non-profit organization established in March 2010 in Mongolia. It follows on the successful launch, in 2007, of the Nomadic Nature Trunk program conducted in 3 eastern provinces of Mongolia (this program has been funded by Wildlife Conservation Society in partnership with Conservation Ink and Denver Zoo). This program is aimed to bring much-needed ecological education to Mongolia's rural schools and communities. 


To know more about the Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia: 

http://www.nnc-mongolia.org/



About the team 

Anne-Camille, is graduated from the University Pierre et Marie CURIE (Paris, France) with a Master research in Natural sciences, specialized in "animal ethology applied to species conservation in-situ". She is studying the Mongolian khulan since 2004. She is also Chairwoman and and research director of the Association Goviin Khulan. 

Tunga, is graduated from National University of Mongolia with Master's degree in Biological Sciences. She has been studying many different species in Mongolia and started studying grey wolf ecology in 1994. She is now Chairwoman and program director of the Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia. 


 

Why we need your support?

We would like to conduct a field trip for about 2 weeks in the southeast Gobi within the coming months. 

This mission is of great importance for our project because it will allows us to conduct activities like:

1- Research activities
 
        -Species ecology

We will continue our research work on behavioral ecology of the Mongolian Khulan and start research work on the grey wolf, and on the relationships predator-prey.

We will also settle some of our trail cameras/camera traps to get further information about these species ecology, nature of interactions with other species (wild and domestic) and human activities, and about biodiversity of our study area (http://www.goviin-khulan.com/explore/2013-research-and-actions/research/). 

 Mongolian khulan (female) walking to a temporary water point. Summer 2012

Mongolian khulan increasing a watering hole at night at a dry river bed. This watering hole has been previously dug by another khulan to access to water located underground. 
http://www.goviin-khulan.com/explore/2013-research-and-actions/research/


       -Illegal hunting and activities

We will collect further information and record any indication of illegal hunting and activities in our study area that could affect these species survival. 

Carcass of a Mongolian khulan illegally hunted we found in 2009 in our study area. 



       -Mining activities 

Our team will also check around some mining sites for which we previously determined locations and for new ones, presence or absence of khulans, density of khulans, behavior and any information related to impact of mining activities on population of khulans. 

2- Nomadic conservation training and education - Community conservation based program

    -Conservation activities 

We will continue to work with local park and volunteer rangers, citizen conservationists, schools and Buddhist monasteries involved in the Goviin Khulan project and with new people as part of our "community conservation based program". 


    -Conservation education - Nomadic Nature Conservation Trunk

We will start using the Nomadic Nature Conservation Trunk created by the Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia in our study area. This conservation trunk contains various items (books, guide books, educational materials, puppets, items to help identify species' tracks...), and some games for activities that could help people understand environmental issues and interactions between species. 

We will also collect some samples that could be used to create items specific to the Mongolian Khulan to create a Conservation trunk specific to our study area in the near future. 


     -Conservation professional training 

We will also provide to park rangers working in the protected area located in our study area, with additional training to use technical equipment we provided them (GPS and camera trap), as well as to provide them with training to conduct some research on ecology of Mongolian khulan and grey wolf. 


3- Local awareness about environment protection

We will also conduct some 

actions to raise local awareness to protect the Mongolian khulan, other Gobi wild species and their habitat. 





During this field trip, as well as during the whole project, local park rangers and volunteer rangers, families involved in the project as "citizen conservationists", buddhist monasteries of our study area, schools of the southeast Gobi, local governments and communities, and other actors of biodiversity conservation will again actively participate to the project. 


What we need and what you will get in return of your support

We need exactly 4,600 USD.

This amount includes all expenses related to the field trip we would like to conduct in our study area  (vehicle renting and driver, gas, per diem expenses, training costs, travel in protected areas, and assistance of park rangers), and indiegogo's fees.  

In return of your donation you will receive very unique contributions, and will also regularly receive updates about our project.

Gifts include: 

-free subscription to our newsletter, 

-free wall paper (photo of the Gobi landscape or of Mongolian khulans in their habitat), 

-postcard from the field, 

-small Mongolian calligraphy, 

-photograph of Mongolian khulans signed by our team (number limited), 

-handmade gift from Mongolia, 

-your logo/name mentioned as official partner of the project, 

-Mongolian art creation, 

-one week in the field with our team during one of our “conservation travel expedition”.


For people who donate from Mongolia, we could change your gift with one of similar value. 


If we don’t reach our goal, funding will be used for other activities of our organizations or will be saved for a next research trip in the Gobi Desert.

If we reach more that our goal (it is something we of course sincerely hope since we really need funding to continue to develop our project!), funding will be used to fund other needs for our project: 

-provide gas to local families, rangers and monks involved in our project to check some of our camera traps during the year, 

-provide further technical equipment to park and volunteer rangers involved in our project, 

-print further educational materials, 

-conduct further educational and training activities in our study area, 

-and much more ! 


Other ways you can help if you cannot donate

If you can't contribute to this campaign, you can speak about our project around you and share the link of this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, by e-mail ... with your friends, contacts, family, colleagues … and help us reach our goal!

You can also follow the link bellow to have more ideas on how you could help our project and then contribute to conservation of the Mongolian Khulan, and share it with your family, friends, and colleagues:

http://www.goviinkhulan.com/soutenir/protect-the-khulan/


1% for the Planet

Goviin Khulan is partner and recipient of the 1% for the Planet, which is an alliance of companies all over the world that donate at least 1% of their sales to environmental organization like ours. 

If you have a company and wish to support our actions, you can also support us through the 1% for the Planet!

Feel free to contact us for any more information.

 

To follow the project

GOVIIN KHULAN's website

Nomadic Nature Conservation Mongolia's website 

GOVIIN KHULAN on Facebook

You can also follow us on Twitter

And you can also contact us at goviin_khulan@live.fr if you have any question about the campaign and the project.


We thank you very much in advance for your support!



Anne-Camille, Tunga and the Goviin Khulan and NNC' teams!

story:
Our Project:

What are our objectives?

The objective lies in understanding the potential of entomophagy (i.e. the consumption of insects) to provide an environmentally sustainable solution to malnutrition for communities with low protein intake.

What is the Importance of edible insects?

Edible insects generally offer higher or similar nutritional quality compared to other forms of livestock, but have a lower consumption of energy and natural resources. they also multiply and grow quicker. Instead, livestock production, including feed-crop production, uses up 70% of the world’s agricultural land, and consumes 77 million tonnes of plant or animal protein to produce just 58 million tonnes of protein for human consumption annually. Obviously, on the long term, the numbers do not add up! For low income communities, low protein intake is one of the main causes of malnutrition which severely restrain a healthy development. 

Hence, in a world were resources are becoming scarce and population is growing, entomophagy is an option which deserves urgent global attention. 

Even in the developed world, there is an increasing demand for edible insects, as these are seen as a solution to contribute positively to lowering our ecological footprint.

What our project consists in?

Our project will take place in the North of Benin. We will be working with the Wama community to understand how they traditionally gather, sell, cook and consume insects. We will also explore the ecological implications of the currently used methods. In addition, to avoid the risk of over-exploiting natural stocks of edible insects in the case of the expansion of this practice, we shall devise methods for insect breeding that can be applied locally and in other communities.

Who's in the team?

Our team members are Laura, Rudi and Mariangela. Let's introduce these lovely people: Laura is the project leader and initiator of this expedition. Her and Rudi are true insect lovers, and have been studying them throughout the years as part of Evolutionary Biology and Integrated Pest Management. They are in charge of the scientific aspects of the project, together with Craig, which is the environmental scientist and science communicator specialist of the team. He will not only look at environmental significance of edible insects, but also be strongly involved in the diffusion and communication of results. Mariangela has specialized in the field of International Development and Environmetal Development Planning. For this project, she will focus on the interpersonal, community and developmental aspects of entomophagy, and prospects for further development projects.

We have been friends for years, and this project has reunited us all around a cause we all strongly believe in. We are passionate about environmental issues, and bringing effective solutions to start building a sustainable solution accessible to those who most need it. We have often traveled around the world and took part in previous projects and expeditions, for example in Mexico and Ghana. We are fully ready for the challenges ahead of us and are eager to bring back fascinating results.... we just need one final thing: your support!

How YOU can help!

We are currently seeking grants and fundraising for the project. Your contribution can make a great difference to support our wonderful initiative and help us further our plans for the expedition.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contributions will be directed towards covering the expedition costs. 

This includes: plan tickets, visas, vaccinations and medical expenses, medical equipment, field equipment, renting of a vehicle and fuel expenses in order to reach remote destinations in which we will be working, renting a house that will serve as headquarters, a local guide to help us with the language and customs of the area, and living costs. Nothing more, nothing less!

To thank you for your contributions, we offer unique and exciting perks directly from Benin! Alternatively you can also just leave a contribution of any amount you decide.

The perks include: a picture with your name spelled out, a series of our ten most beautiful pictures, jewelry from Benin, a personalized video made when we are in Benin thanking you for your contribution, a copy of the report when it gets published, a copy of the film we will put together after the expedition

If ever we did not manage to reach our objective - be reassured! you will receive your money back!


Note to our non-American friends: please take into account that the contributions are in dollars and not in Euros or Pounds, so they might seem more expensive than what they actually are in reality  ;-)

The Impact

The impact of this project really would be to

a. Expand the body of research on edible insects, which will become increasingly useful as we develop new ways to insert entomophagy into our diets, both in the global North and South

b. to provide information to development practitioners seeking solutions for malnutrition. Our aim is for the information collected to really serve the implementation of nutrition projects thanks to the development of breeding techniques, which means that insect eating can be expanded to areas beyond the gathering regions

 

Thank you so much for your help! We are extremely grateful for the attention and contribution you can offer us to make this important project come true to impact people's life globally, now and in the future.

 

Best,

 

Laura, Rudi, Craig and Mariangela

story:
Avec le chantier participatif de la rénovation du bureau d'urbaMonde, nous économiserons ensemble 500l de mazout par an et renforcerons la créativité de l'équipe.

En tant qu’acteur de l’Economie Sociale et Solidaire, UrbaMonde s’engage à :
  • diminuer l'empreinte écologique de son activité
  • promouvoir une ambiance et des conditions de travail favorables à l’épanouissement des personnes

Nos bureaux à la Maison des Associations, sont un lieu unique pour développer l’activité d’urbamonde au coeur du tissu associatif genevois, mais ils sont aujourd’hui une épave énergétique ! 

Nous prenons donc les choses en main et, en partenariat avec la Maison des Associations, organisons un chantier participatif qui permettra :
  • d’isoler les bureaux : plafonds et murs
  • d'installer un éclairage LED
  • de transformer les murs en une surface créative 'white board'
Vous avez ainsi la chance de soutenir cette initiative unique en sponsorisant :
  • 50 l de mazout de chauffage économisé chaque année avec 200chf
  • 100 kwh d’éclairage économisé chaque année avec 100chf
  • boostez la créativité de l’équipe avec un white board avec 50 chf
  • augmentez la bonne humeur de l’équipe avec une plante verte avec 20 chf
Vous pouvez aussi vous inscrire ici pour une demi journée sportive au bureau d'urbaMonde ou venir nous apporter des rafraîchissements !
